name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council of 17 and 18 October 2018 (2018/2772(SDR)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, I will start my report from the European Council with Brexit. Last Wednesday evening, leaders listened to Prime Minister May’s views on the negotiations. Afterwards, the EU27 met in the Article 50 format, with our chief negotiator Michel Barnier, to discuss the state of play. It was made clear by the UK that more time is needed to find a precise solution. Therefore, there is no other way but to continue the talks. Leaders expressed their full trust and support for Michel Barnier. Since Prime Minister May mentioned the idea of extending the transition period, let me repeat that if the UK decided that such an extension would be helpful to reach a deal, I am sure that the leaders would be ready to consider it positively. President Juncker also touched upon preparations for a no-deal scenario, an outcome which we hope never to see. And, of course, I stand ready to convene a European Council, if and when the Union negotiator reports that decisive progress has been made. The Brexit talks continue with the aim of reaching a deal. Turning to migration: in the course of our regular discussions, on Thursday morning we had an exchange on our migration policy in all its aspects. The EU leaders want to strengthen external border control and deepen cooperation with third countries to stop illegal arrivals. The focus last week was also on increasing cooperation with countries in North Africa, and a tougher approach to people-smuggling networks.  Leaders noted the Union’s achievement in stemming mass arrivals of irregular migrants over the past three years, even if more remains to be done. We thanked the Austrian Presidency for its efforts to reform the Common European Asylum System and agreed that work should continue with a view to finding an agreement as soon as possible. The European Council also adopted a number of decisions on internal security. Some of them should be seen in the context of increased concerns and risks of hybrid, cyber, as well as chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear threats. One element of particular interest was the leaders’ call to create a capacity to respond to, and deter, cyber-attacks through EU sanctions. Of course, this is especially important in light of the European elections next year and the active threat posed by malicious, outside interference in our democracies. During the Euro Summit, the Eurogroup Chair, Mário Centeno, gave an update on the finance ministers’ work on the ESM reform and the banking union while the European Central Bank President, Mario Draghi, informed leaders on the economic outlook. The objective of the meeting was to keep up the pressure for concrete results in December. EU finance ministers should speed up their work if we are to achieve our goal, which is strengthening the ESM and the banking union further. Leaders also held a short debate on external relations, including on the fight against climate change ahead of COP24 in Katowice. We adopted conclusions on taking our relations with Africa to a new level – an issue of great importance – and in this context agreed to organise a summit with the League of Arab States on 24 and 25 February next year. For many of the issues discussed at the European Council – from migration to security – as well as the need to scale up the Union’s presence as a global actor in many fields, the EU’s budget is key. At a technical level, there have been detailed discussions on the next multiannual financial framework, but, in general terms, we are far from reaching any sort of consensus. This is why I will propose a political discussion at the December European Council. I welcome the intention that the consolidated position of this Parliament is to be known by then. Let me close with a word on the shocking killing of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Turkey earlier this month. This was such a horrible crime that even the slightest trace of hypocrisy would bring shame on us. It is not my role to state who wants to protect whose interests here. But I know one thing: the only European interest is to reveal all the details of this case, regardless of who is behind it. Knowing your sensitivity and determination, I believe that you will not allow for Europe, the Member States or the institutions, to become involved in any ambiguous game.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, on behalf of Jean-Claude Juncker, I will not go into great detail on the October European Council, as President Tusk has already shared a full account of the results achieved.  Allow me to touch very briefly on the negotiations with the United Kingdom. As was clear after the European Council, the bottom line is that we do not yet have the decisive progress that we need. The goodwill and the determination to find an agreement as soon as possible are there, but it is also clear that we will not rush a deal through at the expense of our principles or our agreed commitments, most notably on the Irish border issue. With all of this in mind, we must now continue negotiating with patience, calm and an open mind.  The Commission and our chief negotiator, Mr Michel Barnier, received the full backing of all leaders to do just that. It is time to deliver and we are getting on with the job. That is what we are focused on doing across all of the issues that matter the most for our future, as we discussed yesterday when we debated the Commission's work program.  When we talk about our future, we must first talk about Africa. Our partnership with Africa has enormous potential for both sides. It must be fair and balanced, helping both partners to grow. This is why the Commission last month proposed a new Africa-Europe Alliance for Sustainable Investment and Jobs, to strengthen the economic partnership with our African friends. This is about concrete action, taking forward commitments made together with the African Union over the past years, notably in Abidjan. With your support and that of the Member States, the Alliance will help attract investment in Africa. It is expected to create 10 million jobs over the next five years and support youth employability through education and training.  The External Investment Plan is well in motion to serve the ambitious objective of jobs and growth creation. It is well advanced in order to mobilize over EUR 44 billion in both public and private investments. The project already in the pipeline will unlock EUR 24 billion. The potential is there. The framework is there. Now it is time to deliver results.   Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren! Die Europeer messen uns nicht an der Zahl der Worte, sondern daran, ob wir diese umsetzen. Ich appelliere daher an Sie und den Rat, die Vorschlàge, die die Kommission bereits vorgelegt hat, voranzubringen. Das gilt vor allem, wenn es um die zentralen Fragen unsere Zukunft geht, wie etwa die Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion sowie Migration und Sicherheit. So messen wir unsere Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion vertiefen, so dass wir ger-stet sind, bevor neue Wolken in der Weltwirtschaft aufziehen. Der Erfolg des Euro h-ngt davon ab, dass jeder einzelne Mitgliedstaat seine Hausaufgaben macht - genauso wie die Kommission ihre Hausaufgaben erledigt hat. Von den 40 Vorschlungen, die wir zur st-rkung der Wirtschafts- und Wàhrungsunion auf den Elfmeterpunkt gelegt haben, wurden allerdings bis jetzt nur sechs angenommen. Das muss sich 'ndern! Bis zum Eurogipfel im Dezember wollen wir, wie bereits im Juni vereinbart, die Bankenunion vollenden. Das hei't vor allem, dass wir den einheitlichen Stabilit-tsmechanismus stunken, welcher die Letztsicherung (back stop) fer den einheitlichen Abwicklungsfonds 'bernehmen soll. Auserdem messen wir mit unserem Fahrplan hin zu einem einheitlichen europeischen Einlagensicherungssystem vorankommen. In allen diesen Fragen haben wir ebenso wie bei der Vertiefung der Kapitalmarktunion keine Zeit zu verlieren.  Das gilt gleichermaen fer die Vorschlàge, die wir zur Migration vorgelegt haben. Wir messen jetzt an umfassenden europeischen Lsungen arbeiten, die langfristig wirken. Die Kommission hat dazu eine Reihe von Vorschlungen vorgelegt, unter anderem zum Ausbau der europeischen Grenz- und Kostenwache, fer wirksamere und make R-ckf-hrungen und zur Reform of Dublin-Systems. Es ist eine Frage europeischer Solidaritet und Verantwortung, dass wir in all diesen Themen Fortschritte machen, und das erwarten die Europeer auch von uns. Ich setze daher weiterhin auf Ihre Unterst-tzung, sehr geehrte Abgeordnete, sodas wir bis zu den Wahlen greifbare Ergebnisse liefern.  - the same in the area of security. Since the beginning of its mandate, this committee has presented numerous legislative proposals, of which only a handful have already been adopted. I would remind you that we have a burning obligation to ensure the safety of our citizens. I would therefore like to see the 20 or so proposals that remain on the table of co-legislators, including those on interoperability, adopted without further delay. There is an urgent need to do so, whether it is cybersecurity or the fight against terrorist content posted online and misinformation that threatens our democratic processes. We must guarantee free elections, transparent and fair. I would also like to add that I am pleased that the Council has agreed that our proposal to establish a new system for combating natural disasters, the RescUE, should be adopted by the end of the year. We cannot accept that more lives are devastated and economies are destroyed because we would not have been able to act in time with all the determination and solidarity we need. Last week was also marked by other summits, especially with our friends in Asia. These summits were an opportunity to reaffirm our shared commitment to multilateralism and a rules-based international order, this commitment coming from a group - Europe and Asian countries - which together accounts for 60% of the world's population and 65% of the world's GDP (gross domestic product). We have also signed new bilateral agreements, notably with Singapore. This agreement will tighten our economic and political ties with Singapore and open up new opportunities for European producers, workers, farmers and consumers, as the EU has achieved around the world with other partners. Our shared determination to meet global challenges will be strengthened by political dialogue. Trade and investment agreements will now be sent to the European Parliament for approval, so that the trade agreement can enter into force before the end of the Commission's current mandate. The Commission has also begun the process of concluding trade and investment agreements between the European Union and Vietnam, and many other agreements are being negotiated. All these agreements go far beyond the traditional abolition of tariffs to also integrate the values and commitments we share, especially in the fight against climate change. In December, in Katowice, Poland, we will all have to live up to the extreme urgency of climate issues and our commitments under the Paris Agreement. In Katowice, the Commission will present its long-term vision and strategy. Scientists from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have told us the truth and we have no time to waste. We no longer have time to think for the next few decades. Now is the time to act. We must work to save our planet and our civilization. Early last week, Jean-Claude Juncker also attended the tripartite social summit. This Commission has put social priorities at the heart of our action, because for too long the social dimension has remained the poor relation of European integration and I would remind you that since the beginning of our mandate, we have presented some thirty legislative proposals in the social field, almost half of which have yet to be adopted. We are therefore counting on the Austrian Presidency so that by the end of the year we will be able to conclude all these subjects. December must be a decisive month for social Europe and we are pleased that during this European Council no Member State has said that we cannot reach an agreement in principle on the next European Union budget before May 2019, a goal that this House has already signalled as essential. We welcome the future of social Europe in particular, with in particular our proposal to provide the European Social Fund with more than EUR 100 billion in budget to support the implementation of the main principles of the European social rights base, which is a genuine programme of action in an area where Member States hold the bulk of competences. It is about our credibility, it is about the trust of our fellow citizens, our students and our researchers in a Europe that listens to their concerns and expectations and provides them with concrete solutions to protect them and offer them better prospects for the future.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to the representatives of the political groups, I wanted to inform the House of what I said during my speech to the European Council. I have insisted on three fundamental points for the European Parliament.  The first point is the Dublin reform, which the Council should approve – and we want it to approve – as soon as possible, perhaps even by qualified majority.  The second point was that of the multiannual financial framework. We are calling for the budget to increase from 1.1 % to 1.3 % also through the own resources instrument.  The third point is brexit, and I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Brok and Mr Gualtieri, who were in Parliament's offices during the Council to support Parliament's action. We have said that there are three fundamental points for us: citizens' rights, the financial issue and the backstop. If one of these three points is not present, the European Parliament will not be able to vote in favour of the Brexit Treaty.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, thank you for reframed a little bit of the discussion we are going to have this morning on the European Council, because we have heard a wonderful electoral programme from Mr Timmermans. But I will just talk, like you, about the conclusions of this Council because from Salzburg to Brussels, last chance in last chance, the summits pass but the problems remain. Let's give ourselves a little more time, they say, but we don't have any more time, we've already lost too much! We are in a moment of extreme urgency, a few months before European elections which are shaping up to be perilous for the future of Europe. However, our national leaders meet but do not decide. Every week we are entitled to the same litany of promises and declarations of good intentions and, behind it, is the blockage. Let's take a look at the menu of this Council: as an entry, emigration and internal security. We know the solutions. If this Council has indeed enabled, Mr Vice-President, to bring about a consensus on the external dimension of the problem and cooperation with the countries of origin, with regard to the internal dimension and the organisation of solidarity, no lasting solution is emerging. In the main course: Brexit. Despite michel Barnier's remarkable efforts, we are still leaving without agreement. At least it will have brought the unity of European countries back and Theresa May's UK to account. Dear British friends, the ball is in your court. Finally, the eurozone. It is clear that if we had a new debt crisis tomorrow, which is a real risk, there is no guarantee that we will be better off. Not all the lessons of the past have been learned, and we are just able to agree on the need, which has been repeatedly raised, to strengthen the banking union. That is not enough to reassure. The balance sheet is not rosy. The European asylum policy: stalled! Eurozone reform: stalled! The taxation of large digital companies, a measure of tax justice that is highly anticipated by our citizens: at a standstill! Brexit: stalled! As for Italy's budget, which could tip the whole eurozone into a new crisis, we act as if we do not see the elephant in the room. And courage, where has courage gone? Europe remains in balance, on the razor's edge, as if tetanus. However, it is not the fault of the Commission, which has never been as voluntary as it is today, or of Parliament, which is redoubling its efforts to complete the many texts currently on the table on time, particularly with regard to the next multi-year financial framework. We are making progress, we are moving forward, but President Tusk himself has told us that we are far from an agreement. It is not easy to agree at 28, but we have seen it again recently in defence, when the political will is there, no obstacle is insurmountable. What is the conclusion? Quite simply, there is a lack of political will on the part of our Member States. Some are motors, but many are standing on the brake pedal. At this rate, the road exit is not far away. (Applause)

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President of the European Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the We are in the process of reaching a great agreement in this House when it comes to assessing the last summit. That, in any case, is my impression. It was a lost date – a date that did not provide answers, a date when the Heads of State or Government have once again shown themselves incapable or unwilling to move Europe forward, and where they have been unable to understand that we are only stronger together. This is a bad image for Europe, represented by the majority of Heads of State or Government. It is my firm conviction that we cannot afford this, seven months before the European elections. Mr Tusk, I would like to compliment you. They are very capable of maintaining a diplomatic language. I appreciate that, you understand. But if you praise the Austrian Presidency for making progress on asylum policy and for making efforts, what efforts did you mean? It may be that I missed something. But please explain to us what efforts you have made in this context by the Austrian Presidency. The opposite is true! It is being sat out, the asylum package is being blocked. That is the reality, and that divides Europe. It does not bind Europe together, it does not build a bridge. The slogan of this Austrian Presidency is wrong. The Austrian Presidency is dividing Europe and giving no answers. That is the truth in this situation, which we no longer accept, which we no longer tolerate. What is happening in the Mediterranean is a scandal. We have said this more than once. We urgently need more sea rescue. That is why we are working to ensure that those who risk their lives are also honoured for being given the dignity to receive the Sakharov Prize. But we know that we need basic solutions – basic solutions in solidarity with secure escape routes, with regulated labour migration and with the asylum package that the European Parliament has adopted. ast weekend showed that when Europe is united, the consequences can be amazing. Last Saturday, we saw some 700,000 people marching in London to have a final say on a possible Brexit deal. We think the British people deserve – once they have seen the measures and the consequences of this divorce and once they have seen the lies of the Brexiteers – to have a final say on their future. This is my firm supply and this is my understanding of democracy. The next European elections are of outstanding importance for the future of our continent and for the future of democracy. You have seen that right-wing radicalism and populism are joining together to undermine the European Union, to put the European Union at risk. Fake news – we discussed this yesterday – the systematic way of undermining democratic decisions must be vigorously combated, and here too we have missed the Austrian Presidency. The Conservatives in the House must decide whether they want to continue to defend democracy and the European Union, or whether they are the ones who open the door to the right-wing radicals. This is a decision, ladies and gentlemen, that you must make if you want to continue to be a reliable partner in the European Union. And we will look at you. Our path is clear: there is a positive moment in these resolutions. Yes, Pedro Sanchez has succeeded in putting sustainability, the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, on the agenda. We look forward to the Commission's contribution. We want to move forward decisively. That is the way in which we can move Europe forward. That is what my group stands for.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Mr Bullmann, I would remind you, when you talk about right-wing extremists, we have to remember that Nazis were National Socialists. It’s a strain of socialism. So let’s not pretend: it’s a left-wing ideology; they want the same things as you. Let’s be quite clear. (Uproar) So Mr President, despite all that – you don’t like the truth, do you? – you don’t like that. Come on, it’s National Socialism. (Interjection from the floor: ‘Rubbish’) A lot happened – I’m saying – I’m telling you – it’s a left-wing ideology, OK? Don’t pretend. A lot happened in Brussels last week, and it is sometimes easy to forget that some of the things that happened were positive. As leader of one of the most pro free-trade Groups in the European Parliament, we welcome the signature of the trade, investment and partnership agreements with Singapore, just as we welcome the progress on the EU-Japan trade deal and the adoption of the Vietnam trade agreement. We also welcome the US Government’s push for agreements – the Trump administration’s push for agreements – with Japan, the EU and the UK. These developments, we believe, are a signal of a more outward-looking EU, a re-engaged USA, and a global Britain. However, it is difficult sometimes to convince the electorate when things are going in the right direction, when we had yet another summit with no clear outcome on migration or on Brexit – as you said, Ms Grossetête. Agreeing a withdrawal agreement may be complex, but many of us have been here long enough to know that there is no such thing as an impossible situation. We have seen time and time again the seemingly impossible become the possible, the inflexible become the flexible, the proverbial rabbit pulled out of the hat at the 11th hour for situations that have been described as ‘all or nothing’, such as a Danish opt-out, or Protocol 36 with the UK – legal experts managed to find unique solutions. In this case, either the seemingly impossible will become possible, or there will be no deal. Mrs May’s position on the backstop isn’t a negotiating position or a bluff: it is quite simply a Prime Minister defending the constitutional sovereignty and geographical borders of a nation of a hard-won peace, born through generations of violence and diplomacy. It was clear that, as leaders sat on the Grande Place sharing a joke and a drink, instead of continuing into the early hours of the morning, there was no real sense of urgency around reaching a deal at this Council Summit. So the sooner we start building our shared future, rather than fighting about our shared past – our joint past – the better for everyone. What we need to do is redouble our efforts to find compromises that address the concerns of both communities in Northern Ireland, not just the Nationalists and the Irish Government. Let us look again at indicative time limits, possible sunset clauses, declarations, protocols and technology away from borders that allows checks away from borders. Let’s look to the future, not cry over the past. The ECR believes that one way of regaining the confidence of the voters is a clear and united policy on the handling of the migration crisis. We welcome the fact that many of the policies now being discussed within the Council were policies proposed by the ECR Group at the peak of the crisis, such as speeding up processing returns; increasing funds and powers for Frontex; seeking enhanced arrangements with third countries to stem the flow of migrants; and allowing countries to contribute in other ways apart from only relocation. If these common-sense policies had been adopted sooner and not dismissed as simply anti-European or populist at the time, then maybe the system might be in better shape now. This is why the ECR Group doesn’t wish to see another national or European election go by, where Brussels dismisses the results or the legitimate concerns of its electorate in favour of policies which actually have not yet reached a real result. Instead, we should be asking countries how they are willing to help. Some will take in genuine asylum seekers; some will help refugees closer to their homes; some will give money to help frontline countries. So whether it’s Brexit or the migration crisis, the time for talking and posturing on both sides is nearing an end. It is time to focus on the future, not simply cry over the past.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I do not believe that there are nostalgic people or heirs to Nazism or the Soviet Communist dictatorship in this House, two horrific and devastating political systems that have caused deep wounds to Europe. Thank God these two dictatorships have disappeared thanks to the European Union. (Laughter) There's little to laugh about, there's little to laugh about, there's little to laugh about! We must respect the ideas of others, even if we do not agree. Risus abundat in hours stultorum. Learn to respect others if you want to be respected. Mr Farage, you learn to respect others, because that is democracy. You are obviously nostalgic for some dictatorship if you do not respect the opinions of others. We have always respected yours and you have no authorization not to respect that of others. Remain silent!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to address Mr Kamall. I want to tell you something. I think that what you did was not very wise, and that you have to apologise, in fact, because talking about Nazis as National Socialists and pointing a finger at the Socialist Group is an insult to all those Social Democrats who fought against Nazis, (Applause) and who died in concentration camps. I think that would be the best step from your side.  To Ms Grossetête, I say thank you very much for your comments. I think I agreed with you 100% – more even than when Manfred Weber takes the floor – and I think it is exactly the feeling of the House. Why was it necessary to have a European Council in October? Nothing has been decided – not on Brexit, that was expected; not on migration and the Dublin system, no progress; not on the eurozone governments, no progress. First of all, on Brexit, you know, we are now in the battle of the figures. Prime Minister May says 95% has been agreed. Michel Barnier says 90% is being agreed. I know that Britain has always had difficulties with the metric system, but I have to tell you one thing: whether it is 90% or 95% or 99%, if there is no solution for the Irish border, then as far as our Parliament is concerned it is zero per cent that has been agreed for the moment. We need an agreement on this Irish border, and the Good Friday Agreement has to be protected.  Nevertheless, I continue to be optimistic. I think that a deal can be reached in the coming weeks, in the interest of the Union and in the interest of the UK, and my question to you, Mr Tusk, is this: can you also make a decisive last push on citizens’ rights – that is, to offer unlimited onward movement for the British citizens who are living in the EU27, in exchange for a right of lifelong return to the UK for European citizens? I was in Downing Street, and they are ready to go for such a trade-off, and if you, with the Council, were to push for such a solution, it is a trade off that is possible. So do that at least, for our citizens, so that they have no negative fallout from this Brexit tragedy that we are living through today. (Applause) That brings me to the second point for the Council – namely migration. I will repeat, and I will say it not in French but in English, that I am very disappointed, as is Ms Grossetête. It is now four months since June when the Council promised that an enormous package would be delivered. The transformation, for example, of Frontex into a fully fledged European Border and Coast Guard with 10 000 new agents – no agreement in the Council on that. The reform of the Dublin system – it was two years ago that the Commission put the proposal on the table – again, no progress in the Council. Finally, my third complaint is about the lack of reform of the eurozone, including the Banking Union. It’s now more or less 10 years since the outbreak of the last financial crisis and we still have no governance system in place for the eurozone. Nevertheless, we all know that there could be a next crisis, and this time maybe not in tiny, sunny Greece but in the world’s eighth biggest economy, namely Italy. We have not a single pension fund or investment company in the whole world today that does not hold Italian bonds or securities. So, let there be no misunderstanding, I think that the attitude of the Italian Government in not following the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact is completely irresponsible. But, at the same time, I’m also saying that a big share of the responsibility rests on our shoulders in relation to the strategy that is coming up. Where is the new governance of the Economic and Monetary Union to avoid the sort of free-riding behaviour that the new Italian Government wants to engage in now? Where is the new Minister of Finance for the Eurozone, who could stop such behaviour? Where is the euro budget? Where are the euro securities and, more urgently – if, in the coming months or year, this sovereign debt crisis should become a banking crisis – where is the resolution fund? How are we going to avoid the next bankruptcy in the eurozone, not only of the Italian financial sector but also perhaps of the entire European financial sector? I really think that the attitude of your colleagues in the Council today is dereliction of duty: sleepwalking to a new financial catastrophe that everybody can see before their eyes. I have one ultimate question, Mr Tusk, it’s not a question directly to you my dear Donald, but you are responsible for it, and it concerns method. Is this really the method that will deliver: the government leaders coming together four times a year for two days, and looking forward to getting back again quickly to their capitals? I think the method is wrong. You need to lock them in a meeting room – no new clothes, no new underwear … (Comment from Mr Lambert ‘no food’) No food? No, that would be torture, that is something different, Mr Lambert. But it is necessary, Mr Tusk, that you change your method. I was with Jean Claude Juncker in Nice, and we worked for four days, and four nights until four o’clock in the morning, and we came out not with the best deal that we have ever done but at least having achieved something. Today we are in the middle of a migration crisis. We face a new financial tragedy in the eighth biggest economy of the world, in Italy, and our government leaders go home and say it was not possible to find an agreement on migration and on the Dublin system; it was not possible to put in place new governance for the eurozone. That has to change. It’s not five minutes before midnight, Mr Tusk, it’s five minutes after midnight.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to raise a point of order. In his speech, Mr Kamall said that the National Socialists – that is, the fascists – were, after all, socialists. He has brought the fascists who set this world on fire close to my political family. I think this is such an unspeakable derailment! I would like to remind you that it was the German Social Democrats who voted unanimously against the Empowerment Act, against Hitler – the only ones, incidentally; others were already in the concentration camp at the time. There are hundreds of thousands of Social Democrats, of upright democrats, of decent people who have fallen victim to Nazi terror because they have cultivated the upright aisle, because they have defended democracy and human dignity. I find this such an unspeakable outrage by Mr Kamall, such a derailment of this Parliament, unworthy in Europe, that I would ask you, Mr President, to ask Mr Kamall to apologise immediately.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: – Mr President, I will explain to Mr Bullmann and then I will move on. I do get tired of people saying that Nazism is a right—wing ideology. We disagree on this. But what I would say is that I believe in freedom of speech. But if I have offended you – and clearly I have – I apologise unreservedly. I have apologised. If I offend – and clearly I have offended you – I apologise unreservedly. I do not believe in offending my political opponents or offending my friends, so I apologise. I hope you will accept that.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I believe that Mr Kamall has given a clear signal, he has apologised to Mr Bullmann and to the Socialist Group. Evidently...  Let me finish talking, then you talk. I believe that Mr Bullmann has accepted Mr Kamall's apology.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: – Mr President, Mr Kamall knows what he is talking about. Sorry.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Kamall has formally apologised. The historical judgment of National Socialism, whether it was right-wing or not right-wing, is not up to us to decide.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the What the honourable Member does not understand is that it is not about our personal relationship. It is a question of someone bringing social democracy close to the fascists. That is what it is all about! Not whether he is kind to me or not. I insist that he correct that.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Kamall has apologised. He reiterated in his speech that he believed that National Socialism – perhaps the terminology was wrong – was not part of socialism, but was not, he argued, a right-wing ideology, it was a totalitarian ideology, not a right-wing ideology, because for Mr Kamal...  (Interruption by Mr Bullmann) If you let me explain, I try to interpret and find a solution.  It was an ideology that was neither right-wing nor left-wing, but it was a dictatorial ideology. If we have to say what the right is and what the left is, let us stop. But the important thing is that he apologized.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the They are in the process of making the issue worse. No one is in a position at the moment – neither Mr Kamall nor you – to understand what a political piggy back it is to bring the Socialists in Europe close to the fascists. I insist on clarification. It is not about my personal, our personal state of mind. It is a historical madness, a demagogy of the right in this House. They unmask their inability to comprehend political processes historically and up-to-date. Now I know exactly who spirit child they are. And, Mr President, please do not identify with it, because you do not pay homage to the colour to which you belong.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I didn't understand what approach. Now let us close the debate.  Mr Kamall has apologised. No one in this House, starting with the President, thinks that National Socialism has anything to do with the history of the Socialist Party throughout Europe, either in Germany or in other countries. Then the ideological and cultural debate is something else.  Mr Kamall apologised and explained, I think he said very clearly that he did not want to offend socialism and he did not think that National Socialism was linked to socialism. This is, I understand, at least from the translation.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (start of speech outside the microphone) ... Article 11(3) of the Rules of Procedure: obligation to respect each other in the Debate of the Chamber. Mr President, I ask that Mr Bullmann apologise to all members of the right for associating right-wing ness with any extremism. From Winston Churchill to polish right-wing politicians who rotted in Nazi and Communist prisons, we're ironing out that language! We are constantly hearing the division, segregation of Europeans, the treatment of people with right-wing views as people of a worse sort, who can be attributed to extremism, radicalism. And i ask you, Mr President, to react to this demagogoy every time. We Poles politische Schweine associates as the worst and we iron out this language!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It is clear to everyone that neither Communism nor Nazism has anything to do with parties that are present in this House, either historically or politically. I said that and that is very clear to everyone. I do not believe that Mr Bullmann wants to associate Nazism with the liberal right, and I do not think that Mr Kamall thinks he is associating Nazism – if he has had the wrong expression he has apologised – with the history of the Socialist Party, because no one, starting with the President, believes that National Socialism can be associated with the history of socialism in Europe, nor that National Socialism can be associated with the liberal right. , because both the liberal right and socialism fought together against the Nazi dictatorship and the Communist dictatorship. Let us close the debate, otherwise let us have a historic debate, and that is clear!

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tusk, I do not know if you are interested, but finally we can always talk. The Treaty on the European Union makes the European Council the body that gives the necessary impetus for the development of the Union and defines its general political priorities. The citizens of the Union are therefore entitled to expect some political leadership from the 28 heads of state and government that make up it. Between the climate change and the growing inequalities, the conflicts and persecutions at our borders, the terrorist threat, the impact of the digital revolution or the exorbitant power of multinationals, it is little to say that our Union faces existential challenges in a world where its friends are becoming scarce. This is probably why in October 2017 the European Council set up a programme of work called, somewhat pompously, 'The Leaders' Agenda'. A year later, where are we? We welcome the adoption last spring of the declaration on the European pillar of social rights. Although it is largely a statement of intent, it has the merit of recalling that human well-being is not just about maximizing the profits of a few. But other than that, we are still looking for the leadership of the European Council and its meeting last week provided, once again, a sad example. On the issue of Brexit, the 27 heads of state and government cannot be held responsible for the failure, we are facing here a British government entangled in its own contradictions and an Theresa May torn between members of her majority and her party. Until she decides this Gordian knot an agreement cannot be reached. But on the other issues, no excuses for the "leaders"! Let us take the issue of asylum and immigration: this subject may have been on the agenda of all European Council meetings for more than three years , with one exception - but the heads of state of the Member States are still unable to agree on a common approach to welcome asylum seekers to our continent with dignity. The only common ground at the moment is to discard their responsibilities to the neighbouring states of the European Union. It has been a year since this Parliament has been able to find, on the same issue, the political courage and creativity to propose common solutions in line with the values of the European Union, proof that a political agreement on this issue is indeed possible if there is political will. On the issue of monetary union, the heads of state and government have not advanced one iota. How many times will we have to repeat that an economic and monetary union is not viable - I repeat, not viable - without a fiscal union and therefore a fiscal union and without a social union. Here again, while tensions are revived by the Italian government's budgetary choices, the "leaders" remain in denial of reality. The ecologist I am would be tempted to ironise on CO2 emissions and the blockade of Brussels caused by yet another inconsequential European summit. But this lack of leadership is in fact not without consequences. It weakens the European Union every day in its ability to respond to the challenges of our time and undermines its credibility. One gets the impression that the conservatives, the Christian Democrats, the Social Democrats, the liberals who populate the Council are proving to be a little less able to understand these challenges every day and are taking refuge in a choreography without impact on reality. Is it any wonder, then, that an increasing number of our fellow citizens are choosing to find their questions elsewhere? Of course, with nationalists of all stripes, but also, and I welcome it, more and more with the environmentalists, as the recent elections in Bavaria, Belgium and Luxembourg have shown and, who knows, perhaps in a few days in Hesse.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Sorry, ladies and gentlemen, but I will return in my speech to the controversy of just now. Mr Kamall, I would really recommend to you: read Klemperer's diaries, read his treatise on the language of the Third Reich, "LTI – Lingua Tertii Imperii"! You will find that what happened there, namely misuse, reinterpreting terms, is not just a matter of the past and the manifestly flawed confrontation on your part with the history of Europe – which is why the European Union came into being after the devastating war of the last century – but that it is current today. Why my Social Democrat colleagues react in this way – and rightly – has something to do with the reconnection of the concept of National Socialist/national, and the fact that this is happening again. There are in our countries. There are people on the streets who are collecting weapons, who are ambushing foreigners, who are invading the left, who are murdering – in Europe, in our EU.  You must have understood this slowly, but you cannot have isolated yourself – on your island – from the history of Europe. They are one of them. That is what I had to tell you. It is not a recklessness to deal with these terms.  (Applause) It is not a recklessness, it is a political outcry that you have done here. I would like to say to you: please read, deal with things and, above all, see what is happening in our Member States! I now come to the summit. Much has been said about the way in which the summit went, what it brought. But at the end of the day, we still face one of the biggest challenges, both with Brexit in mind – Theresa May can say ten times: we are now at 90%, we are at 95%, we are at 97%, or at 99.5%. The crucial question is: is the British Government prepared to find a solution within the withdrawal agreement – the divorce agreement – which includes acceptance, respect for the Good Friday Agreement and avoids the rights it enshrines for the citizens of the north of Ireland and, at the same time, a hard border? Is it ready to finally stop playing with the fears of people in the UK, but also in the EU? What we are experiencing is a tragedy. I have the impression that people are deliberately aiming to arrive at the very last minute. This is British negotiating tactics. I can't tell if it's the pressure from the Brexiteers or from anyone else – from the government, from Parliament, from the street or anywhere else. All I can see is that there is no willingness to finally put anything on the table. It is the British themselves who say: do not interfere! We are responsible for ensuring that there is a solution for Northern Ireland. But they are not presenting it, and that is the point. There will be no agreement – I repeat here – unless the issue of Northern Ireland is resolved in the divorce agreement. I like to explain this again, like stubborn children. I would like to make one more comment to you, Mr Timmermans. You said earlier about the need to do our homework with regard to the budget. I would just like to say that, in my view, success does not depend on everyone doing their homework when the homework is wrong, when the homework is done to even the most willing pupils – and this is certainly not the case with Mr Salvini and Di Matteo – is not the case; but even the most willing students would not be able to achieve the class goal unless the homework was formulated differently.  In other words, you have just explained to us, for example, with the social pillar, how great everything is, how great we are on the way to finally agreeing this together. The fact is that we have an economic and monetary union, we have a financial union; but we do not have a social union. We don't have them. So please do not tell you something that is not true in reality and is not perceived by people. When we talk about why, for example, populists had such an influx, we have to question that. Then we have to question why people in Italy, in other countries, are more willing to look to Brussels than to actually elect a non-populist democratic government in this way.  I also call on my friends, who are here from Five Stars, to stop offering Mr Salvini this, not to be held responsible for a policy that they do not actually stand for at all.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I think under Rule 164 of our revered procedures I am allowed to respond to the comments you made as President of Parliament, some of them personally insulting. Maybe you have a bit of a problem with your temper. I will ignore the personal comments you made about me, but I will say this: we do seem this morning to be struggling just a little bit with our history. To claim, Mr Tajani, that the European Union brought about the downfall of Nazism and Soviet Communism isn’t only laughable, it is very ungracious and deeply insulting to the United States of America, which made massive sacrifices so that Europe could be free twice in the 20th century, and – to a slightly lesser extent – the United Kingdom, as 30 000 British dead in Italy will attest. So you can claim what you want for the European Union, but please do not rewrite history.  Mr Tusk, I want to thank you for confirming that it was Theresa May who asked for the one—year extension to the transition period. I also want to thank you for your recent offer, saying that if Britain wants a Canada Plus—style trade deal, you are open to it. Indeed, it’s what I have campaigned for, for 25 years. I’ve always thought this was a better approach between our country and the EU than the one we currently have.  Now every proposal of course seems to founder on the question of the Irish border, but given the slight state of panic that German industry is now getting itself into – and maybe that’s not surprising because a WTO deal would lead not just to tariffs on German cars, but a weaker pound and probably a more competitive UK economy – the time has come to look for answers. The funny thing is the answers are staring at us. Not so long ago, Mr Juncker in the Irish Parliament made it very clear that there were no circumstances under which the European Union would impose a border. Indeed, even Mr Varadkar, the Irish PM, who is not usually particularly helpful in the Brexit process, has said that under no circumstances will there be a hard border. This Parliament produced a study by one of its own committees, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, entitled ‘Avoiding a hard border on the island of Ireland for Customs control and the free movement of persons’.  The point is, there are solutions everywhere we look. The idea that somehow this border is an impediment is, frankly, a red herring. The problem, I’m afraid, is that there is a rogue element in these negotiations, a group of people who do not wish to see a solution, who put up an immovable brick wall to stop us from breaking free, and I regret to say that it isn’t your chief negotiator, Monsieur Barnier, but actually the British Civil Service and Olly Robbins’ team. They signed up years ago to the European dream. They’ve been happy to take their orders from Brussels. They are now out to sabotage Brexit. They are indeed the enemy within.  I think that unless the Conservative Party comes to its senses and gets rid of a leader who clearly is being led by the nose, then we will head to the December summit, we will head towards a humiliating sell-out, and we will head towards the United Kingdom being trapped in EU rules for many, many years to come. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Farage, I would remind you that Communism and the Soviet Union, the Communist dictatorship, ended its season when many Eastern European countries joined the European Union. (Applause) Let me finish... I now believe that you have a duty to respect everyone's positions. I respect everyone, I have never laughed when you talk about the United Kingdom because I deeply respect the United Kingdom and demand that you respect the European Union. You can be against it, you can go out, but you have to respect the ideas and values of others. And I would remind you, Mr Farage, that until next spring the United Kingdom is part of the European Union, because the United Kingdom has applied to join the European Union, it has not been obliged to join the European Union. So if seventy years of peace have been guaranteed in Europe, after the two horrific dictatorships, this is mainly due to the European Union. That is the story, perhaps you should read it a little more carefully.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, as a preamble, I would like to remind Mr Bullmann and a number of people who have been moved by Mr Kamall's comments that there is not a plenary session, not a plenary day where, in the ranks of the left or the liberals, we do not hear a torrent of insults and aggressive and outrageous remarks accusing us of extremism. , especially with regard to all those who, like our group, simply defend a different conception of Europe. We are in favour of freedom, including freedom of expression. You, you do not support, you do not bear that we can have a vision other than yours of European construction.  Last week's European Council dealt with three closely related topics: migration, internal security and external relations. In its final communiqué, it refers to the 'return directive' adopted by our Parliament in 2008. The problem is that in the first months of its implementation, two judgments of the Luxembourg Court of Justice have considerably reduced its scope. In the next paragraph, the text of the conclusions states that, I quote, more needs to be done to facilitate actual returns. The problem is that, not to mention the unfavourable judgments of both the European Court of Justice (ECJ) and the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR), the countries from which illegal immigrants originate often refuse to issue consular passes.  Thus, while France has hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants on its soil, its government is unable to be respected. There are, it is true, some bilateral agreements between Spain and Morocco, for example, but they are all the less enforced because the European Union refuses to condition its financial aid on the effective control of migratory flows. Worse, last July, the Commission referred the case to the Luxembourg Court to have Hungary repeal its law against left-wing associations that help to set up illegal immigrants.  Therefore, what can be your credibility when you claim to want to "facilitate the actual returns" of illegal immigrants?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: There is no "blue card" issue because we are late and we have voting hours today. I apologize, but it is not possible.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, once again savage anti-communism in the European Parliament. You're competing with who's more anti-communist! You unspeakablely equate communism with fascism and thus feed the far right and fascism that is the reserve of your capitalism. Because you all have a common enemy: the peoples you are smashing and with the decisions of your Council, like the last one, where huge rivalries may appear between you over Brexit, for the Italian budget, which has been rejected and which literally rags syriza's lies in Greece that you can leave the memoranda and the commission within the European Union and the power of capital. But you agree on unpopular politics, to crush the people to give them to monopolies. Crush the refugees with your anti-refugee policy, with the repression at the border, with the entrapment in the first country of entry, with hotspots in Moria which are hells, with the intensity of repression within European countries. In the end, the pre-election dilemma you're selling, who's progressive or conservative, is fake. Power, that is, the real dictatorship of capital, Mr Tajani, with any government and The European Union are not humanized. The people must reject them.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Mr President of the European Council, I would like to thank the President of the European Council for his work and for his work on I would like to thank the European Council and the Commission, Michel Barnier, for getting us to have a unified view on Brexit history. I believe that this is the best way to achieve something here. We have to get through this. The crucial point is that there is no common position in Britain in government, in the government faction and in the whole parliament and within the opposition. That is our basic difficulty. In other words, we have a partner with whom we cannot negotiate seriously, because there is no structure for that partner. I believe that the European Parliament has as a condition – as Mr Tajani has said: we must get a sensible solution for avoiding the hard Irish border, and we must make it clear that the unity of the internal market must be preserved. Let me make a second comment. The INF Treaty, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, has been concluded to make medium-range missiles impossible in Europe. That is why it is important, and it must be enforced. I find it intolerable that the American President should quit without consultation and cooperation with the Europeans and now mix this up with China. We must stand up together to save this, so that we do not get new medium-range missiles in Europe, regardless of which side. Even if we then have to talk clearly with Russia that they must not do that. Third point, in short, populism is picking up the issues that can be used in populist terms. I sometimes have the impression that we are not making progress on migration, because some people do not want to solve the migration issue, but need it as an issue in order to impose their positions politically and to use them in a populist way. However, I would also like to say here that we Europeans have secured this peace for 70 years, Mr Farage, that this Europe was built in cooperation with the United Kingdom and the United States, and that europe has helped to achieve the defeat of the great totalitarian regime from Moscow through Europe. And one last word: German Social Democrats voted against National Socialism in 1933. I will never forget this for the SPD, and this should be expressed in such a situation.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to President Tusk that we have indeed a serious situation when it comes to the European Council not being able to deliver real solutions to the problems we are confronted with. We do, of course, have many external challenges but something that we know for sure is that we need to strengthen internal cohesion among Europeans and the recipe for this is very clear. We need to address social inequalities by fully implementing the social pillar and we need to support investment into the future. We still do not have all the necessary means. At the heart of this you have a historic task, which is to complete, reform and rebalance the economic and monetary union. We have all the proposals on the table. We need the political will to complete the banking union, to reform the European Stability Mechanism and to create a budget capacity in the euro area in order to support Member States to invest in the future. Let me give you a concrete case. I come from Portugal, which is recognised today as a country which is making a real effort to go beyond blind austerity and to make a real recovery and a real effort to change. But now we are stuck. We cannot go forward unless the economic and monetary union is properly reformed. These kinds of cases must be supported because, if they are not supported, you will start having cases like Italy in other places in Europe. This is the choice that the European Council is confronted with. Either we support countries which want to move ahead with social cohesion and turn to the future or we will have a fragmentation of the European Union. The choice is there on the table of the next European Council in December.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for I suggest that we stop shouting and roaring here. I have to say that people are sometimes ashamed to be members of this Parliament. Mr President, Mr Tusk, Vice-President Timmermans, I would like to thank Mr Tusk for his work on You have certainly also watched with interest and sympathy the demonstrations in London last weekend. However, I have also heard from some former Remainers that they have become Brexiteers because they are upset about the way the European Commission treats Britain. Michel Barnier is always very keen to explain the economic impact of Brexit on the European Union. But I have not yet heard from the Commission what this means for industry in the European Union, for jobs and economic growth in the European Union. Today, the UK is already the largest customer of the European Union, and in the economy, customers are treated neatly in size. I think it is time for the Commission to make a customer-friendly offer to the UK.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, today’s debate is the monthly ritual dance with the Council and I think many of my colleagues have already explained how we feel about the total inability of the Council ever to reach any results. I am getting a little bit tired, Mr Tusk, of the monthly hollow words that we are hearing, of the bored look on your face when you are listening to the debate. You just seem to think, ‘OK, I have to sit through this, but at least I can go for lunch afterwards.’ Nobody seems to be feel responsible here. You are the co-legislator, but the Council has become a completely dysfunctional body. It’s a bit like the Bermuda Triangle of politics: you put proposals in there and they disappear, never to be seen again. It is total paralysis. You know what? It’s not just that the Council is totally unable to solve any crisis at all; the Council has become the crisis. And I dare to say more: the Council, in its current paralysis, is a threat to the future of the European Union. You have to ask yourself, as President of the Council, Mr Tusk, ‘Am I going to assume my responsibility for the European Union or am I just going to enjoy this job for as long as it lasts?’ It is about time that the government leaders understood that they are also European politicians; they have a responsibility for this continent, for the European Union, and they cannot content themselves with travelling to Brussels or Salzburg or whatever, having a photo opportunity and then agreeing not to decide anything, because I don’t think it’s even an inability to decide anything – it’s deliberate. The government leaders don’t want to decide anything. They are quite happy keeping everything that they have. But what they don’t seem to understand is that by not deciding anything, they cannot keep things as they are, because the world keeps turning – they cannot stop it. Finally, on the asylum package: it is an absolute disgrace that after three years’ deliberation, there is still no decision. Go back and do your homework, Mr Tusk. Skip lunch today.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, I would like to bring some quiet and peaceful words after the previous disgraceful dispute. I will concentrate on Northern Ireland, because thatʼs an important point, and summarise the situation. The goal of including a protocol or not in Ireland in the withdrawal agreement is to protect the Good Friday Agreement by avoiding a hard border and by ensuring that there will be no diminution of rights for the citizens in the north. This protocol will be used as a backstop to protect the Good Friday Agreement in case the future relationship does not solve the issue. We propose the participation of Northern Ireland in the Single Market and the Customs Union for goods through regulatory alignment. But this solution cannot be extended to the whole of the UK, as Westminster would like, precisely because the UK’s government majority in Westminster – of which the Democratic Unionist Party is a key element – does not accept any differential solution for Northern Ireland, since this would create a border in the Irish Sea. The Commission remains open to discussing other proposals to secure a backstop solution for Northern Ireland in the withdrawal agreement, but at the moment the UK has not presented any alternatives. Unfortunately, we didnʼt achieve any agreement at the political level. In any case, we support the position of the Commission on the need to include the backstop in the withdrawal agreement; on the proposal itself; on the fact that we are open to discussing other proposals if the UK comes up with something reasonable. The last Council meeting was not able to take steps forward on this extremely sensitive issue, which needs a prompt and clear solution.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, as we predicted, the British Government is trying to isolate and understate the issue of the border dividing Ireland. It is saying that we have 95% of the issues solved so therefore it is in the interests of the EU to abandon Ireland. They discovered the bottom line of the EU in December and have been trying to negotiate downwards ever since. The British Government has yet to understand that failure to agree the 5% – the backstop – means that there is no agreement on the 100%.  Time is running out for Theresa May to escape the poisonous embrace of the DUP. The DUP are a busted flush. They do not even represent the majority view of the North of Ireland. They speak out of both sides of their mouth on regulatory divergence from Britain – just ask the LGBT community and the women who travel to Britain every day for abortions. It is time that Theresa May restores trust in the negotiations and signs what she agreed in December.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, this European Commission will go down in history as the one which saw the wheels fall off the federalist wagon. Mr Juncker and Mr Timmermans have been full of bonhomie in their personal style, but the content of their politics has brought the EU into constant conflict with democratically-elected national governments. The latest victim is Italy, whose governing coalition has been told its economic policies – for which it has a mandate – are unacceptable to the Brussels commissars. What was it that Mr Juncker famously said? ‘There can be no democratic choice against the European Treaties’. So from the moment the Commission was chosen as the EU negotiator for Brexit, it’s been determined not to agree a velvet divorce and continued friendship but to administer a public punishment to the British people for daring to vote for a future away from the constraints of European Union law. It’s not been motivated by a desire to keep trading ties smooth with its largest customer. It’s shown no understanding of the character of our island nation, inhabited by the proud descendants of those who saved the countries of continental Europe twice in the 20th century. And I’m sorry to say it’s been aided in its mission by a weak and uninspiring British Prime Minister who neither supported nor even understood our desire for national independence. But do not believe the bulletins brought to you by has-beens from the UK political class – the likes of Heseltine, Blair and Clegg – who tell you that by keeping the punishment up, you can bring Britain to heel. The ordinary patriotic British people are, in fact, appalled by your antics and will not buckle. Mr Juncker says Europe is the love of his life. The sad truth is that his Commission is behaving like an obsessive: smothering goodwill and suffocating affection for her. In the time this Commission has left, I urge him to steer a wiser course on Brexit and much else besides.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Sometimes one could not trust one's ears when one hears the unkindness with which the individual Member States of this European Union meet. The last time it was the Hungarians and the Poles, today it is the Italians, just because in these states you obviously do not like the governments. At the same time, we have the negotiations on Britain's exit from the European Union. Here, too, one cannot avoid the impression that you want to make the British bad with a punitive action here. That would be absolutely the wrong way to go. What is needed now in the final of the negotiations is to find a way on an equal footing with the British, in which both sides do not count as losers, but how adult people can carry out this separation process accordingly successfully here. The worst thing that can happen here is that through the back door you try to thwart this decision of the British people with a second referendum.  That would be the wrong way to go. You have done it before in Ireland, with the Treaty of Lisbon. To evade this referendum now through the back door would be absolutely the wrong way to go. Please write this in your master book.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the conclusions of the European Council meeting are disheartening for the citizens, sorry for their content and disparaging for the everyday life of every European. While the institutions announce illegal immigration that everything is going well in Greece, more than 200 people enter a day. Half of them will legally leave the country, while practically no one will return back to Turkey. But German authorities are returning 4,000 to Greece, the country where more than 100,000 are officially housed without legal documents or wanting protection through asylum. Nevertheless, we hear charitable words from politicians who love humanism, but as it turns out they don't care about people. The Council calls for better implementation of the agreement with Turkey while in fact serving illegal smugglers. It serves the perpetuation of lawlessness. It serves Erdoğan's interests. We demand the minimum: restoring the sense of security among citizens, restoring control at internal and external borders under the sole responsibility of states by rejecting parallel societies within our borders and, at last, deporting all illegally trafficked smugglers.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, I would like to thank the President for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is excellent and a real ray of hope in European politics that the 27 Heads of State or Government have not yet been divided on the issue of Brexit. You are making a very good contribution to this, and I would also like to highlight this merit. On the other hand, however, we have seen your report. And although today is the debate on the Council meeting, your report did not last five minutes. In other words, there was nothing to report. Many previous speakers have already referred to this. I remember the days when the European Council regularly produced large reports, when we developed Europe further, when we tackled the problems and challenges with vigour, not only in the Commission and Parliament, but also in the Council. I really call on you to think twice, take the initiative so that, at the end of this parliamentary term, you enter the history books as the one who has overcome the Council blockade, who has managed to re-energise and finally lift the deadlock on decisions! That would really be a great achievement that you can give to the whole of the European Union. What have we got? We see many governments in Europe as a weak point. We have often talked here about the unspeakable situation in Poland; the European Court of Justice has, of course, delivered a judgment here. Most of us are concerned about the Romanian Government's dragging on the fight against corruption and flouting European values. We are now seeing the irresponsible government in Italy that wants to break European law, thereby plunging its whole country into the abyss and endangering the future of its people. When two previous speakers have mentioned that this is a question. whether we like a government or not, that's not what it's all about. What we are concerned about is that, as more and more European governments do not see more responsibility, but only see: how to create a popular mood, how to achieve good election results at the expense of the people of these countries, then I would also like to see a clear debate in the Council on how to deal with the people and peoples of Europe and what responsibility in politics can be achieved. , also in state and government headquarters.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear President Tusk, how can you say that you are committed to taking measures to manage migration? Last week's summit missed an opportunity again. No progress on any of the issues that were on the table.  If we're talking about migration, it's not a migrant crisis, it's never been. This is a crisis of institutions, it is a crisis of governments that fail to agree on anything other than how to stop people from europe's increasingly tight borders.  The Austrian Presidency wishes to open agreements already concluded. We in the European Parliament have adopted a complete overhaul of the asylum system, and this remains blocked by the Members. How many times have you put your hands on each other and promised a breakthrough, and yet you have come before Parliament empty-handed? Just like today.  The conclusions speak of enhanced cooperation with Africa, the fight against people smugglers, the increase of border guards, the faster return of people, the adoption of a security package, but there is no word on legal and legal routes to Europe. The renewal of the Blue Card, the only instrument for legal migration, remains blocked.  We cannot, nor want to hand over your empty words, to European citizens – they only expect us to act effectively. And debates like today, when some in this Chamber spread very dangerously hostile rhetoric, are deeply irresponsible, they are political villains. Unfortunately, they're not in the courtroom anymore.  And the election is coming insatiable, and we will approach the electorate as much as you do today - empty-handed because of the inability to make deals between governments.  And how is it possible that you still do not realise that all the problems will be much bigger if the future composition of the European Parliament is even less pro-European? Take action before it is too late for some more sensible policy and for a sensible Europe.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Madam President, Dear President-in-Office of the Council, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-3, for At the end of the Council meeting, some emphasis is right in the direction of migration policy, even if it is how migrants are resettly resettly, returning them (those who are not refugees) and also reducing the influence of criminal organisations in this process. At the same time, however, it must be said that it has not been possible to take significant steps in the creation of the coast guard, the border guard body. Although relocation schemes in Member States that do not work continue, we see this from the experience of many countries. But the most important thing for me from the Council meeting was the issue of Brexit - and hardly citizens and business on the European continent, and also in Britain, are reassured by the announcement that 90% of the compromise has been reached, or 95%. The most important thing, perhaps for citizens and business, is to put an end to this scenario of a drama that will end with an unknown result in a month or two, but finally think about this content, which will ensure cooperation and, above all, security on the European continent, and is not just a disconnect for the security of the European Union from the security of the European continent.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, unfortunately I could at this moment repeat the same conclusions from any of the past three years’ Council meetings, because it’s very obvious that the leaders are failing European citizens’ expectations miserably and profoundly. We have delivered on climate change and security, but when it comes to migration, there is a complete failure. Council does not deliver. This Parliament acted responsibly. After careful studies and consultations, we made difficult compromises and came up with a text on the reform of the Dublin Regulation that a two—thirds majority of this plenary – this House – could tolerate. Meanwhile, in the ivory tower far away from any contact with citizens and reality, Heads of State are throwing insults at each other and refusing any compromise. Frankly, I find this embarrassing for this Union. Council has not made one single step of progress. And I would just ask this: when can we foresee any kind of result from the Council?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, do you remember ‘Brexit means Brexit’; ‘we’re going to make a success of it!’; and the promise of an EU trade deal that would be the easiest in human history? Well isn’t two years an exceptionally long time in politics. There is now parliamentary paralysis and the Conservative Party has descended into bitter in-fighting, unable to agree a way forward. My country has been left ungoverned by the ungovernable. Chequers is dead, but neither is there enough support for alternative versions of Brexit being driven by a Brexit syndicate of far-right think tanks. Now the language has also become mafiosi, with talking of a killing zone and hot knives in the Prime Minister’s chest. This highly dangerous talk must be stopped right now. It’s now clear that the only way out of this deadlock is to hand the process back to the people. Last Saturday I joined 700 000 others on the streets of London, marching in support of the people’s vote, demanding a choice between this Brexit shambles and staying in the EU. This was the second-largest demonstration in British history. I was delighted that it was young people who led this march and who spoke so passionately about our place in the European Union. They have a right to all the freedoms and opportunities that I’ve enjoyed during my life. The movement looks unstoppable. British MPs are now being bombarded with letters and emails from their constituents demanding a people’s vote, and there is growing cross-party support for the idea. It’s time for the UK Parliament to let the people decide the best way forward for our country.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to focus on the migration part of the Council's work. In this House, we have worked to bring about a system of legal and safe roads, in which we share the responsibility for receiving people in a dignified manner. In the Council, Mr Tusk, you are focusing exclusively on repressive measures, cooperation with dictatorships and blaming responsibility on third countries. It is a dangerous adaptation to Orbán, PiS, Austria and the extreme right. They are obsessed with closing our continent. It's not the future. It is an unacceptable policy. It's a dead end. It is time to take responsibility, to put together a coalition of willing countries that want to share the responsibility of receiving people on the run, who want Europe to live up to respect for international asylum law. It is time to put in place proper life-saving operations in the Mediterranean, not to criminalise those who do something when Member States and Europe leave people in need. So again: Take responsibility, put in the paper barrel this proposal for 10 000 new border guards and on mass deportations. We need to respect the right of asylum and save people in the Mediterranean.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Dear President, I believe that the European Council has finally realised that the influx of migrants is a disastrous for Europe. I welcome the proposals to prevent illegal migration, strengthen border protection and the number of officials.  Therefore, after such an understanding of the European Council, perhaps other European institutions should finally understand and abandon attacks on Community countries, which have categorically advocated limiting migration even at internal borders. Do you think that without their categorical attitude and firm stance, illegal migration would have been reduced? It is the return directive, and not the allocation quotas for migrants around the Countries of the European Union, that must be the essential document that we must now follow.  At the meeting, however, I missed the European Council's approach and focus on social exclusion. It is they that are becoming increasingly acute in many Countries of the Community today. Thinking only of cybersecurity, but without reducing social exclusion in society, we will not solve the problems in the European Union.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the somewhat ramshackle polemics following Mr Kamall's speech – to which I have complete solidarity – show how sensitive it is still, how much of a punctum dolens is, our historical backlog that we have to deal with, especially when we dare to slander our political opponents with accusations of fascism or Nazism. We should respond with the wisdom of the Jewish President of Austria, with the intelligent response he gave to Simon Wiesenthal, when he proposed to him to clean up the party from the former Nazis and said 'I would not risk us being the only two of us'.
