This summit concluded nothing at all, other than empty words to underline the importance of preventing illegal immigration and strengthening cooperation with countries of origin and transit. There was one country, Italy, which for years has been asking, even in this Parliament, to be assisted, which said that the right way was to block departures. She made it, but she made it on her own, thanks to Minister Salvini who closed the ports! Do! And do not continue to be the useless 'blah blah' of European policy. Do, do, do! To save lives and prevent tragedies such as that of minors that Macron's France dumps as garbage in the woods of Claviere! (The President cut the speaker off.)

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I have taken president Donald Tusk's speech as realistic and pragmatic, and what I lacked is that President Timmermans has developed his message in detail. We certainly need a rational and friendly atmosphere in the final weeks of the Brexit negotiations, because, as Mr Henkel said, not only British interests but also European interests are settled.  We need a stricter fight against people smuggling. And here I would look forward to the action of the European Commission, including on the fight for the security of our elections threatened from the outside (elections to the European Parliament).  And finally, there was too much ferocity at the expense of responsibility. Mr Bullmann attacked the Austrian Presidency, and Mrs in 't Veld rebuked the Council, accusing it of paralysis. These are bad examples of reducing trust in the European Union. Rather, we need an example of trust in other institutions on the part of the European Parliament, because this gives us the opportunity to act rationally.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The first day of the last summit was yet another testament to the problem that the British sovereign has prepared for his own country, then for Ireland and for the European Union as a whole. The problem is with the United Kingdom, because the European Union is united in this matter. On the second day, however, the written conclusions concerned cases where there are differences of opinion between Member States, namely immigration policy, internal security, relations with third countries. This is still a work in progress and voters in 2019 will tell us all whether these security efforts are appreciated, because this is the biggest deficit in today's European Union. This is as important a challenge for the current Head of the Council and head of the European Commission as the great economic crisis for Herman Van Rompuy or Barroso in the previous deal.  I would like once again to return to my disappointment with the situation on the part of the United Kingdom in its negotiations with the European Union. I have personal reasons, because for my environment, which was part of the great Solidarity movement – Donald Tusk also grew out of this environment – British parliamentarism was a role model, a model and an inspiration worthy of imitation, because of its quality, because truth prevailed untruths and political disagreement was a way of educating people on the issues that matter most to the country. Hence this inspiration and hence my great disappointment, but also, of course, and the wish for this disse0 to take place in an orderly manner, also in the interests of the hundreds of thousands of my compatriots who have found a better life in the British Isles, and I would like them to get the chance in the future as well.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, with all due respect — with all due respect because you are the President of the Council, an institution to which we owe all respect — you have seen the position of this Parliament, a majority, very majority, and it is a very harsh criticism of the Council's paralysis. You are a Democrat, we represent the citizens of the European Union. I guess you do believe in that. Therefore, your obligation is to listen to what this Parliament is telling you. But not to listen to it as if it were a fine rain that you have to endure every time there is a Council and you come to tell the conclusions, but to take it seriously, Mr Tusk. Because, you know what's going on? That the Council's paralysis, the lack of Council solutions fuels this which it has also heard here. You start by putting a shoe on Commissioner Moscovici's papers, still accusing the Socialists of being Nazis, or you have to put up with Mr Borghezio's speech. And that has to do with the no European solutions to citizens' problems. So you are no stranger — the Council is no stranger — to the great vacuum that is being created in this European Union. You have already listened to the parliamentary groups, from right to left, to say with all due respect that you have to listen to this Parliament, that you have to move, because you are contributing to the total failure of European policy. And citizens need to know that it is the governments — which is not the Commission, which is not Parliament, which have done their homework — that it is the governments, most of the conservative governments that are slowing down the solutions of the European Union. You have even allowed yourself to congratulate the Austrian Presidency on its great commitment to migration policies. It's a joke, isn't it, Mr. Tusk. It's a big joke. Because Austria is considering leaving the United Nations Global Compact on Migration. That's Austria's attitude. You are consenting to the citizens getting away from everything we stand for here. And that is your responsibility, Mr Tusk, of the Council, of the governments, of the conservative majority currently leading the European Union. And we have to raise our voices against that paralysis that fuels the worst ghosts in the European Union.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, my Group Chairman Kamall's comments this morning were unwise and incorrect. Mr Kamall does not seem to know that Adolf Hitler killed socialism by supposedly embracing it, which unfortunately resulted in many socialists losing their lives in concentration camps, among other things. I distance myself from his comments. Mr President, Brexit is an irresponsible choice. There will be losers on both sides of the Channel. That is a pity, because we also need the British to reform the European Union. The EU should not interfere in everything, as the overly political Juncker Commission is doing at the moment. It is a pity that the British cannot help. Mr President, I hope, like the hundreds of thousands of protesters last Saturday, that, for example, a second referendum will not allow Brexit to happen. If brexit does happen, I hope that the United Kingdom and the European Union can stay close together, because a no deal would be a disaster.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Present Tusk that he has heard a lot of sharp words here today and I must say, President Tusk, some of those were unfair and I would not share in them. In fact your task is not an easy one. I know that you have to cope with Prime Ministers, Presidents, and if I look at the Czech leadership, one of the most critical to the European Union in terms of the abilities to solve migration issues, then the same leadership is undermining issues or instruments such as Frontex. I must say that looking at you, I even envy our Polish friends that they have a politician like you.  But the fact is that Parliament is an ally for you. You can come and you can tell us something different from what we read in the media. You can come and you can consult ahead of the European Council, you can use us and the views that are practically unanimous, in the European Council. You can provide leadership and you can really deliver. At the moment, whether it’s migration, whether it’s governance, we are failing. The Council is failing.  One last remark: I am really ashamed that the Council and the High Representative are unable to say a strong word and a strong message and sanctions on the question of the Saudi Arabia issue. It is a shame.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, you made a brief mention at the end of your speech on the Saudi Arabian affair. The European Council cannot remain silent in the coming days. We need you to make decisions: this brutal murder has to be a before and after in our relationships. The first thing to do, apart from condemning the murder, is to condemn what constitutes a violation of the 1963 Consular Relations Convention and non-compliance with the Convention against Torture, of which Saudi Arabia is also a signatory.  Apart from all this, an urgent decision must be taken: the european Union-wide embargo on arms sales to Saudi Arabia, because it is also what sets out our common position, which, in our second criterion, states that arms sales licences cannot be given when fate is a country that violates human rights and international humanitarian law , as is happening in Yemen. That's what our law says. It is the Common European Position, which has been mandatory since 2008. So I ask, please, that the Council act once and for all in this regard.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, the threats to Europe do not come on legs, but come on a yacht. The threats to Europe are those billionaires and those multinationals that evade, defraud and plunder public accounts, as the recent case of the "cum-ex files" shows us once again: multinationals that relocate companies and take their jobs, organizing their accounts to minimise their contributions to the tax. These are the real dangers to the European popular classes. But it seems that the Council does not want to talk about this. In recent months we have seen how in my country was threatened with the relocation and closure of Vestas in León, La Naval in Sestao, Alcoa in A Coruña or Avilés, leaving thousands of people on the street, sharpening the deind industrialization of the country. They are companies with benefits that have received great public aid, some were even privatized not so long ago. Ladies and gentlemen, a re-industrialisation plan, a change of productive model that recovers the strategic sectors for the public and puts them under social control, ensuring the work and future of the European people's classes is urgent.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: It’s often better to make your key point first.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, european councils and summits pass, and everything remains tragically as it is. If we were to give you a vote, how much should we give you? Zero for the tragedy of the migration crisis, with a Reform of Dublin remaining a pipe. Someone deludes himself, proposing some disgusting tips, that he can still leave Italy alone as in recent years. We won't let you. Zero on overcoming austerity. Instead of sprinkling the head of ashes after the social disasters of recent years imposed on southern Europe, find unity only by obstructing an Italian manoeuvre, the manoeuvre of redemption for hundreds of thousands of innocent savers scammed by banks, for millions of unemployed who need to be retrained to re-enter the labour market, for millions of minimum pensioners forced to rummage through the trash at the end of the month. Faced with all this, you continue to close your eyes, as you have closed them in front of the billions given to the dishonest banks by previous Italian governments, in the face of our courageous reform against corruption, and some even think of cheering for the spread, hoping that the markets will do the dirty work of bending an uncomfortable government. Shame! You squabbled for half an hour on the labels of totalitarianism without understanding that the real threat of our time is the undemocratic totalitarianism of speculative finance. Shame! The 5 Star Movement won't give up! There is not much left, the real reports will be delivered to you in May by the citizens.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I myself am a fundamental opponent of the guardianship of the European level over the social and economic policies of the Member States. I think it is one of the major inhibitors in Europe. But I would like to thank you for one thing: that, in the context of that guardianship, you have made a damning judgment on the socio-economic policy of the Kingdom of Belgium. Fortunately for the Belgian Prime Minister, who called the assessment fake news, Jean-Claude Juncker helped to minimise the situation, but the situation is serious. There is nominal growth in net primary expenditure. The unacceptable debt ratio is now again firmly above 100%, or 103.6%. Taxes are now at the highest in the OECD. Despite the savings in social security and despite the pensions being among the lowest, the raising of the retirement age and electricity prices, water prices and fuel prices, despite the energy policy of a third world country, Belgium is underperforming. What's wrong with Belgium? I will tell you: it is a country that is split, two economies and two societies. Artificial gathering that does not belong together is not good for the citizens, certainly not for the Flemings.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, I want to thank President Tusk for the update and insight into the possible extension of the transition period. Like you, I hope for an agreement at the end of this process and an orderly withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union. The public debate has moved on from the October Council. We now know, from leaks of the text, that the EU will consider an all-UK customs arrangement for the backstop, but apparently not within the withdrawal treaty; I’m presuming wanting to leave the Northern Ireland-specific one in place. While this would be portrayed as a move forward from the EU, it is both a naive and negligent strategy. The insistence of a customs or regulatory border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain would damage Northern Ireland economically and constitutionally. It would ignore the principle of consent within the Belfast Agreement. It would leave a hugely controversial measure in a legally-enforceable treaty in exchange for a promise of further negotiation: not something that could be accepted.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "Madam President, I have only been in this Parliament for four years. When I arrived, Europe was the solution for almost everyone. Now, just four years later, for many it's the problem.  In just four years we have seen a migration crisis that has drowned fifteen thousand people at sea; in just four years we have seen terrorism returning to the European Union; that nationalpulism was trying to break my country; that the Commission, for the first time, has initiated an Article 7 process against Poland; Parliament, for the first time, has initiated an Article 7 process against Hungary; that the Commission, for the first time, has returned the budgets to Italy; that the next Commission will have at least three anti-European Commissioners and that the next Parliament will have at least one third of anti-European parliamentarians. Europe is going through a storm and we can't ignore it anymore. It's time for bravery and it's time for idealism. What is happening is the worst is the Brexit, because it assumes, as we saw this morning, that we have forgotten everything we had to learn during World War II.  I always think politicians can do more. And with regard to Brexit, I'm convinced we were able to do more. They said, "Don't go on election campaigning," and we didn't go, and the Europeans lost. This weekend, on Saturday, young Britons have given us a lesson going out on the street again and saying something very clear: soft Brexit or hard Brexit are not the only alternatives; there is also a new referendum, there is also no Brexit.  This time I am not going to be silent and I ask this Parliament, with respect, to ask the United Kingdom Government - just as it can speak to the Government of Poland, Hungary or Italy - to hold a new referendum. A definitive referendum as young people are calling for on the street.  I am not going to be silent and I ask the Council, if the United Kingdom calls on it to extend the transitional deadline, we will do so by setting a new referendum as a condition. We extend the deadline, but with a new referendum, a definitive referendum. We, the European Parliament, are the strength of The Europeanists in the United Kingdom. Let's not fail them again.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Council summits follow their own logic. The choice of topics is often based on domestic political considerations, and this is also perfectly legitimate. However, it becomes problematic when these are primarily symbolic issues. You may be able to optimize votes at home, but you can't solve the real problems. There are many that we need to talk about: how to deal with digitalisation or how to address the wage gap within the Union.  As always, last week everything focused on the number one issue: the defense of refugees. The result was meagre. This could not be expected otherwise, if the political claim is reduced to keeping one's own responsibility as low as possible. Then one finds very easily like-minded people, but also the common denominator remains small. Once again, it was only possible to commit to vague declarations of intent. Once again, it was also not possible to respond to Parliament's asylum package. Not a word about the essential reform of Dublin or the creation of legal entry. These would probably be the most important contribution to the fight against smuggling.  The Heads of State or Government have also been strangely calm in creating European capacity to secure borders, contrary to the policy model based solely on national interests. It is also very regrettable that there has been no unified EU response to the brutal murder of the Saudi journalist Khashoggi. A temporary halt to arms supplies to Saudi Arabia would have been the least. It would also have sent out a clear signal that we are really serious about combating the causes of flight. It is not enough to welcome cooperation with the Arab League or to take cooperation with Africa to a new level, as the conclusions state. Declarations of intent will only take us further if they are followed by concrete action, and unfortunately that has not been the case for a long time.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, if the UK needs more time to reach agreement, it should be granted. In the spirit of the peaceful coexistence of countries, all of us should refrain from meddling in the political diversity of the UK, as well. I welcome the Council tackling hybrids, cyber, disinformation and CBRN. I also welcome the notion of restrictive measures, although I point to the huge challenge in the attribution of attacks.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, I would like to welcome the cohesion of the European Union in the Brexit negotiations. It is due to the effectiveness of the Commission, the talent of Michel Barnier and the responsible attitude of our Member States. Can we, therefore, feed the hope that at least when crises become existential, we can still mobilize the critical mass around a project? Doubts are allowed in view of the hesitations, procrastinations, endless discussions and postponements that prevent us from moving forward on essential projects. For current reasons, however, I would like to end my speech by renewing my respect for the way in which German social democracy opposed Nazism in the 1930s. It was also on these acts of resistance in particular that the hope of a return to civilization became thoughtless. Anyone who still likes to confuse this aspect of the history of the 1930s disqualifies himself from responsible political debate.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, another European Council which highlights a process of exhausted integration, without solutions to the problems that it has created and which it has created. The euro summit insists on a web of even more rail constraints to prevent any project of sovereign development, especially if founded on social progress. Then they admire the consequences. The expedient, the old expedient of waving threats and external enemies, serves to justify militaristic escalation, the arms race and the security drift on the internal level. They burn here the money that is lacking in economic and social cohesion. Then marvel at the consequences. The insistence on a selective, exploitative, racist and xenophobic approach to the migration issue demonstrates the true face of the European Union and reveals the assimilation of far-right practices and designs.  As regards the negotiations for the united kingdom's exit, we reaffirm here the right of each people to decide their fate in a sovereign manner, including with regard to leaving the European Union. And we stress once again that in any scenario the rights of migrant workers in the UK must be respected.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We are talking about Brexit here again. It is well known that both parties in these negotiations are committed to delaying negotiations until the last minute and not putting their cards on the table at the moment. In this respect, nothing new on this front. The same applies to the migration crisis, to all the efforts around Frontex, which have so far achieved nothing – no agreement in sight there, after three years. However, the fact that you are insulting the Austrian Presidency of the Council for being the only one actually willing to act on this point is a special form of humour. If you are going to fall for Mr Salvini because of his budget, I would like to point out one thing: it is true that Italy has too many budget deficits. But Mr Salvini has presented the budget with Italy's third-lowest debt for the last 18 years. And finally, a quote from Herbert Frahm: "The socialist element in National Socialism, in the thinking of its followers, the subjective lyrise at the grassroots level, must be recognized by us." The man was later named Willy Brandt and was SPD party chairman.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The main theme of last week's EU summit in Brussels was undoubtedly the continued migration crisis. We can say with satisfaction that Brussels and the pro-migrant countries have not been able to impose their will on member countries that oppose migration. The participants in the deliberations have been forced to confirm that their aim remains to stop illegal immigration. On the other hand, the truth is that the fight between pro- and anti-immigration forces and countries in the Union continues. There is a real political war going on between those who want to stop illegal migration and those who want to manage and legalise it. Ideological warfare is being carried out by Hungary and Poland, by Viktor Orban, by Guy Verhofstadt, by Emmanuel Macron and his allies by Matteo Salvini's Italy.  Nevertheless, the Austrian Presidency and Sebastian Kurz's proposal for mandatory solidarity are heading in a positive direction. The debate will continue at the forthcoming Summit in December and it is hoped that elections in May next year will bring about a breakthrough in the UNION's migration policy. It is hoped that the European People's Party, which is renewed and strengthened in European elections, will play a crucial role in finding a solution, in protecting the Europe and sovereignty, values, culture and identity of nations. Hungary, in any case, he stands for his freedom and independence in the spirit of the 1956 revolution that erupted on 23 October.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, before I give the floor to the next speaker, I regret that we will not be able to take catch-the-eye because of the time constraints, and we do have a two-hour vote. So apologies to those who wished to use that.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Madam President, this European Council, as we have established, will not go down in history. On Brexit, the responsibility is clearly on the UK side. We fully back the assessment that negotiations have not achieved decisive progress and President Tusk’s decision not to call for a European Council in November but to stand ready to do this if and when decisive progress is made. We are close to an agreement, but at the same time what is missing is a decisive and indispensable component of a deal. We reiterate that without a backstop for the Irish border, the European Parliament will not give its consent to the withdrawal agreement. We are not demanding a border in the Irish Sea but a simple, decentralised, mostly immaterial fall-back mechanism which shall not pose any challenge to the integrity of the United Kingdom, and we stand open to consider solutions like a longer transition and a UK-wide customs union, which will make the likelihood of using such a backstop remote. In this respect, we fully share the overall stance expressed by President Tusk and Michel Barnier. We are calm, open, constructive but very firm on principles, such as the right of citizens, the integrity of the Single Market, the protection of the Good Friday Agreement, and of course our arms are and will always be open if the UK changes its mind. The lack of progress on the completion of economic and monetary union is a great responsibility of the Member States. Those who do not understand that we desperately need to complete the banking union, to establish a European unemployment benefits scheme, to make tech giants pay their fair share of taxes and to enhance our investment capacity are making a big mistake. A special mention has to go to the cynical irresponsibility of the Italian Government, which is challenging the very logic of any common rule and is doing this not to support growth and jobs but to pay with the money and the savings of Italian citizens for its electoral campaign, giving amnesty to tax evaders and paving the way for further austerity, making any battle for a better eurozone and more risk-sharing more difficult.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, I have listened this morning with a degree of trepidation to what I have heard. Let me make it very clear to the great and the good in this House – if you want to listen – that we cannot and will not, as Unionists in Northern Ireland, accept a customs or regulatory border between us and the rest of the United Kingdom. That’s non—negotiable. On that we are united.  Now we have the backstop behind the backstop, and I’m just wondering where we’re actually coming from, and who is involved here. Let me make my position very clear: I do not want to be in a position where we have no deal or a bad deal. I want – and the people I represent want – a deal that works, and above all that delivers. The backstop does not. It is a busted flush. It can’t deliver.  So I have to say to you, Mr Tusk, why do you and Mr Barnier continue to go down this road? There are other ways. There are other solutions. Is it not time we looked at other ways, rather than trying to push something that is never, ever going to work?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, when the Council conclusions on migration are made, there will be detention centres, there will be persecution of NGOs, there will be brute force against those fleeing hunger or death, but there will be zero solidarity. And all this will coincide with the same period in which tax schemes and gold visas were implemented, giving residence and tax advantages to those who have a lot of money, schemes that have already been denounced in successive reports for opening the door to money laundering and corruption. The difference is that it extends a red carpet to those who have money to buy rights and let themselves die in the Mediterranean who has nothing. Mr. Tusk, there is no shortage of heads of state in the Council who invoke Christian values, but it seems that there is no good Samaritan left. They prefer fear, inanity and electoralism. The cost, Mr. Tusk, is very expensive: it is the cost of the European project itself, it is the cost of democracy itself.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, who made you king?  The European Union is the creation of its Member States, you must be at their service, not their master!  European states have an interest in signing a comprehensive free trade agreement with the UK, it is the largest trade deficit in the EU. But you prefer to punish this great democracy to protect the Brussels system. You are acting out of ideology and not in the interests of the states. You want to humiliate the United Kingdom to prevent people from having their sovereignty.  You reoffend after the 1992 referendums in Denmark, 2001 and 2008 in Ireland, 2005 in France and the Netherlands, 2016 in the Netherlands. You continue with Italy, humiliated too.  You boast of promoting democracy and the rule of law? In truth, the European Union is a permanent coup against the people. That is, a dictatorship. What Europe needs is bruxit, to get Brussels and its Commission out of Europe so that the Europe of nations and peoples can live.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, Mr Timmermans, I can only agree with my colleagues who have said that the Council has achieved nothing. We talk on the one hand "Unification makes power", and the leaders of the member states are divided even on this extremely important issue, such as migration. We need to make progress on these issues very quickly. One sentence on the historical topic that just played out – the debate on the left and the right. National socialism and communism are two horrific totalitarian dictatorships that have resulted in millions of casualties, and we must condemn both dictatorships and pay tribute to all who have died. Go back to Brexit. Both sides - both Britain and the European Union - are losing out on Brexit. I see that in recent times the civilian pressure in britain for a second citizens' survey is growing and I hope this will happen to prevent this folly, which is Brexit.  Whatever the outcome of the negotiations, citizens on both sides of the Channel should not be allowed to pay the high cost of divorce between the European Union and Britain. With or without a deal, they need to be sure that they will be able to continue to work, study and live as before. Negotiators must deliver on what they have already promised and guarantee and protect the rights of European citizens living in Britain as well as British citizens in the European Union, even if that is the only point they agree on. Dear Mr Tusk, I have another topic that I would like to raise. How long should we wait for the Council decision on the accession of Bulgaria and Romania to the Schengen area? Stage one – with international airports and maritime borders.  Europe is safer when it is united. Bulgaria and Romania will make Schengen safer and more stable – this is the assessment around which both the Commission and Parliament and all the security experts involved are coming together. Both sides have been fulfilling all technical criteria for seven years, and their adoption is suspended for entirely political reasons. I do not understand how long the Council will postpone the accession of Bulgaria and Romania with air and sea borders. I call on you to put this back on the agenda in the Council.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, there is deadlock on Brexit. The October deadline has been missed, the November European Council is uncertain, and all because of paralysis inside the UK Government, which seems incapable of reaching internal agreement as to what it wants. But already one thing is clear: Brexit will bear no resemblance whatsoever to what was promised by the Leave Campaign in the referendum. They said it would be easy; it’s proving to be pretty difficult. They said it would save lots of money that would all go to the National Health Service; it’s proving to be costly. They said there would be new trade deals ready on day one: what an illusion. In these circumstances itʼs not surprising that many people in Britain are asking to reconsider: 700 000 marching in London on Saturday; opinion polls shifting in the opposite direction of what people had expected: not rallying behind the referendum result but moving the other way. ‘If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy’, and that is what many in Britain hope will be available for them to do. And I know, Mr Tusk, I know, Frans Timmermans, you cannot intervene in that internal British debate, but please, do nothing to make that change of heart more difficult.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – President Tusk, in connection with the council's work last week, I have a few observations. One: about the Brexit negotiations, it was said that it is almost 90% over. The agreement seems not to be ready and it is obvious that the parties are at a standstill. That's bad, because the dispute is finally on the meaning of the concept of sovereignty. Second observation: on the proposal that the distribution of refugees be replaced by a financial contribution. Although, at first glance, it seems a breakthrough in relations within the Union, it is still a bad thing.  From a human rights point of view, the proposal is simply immoral. From the point of view of the Treaties, it cannot be required for a State to receive foreign populations, so the distribution is null and void. These are just two examples for which the current legal and institutional framework of the Union cannot provide principledly correct solutions. I stress, we cannot continue to go like this, because the problems are growing exponentially. We therefore need urgent and rapid reform of the European Union.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on the work of the President-in-Office This summit was a summit of consolation for the next summit, the handing over of the packages that are ready on the table by the European Parliament and the Commission. On Brexit, the Brexit debate shows us very clearly and thank God that the European Union is a community of justice, values and solidarity, not a game. We are an obligation, we are a responsibility, we are an idea. And not a single demand or promise from Brexiteers can be implemented in the Withdrawal Treaty because people have been lied to. Secondly, what do you, as the Council, say about this – although I know that there are some – that out of 40 proposals to deepen economic and monetary union, only six have been adopted, that out of 30 proposals on social union, only 15 have been implemented? Who is to blame for blocking the migration package? Who is to blame for the blocking of the expansion of the border agency? Who is to blame for the fact that the European Union – Parliament and the Commission – is increasingly having to initiate article 7 rule of law proceedings against Member States? Please put an end to the state of the blockade in the Council! Our thread of patience is beginning to tear. On the basis of today's debate, I would also like to say that I have the feeling with more and more politicians in the Council, but also in our House, that they are negligent in dealing with European responsibility. I therefore propose that every new official be given a one-day leadership in the House of European History at the beginning of his or her duties, that we be given a leadership in the Parliament, that we draw up a vow formula and that an oath be taken at the beginning of parliament and a Council function, that an approach be made to European law and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that it is a little sad, for those who believe in the European institutions and Europe, to have to comment on the October European Council, especially when I think of the debate we have had in this House in preparation for the Council itself. We have gone far behind the evanescent and pale decisions of June, and I have to say that all references to solidarity, to a common immigration policy, have disappeared. If you take away the Brexit decision, I think we could say that it was a European Council of nothing, of renouncing to exercise its responsibility. And I really wonder why. In short, we are at the end of a parliamentary term, we are also at the end of a "council", why give up like this? Why get to the end of our work with a kind of renunciation, of surrender? Do we realise that this opens the door to Europe's many and growing enemies? When I think of this renunciation of a serious policy, which has been progressively destroyed and faded from Council to Council, if I think that the government of my country has also contributed decisively to this, I am truly disheartened! And if I combine this, you must know, with decisions that within national legislation are destroying everything that has been done for integration, I really ask you to open your eyes and to be on the side of those who still want a European immigration policy.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to start by saying a little about the discussion that was before. I find it sad when a discussion degenerates a bit like it did. I understand that you have different positions and you have to be able to respect each other. There are many people with whom I do not share my views in this House, but I would never try to stop you from having your views. I believe deeply in democracy, and I find it sad when such scenes take place as they did just now. Otherwise, I would just like to say a little quickly that I am a little disappointed that absolutely nothing was achieved at the last summit in terms of Brexit. They sat and drank beer at Grande Place in the early evening and it shows how little effort was made to reach such a solution. Where did the night mangling go, I wonder, on such an important issue? Has all the will to find a solution to this ceased? So now is the time to take serious seriousness on the part of both parties to find a solution to the Brexit issue.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, so another Council meeting comes and goes without an agreement, the United Kingdom tries to backtrack on a backstop agreement that was agreed in writing, and 700 000 sensible people take to the streets of London to protest about this ongoing calamity. This past week truly was Brexit in a nutshell.  It was indeed disappointing that a deal could not be reached. However, Michel Barnier has the full confidence and support, and indeed gratitude, of Ireland and the rest of the EU27. Progress has been made and I am confident that a deal can be reached, including the protocol on Ireland and Northern Ireland, and the avoidance of a hard border on the island of Ireland. From my meetings this week with Michel Barnier and United Kingdom Permanent Representatives, I think this will be achieved at the 11th hour. On the Irish backstop, let me be perfectly clear. Ireland will listen to all proposals that the United Kingdom brings forward, but any proposal, in order to be acceptable, has to be legally operative and ensure that we avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. It has to protect the integrity of the single market and the customs union, and it has to apply unless and until we have a new relationship that supersedes it. We cannot allow uncertainty about the border and its impact on the peace process to persist beyond the United Kingdom’s withdrawal. This is something I would expect the hard Brexiteers to be conscious of, given the fact that they are part of the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland is in the United Kingdom. A deal is essential. A no—deal scenario would have enormous impacts on us all and most of all on the United Kingdom. Research by Imperial College London has estimated that a two—minute check at the Eurotunnel would cause a 10-mile traffic queue, a three—minute check would cause 20 miles, and a four—minute check would cause 30 miles. This is the reality of a hard Brexit. Let us be very clear. We want an agreement. An agreement is essential. I thank all our colleagues here, Michel Barnier, Donald Tusk et al, for their support. We will continue working on this issue.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, when I heard you a little over two and a half hours ago now, I must admit, I laughed. Then I wondered if you had come here to make fun of Parliament or if you had come to provoke us, because you know very well that no concrete conclusions on the Asylum package have been adopted. And as you have been asked to do many times, I would like you to explain to me how, for more than two years, no concrete position has been taken on this subject. While, at the same time, it is quite simple to look at it and reach an agreement on strengthening borders, this is going to happen on its own. At the same time on the 'Back' directive, the Member States are urging us to have the quickest possible reform, and moreover, by taking on board the French model, which is the most ineffective in this area. So you see, Parliament is not the chamber of registration of the Council's wishes and we do not intend to get caught up in this manipulation which is not ultimately aimed at effective reform, but simply at satisfying the populists.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, first of all, banking legislation: in order to reach a compromise, the Council needs to understand there is a need for compromising, and then we can achieve a lot. Africa: a continent of hope and despair. Countries in war but also countries with growth.  When China wants to increase Chinese power, we need to support African democracy. When the US makes itself smaller, we need to get taller. When China gets meaner, we need to be keener. Regarding frameworks and agreements for trade, investments, modernisation, new infrastructure: doing what we can in order to have the best possible development in this continent of huge opportunities and one of our most important neighbours. Brexit: let’s hope for democracy. Let’s hope that the millions of people wanting to stay can make their voices heard. But letʼs also ensure that we can get the best possible agreement if there is no change. Of course, the United Kingdom is an important part of Europe and an important country, and we need to safeguard the best possible relationship. Russia: let’s not underestimate what Russia is doing to the Europe of today. Cyber warfare, hacking, destabilisation, warfare (as in Ukraine), repression, corruption: let’s be strong in standing together and do what we can regarding Africa, safeguard ourselves against Russia and ensure that we can have the best possible economic development. Then we will be strong in the world.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, I too would like to express my great disappointment at Brexit, especially with regard to Cyprus. A large part of the Cypriot European citizens living within the English bases in Cyprus remain uncertain about their future and this has great economic implications but also much more around the design of everyday life. But I think that this phase gives us the opportunity to discuss both the rule of law and human rights, which are always in the news, and I regret to say that while we have recently decided that Turkey has failed in the areas of the rule of law, democracy, freedom of the press, at the same time, some people here – and I am referring to both the European Council and the European Commission – continue to regard Erdoğan's status as a democracy. Let's finally decide is it a democracy or is it a dictatorship? There's nothing in between!

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Dear President, like many speakers before me, I regret that the latter Council did not bring the expected results on Brexit. The UNITED KINGDOM wants more time to reach an agreement, and there is still no agreement, as there is no solution to the problems. The important problems that Brexit will bring, particularly on the border in Ireland. The second, which my country Lithuania also faces, is the situation of the citizens of the Member States of the European Union in the United Kingdom after Brexit. We do not want a divorce without an agreement, but every day makes us think that we must be prepared for this scenario as well. There is no consensus within the United Kingdom, there is no consensus with the European Union - we are losing all of us.  On migration. We all understand the importance of this issue, but, again, the expected results in the Council have not been achieved. Illegal migration is taking place, and we, a strong European Union, are unable to find a solution to this problem year after year. Our structures don't work? Let's change, reform them. But we have to deal with it. For internal security. Our citizens identify security as the most important among priorities. The European elections are approaching. It is important for us that our citizens are free to express their will so that their opinion and will are not manipulated. budget of the European Union. We also need an agreement on this issue. I know and understand that this issue is not an easy issue, but solving many problems is based on funding issues. I invite and ask the Council to find the political will to resolve this issue before the European elections.  I will be honest: I am missing the leadership of the European Council. The mandate you have, where are the results, where are the solutions that are expected? Our inaction has its price– it strengthens our opponents, it feeds on populism and extremism in Europe.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tusk, at last week's European Council there was no agreement on internal solidarity, either on Brexit or on the eurozone. But what have you come together to do? The Dublin reform has disappeared from the conclusions and there is not a single line on the legal and safe ways of accessing the EU for those fleeing. All we are talking about is blocking flows, increasing returns, conditioning development aid to greater control of Africa's borders. A disgrace! There has even been a summit to be held in Egypt's Al Sisi, when tomorrow we have been asking for truth about those who tortured and murdered Giulio Regeni, a European researcher. Chancellor Kurz's great idea of mandatory solidarity, although not as relocations, is nothing more than the flexible solidarity already proposed by the Slovak Presidency two years ago. Have you discussed two years to find yourself at the same point as before? President Macron, on the other hand, is calling for reform of Dublin before the elections, but in the meantime he is secretly bringing migrants back to the Italian woods. Explain this to the citizens of Europe because you are holding our two-year work on hold and making yourselves responsible for the advance of the worst nationalisms!

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, I firmly believe that the European Union, despite its problems and difficulties, will find its way, and certainly an important issue is Brexit, which concerns us all, especially us, who are from our small country Cyprus, where we really feel that there must be such an agreement that the rights of European citizens are registered so as not to create further problems. Nevertheless, we are proud because we are Europeans. We are proud because we belong to the large European family. We vigorously defend this European edifice because we want and demand a Europe that is strong. A Europe that can face the challenges. A Europe that will be able to respond for years to come, for decades to come. Today I will speak as one of the five hundred million European citizens. Dear friend, President of the European Council, Mr Donald Tusk, if you asked European citizens today 'what Europe do we want, what Europe do we claim', they would reply with one voice that we are claiming a Europe of solidarity, a strong Europe, which is sovereign and secures and secures the sovereignty of its member countries. A Europe that truly responds to the challenges of the new generation. A Europe, Mr Vice-President, which will be social and humane and you quite rightly said that the social dimension of Europe is the poor relative. We do not want this Europe. We want a Europe that is truly next to man, next to every European citizen. A strong Europe with a single defence policy, with a single defence and security. A Europe that is not a Europe of two measures of both stations and, when it imposes sanctions on its member countries or even on third countries, must also impose sanctions on countries that violate human rights, which hold a Member State of the European Union, such as Cyprus. It is none other than Turkey, which is in the undisturbed and under the tolerance of the European Union. I am proud, I said, of the European Union, but neither I nor my compatriots are particularly proud when, as we speak, the Turkish ship Barbaros and the Turkish ships are in the Cypriot EEZ without being harassed by anyone.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Madam President, it’s a strange quirk of parliamentary procedure that you have to wait so long to listen to sensible British voices in this Chamber, having heard the complete disgrace from Members opposite earlier this morning. I cannot believe what I am hearing from my own Government party – and, indeed, the disgrace that is Nigel Farage – criticising the civil service for not delivering their own fantasy. The reality is that Brexit is failing and we are seeing people flailing around desperately, issuing insults in the name of the British Government. It is not a strategy to threaten a no deal, effectively standing there with a can of petrol and a lighter threatening self—immolation. This is people’s jobs and people’s livelihoods we are talking about. Nearly three quarters of a million people marched in London against the mess that is Brexit. These are ordinary, decent people, who are sick and tired of being insulted by their own Government. It is time now to stop this nonsense. Nothing that is happening now is anywhere near what was promised in the referendum. It is time for informed consent for the British people if they want this mess to go forward. Put it to the people, put it to a people’s vote, and we need your help in giving us the time to allow that to happen. (Applause)

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, let me just cover three issues which have already been discussed here, first of all concerning Brexit. It is a pity that sufficient progress has not been reached but I still believe that in the weeks to come we will find a good agreement. It is essential that the EU27 keeps together as one and that we defend the clear interest of our members, especially of our Irish colleagues. Secondly, let me talk a little bit on taxation, as I am coming just for negotiation of the report of the Committee on Financial crimes, tax evasion and tax avoidance (TAX3). This is an area in which the EU can bring enormous benefits for EU citizens. If we solve the outstanding issues in the tax regimes, this will bring better and fair competition to the market and we will gain the trust of our citizens and, at the same time, this will allow countries to reduce some taxes which are the most damaging for the economy. There are many very important files on the table, especially CCCTB, CCTB, VAT reform and digital tax. While the Council was able to reach some progress on some tax files, it seems to me that there is not sufficient progress on these dossiers and this is a great pity; it is a lost opportunity for Europe. Last, but not least, let me talk about migration. The number of irregular migrants has gone down. Unfortunately, it seems to me that the efforts of the Member States to find agreement and make Europe more ready and better prepared for such a crisis in the future are also fading away and that is a very bad thing. We must get ready for future problems and we must solve the issues that we have been discussing for the last three years. So, also in this area, let me urge the Council to move forward.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, apart from Brexit, the Council has shown our blocked governments. It continues to fuel the business of human traffickers by not opening safe, controlled legal routes for migrants and refugees. They let poor people drown in the Mediterranean while 18 Member States sell gold visas to wealthy migrants, endangering European security, infiltrated, corrupted and captured by kleptocrats and mafias.  Without taking care of the eurozone, the Council deters taxing the digital giants via CCTB, while leaving criminal groups, including terrorists, to continue to finance themselves with carousel fraud without reforming VAT. They are calling for interoperability, but most governments are not even operationalising the PNR, the passenger lists they say are vital against terrorists, but that they have excluded private civilian flights, such as those that led to The Khashoggi murders in Istanbul and that at many European airports would not be controlled. President Tusk condemned this brutal murder here today, but the Council has done nothing to stop the export of arms to the Saudi dictatorship. No wonder! It's been a year since the murder of journalist Daphne Anne Caruana Galizia. The commanding men are still at large, unpunished, and Joseph Muscat, the main head of the investigation that is based in Malta, is sitting at the European Council. Everyone who sits there should blush with shame.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, allow me to thank all those Members who took time from within their small amount of numbers to speak, to set the record straight from other political parties as to the historic role social democracy has played in fighting Nazism. Thank you.  What I would also like to say – because what was said this morning has really affected me emotionally – it’s not so much the comparison that is made or the putting of social democracy in one group with Nazism. That’s not new. This is what we’ve seen happening – just go on the Internet – for years on the extreme right, where they try and rid themselves from their own heritage by saying that Nazism belongs to the left or to social democracy. That’s not new. What is new to me is that the leader in this House of the party of Churchill and Thatcher would appropriate that narrative. What has happened to the Conservative Party that not so long ago – in the last 10 years – was still a member of the European People’s Party (EPP) in this Parliament? What has happened that they are now using the same narrative that Mr Farage and others have been using for many years, a narrative that they’ve always distanced themselves from? Has what Churchill predicted when he talked about appeasers happened – the only thing you get by feeding a crocodile is that the crocodile will eat you last? Has the Conservative Party finally been eaten by UKIP? I hope not.  (Interjection from the floor: ‘I hope so’) I’m sure you hope so, yes, but I do hope not. I say this because I will make no secret of my deep admiration and affection for the United Kingdom and everything it has achieved during European history. I say this also because I don’t want to hide my deep sadness regarding the decision taken by the British people in the referendum to leave the European Union. The European Union is not a market. The European Union is an instrument to help European people solve their differences around the negotiating table instead of at the battlefield. The European Union is the best guarantee that no British soldiers will have to be sent to battlefields in Europe again, as they have so valiantly done in our common history. The European Union is the best guarantor for peace in Europe for the ages to come, and for one of the biggest Member States to leave that European Union is an incredibly sad moment. I want to say that in this House, but, given that decision, we are all under an obligation to do as little harm as possible in the process. As a democrat, as a human being, who in this House has never ever changed their minds on anything? We’ll leave that with the British people. That’s not for us to judge. But I want us to be clear about our obligation as the Commission, European Parliament and Council: that we should do everything in our power to make sure we do as little harm as possible. That is the attitude with which the Commission should do this. This will not be helped by exaggerated political rhetoric, by appealing to the darkest angels of European history. Let’s have a rational debate, let’s understand that we build bridges – not walls – in this European Union. Let’s be clear about that.  I want to end with a quote from one of my favourite writers, Primo Levi. I say this because of what was said this morning. I quote: ‘Auschwitz is outside of us, but it is all around us, in the air. The plague has died away, but the infection still lingers and it would be foolish to deny it. Rejection of human solidarity, obtuse and cynical indifference to the suffering of others, abdication of the intellect and of moral sense to the principle of authority, and above all, at the root of everything, a sweeping tide of cowardice, a colossal cowardice which masks itself as warring virtue, love of country and faith in an idea.’ (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, thank you for your interesting interventions. I really appreciate your involvement, even if I don’t agree with all your arguments and emotions. You may have noticed that I never try to take too much of your precious time, and today I will also stick to this rule. However, I cannot leave two interventions without a comment. First, on migration. Almost all of you have expressed your disappointment with the lack of decisions on migration policy that you were expecting from the European Council. I understand your dissatisfaction, because I know that the will of the majority in this House was to establish mandatory quotas. In spite of what you are saying, the European Council is building the common European solution for migration policy. But in the centre of this approach is the strengthening of cooperation with third countries, a fight against human smugglers, external border protection – and not mandatory quotas. The real progress in the European Council is that today, almost everybody understands that our priority should be stopping the inflow of irregular migrants and not their distribution. On Brexit, we want to avoid a hard border in Ireland, but there is no guarantee that we can do it. And do you know why, Mr Farage? Because Brexit is de facto a political decision to re-establish the border between the Union and the UK. Brexit is a project to separate the UK from the EU. I don’t know what is going to be the result of the negotiations, but I know that it is the Brexiteers who are 100% responsible for bringing back the problem of the Irish border. Finally, I would like to share with you one remark. Listening to the debate here, I get the impression that some of you would like to see a Europe where there are no Member States and no governments. Please do not be surprised that I am not on the same line.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, this question is addressed directly to you. I have read in the press statements that you are complaining that a programme launched by the Italian government would probably not benefit Italians, but Roma, foreigners. This kind of discourse, if true, is very much akin to the discourse of national preference that we are not used to hearing from the EPP. Whether it's from the ENL group or the EFDD group, I can understand. But whether it comes from you, it poses a serious problem, I think, of simply respecting European values! So if you have said these words, I invite you to withdraw them, because they are not worthy of a President of Parliament. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: You do not know, Mr Lamberts, the Italian situation. I listened. You always have to respect others. You don't know the Italian situation. I said that you cannot draw from the Italian budget to give money to Italians who do not work and to citizens who are not Italian and who do not work. I said that few Italians will have money and that foreigners will also have money. So this is not a benefit for italians. We are going to waste money without solving the problem of unemployment. I said that we have to give money to companies that are able to give jobs to citizens, either Italian or foreign. So we couldn't express themselves like that? But it is an opinion and one is free to have an opinion. I did not say that we should not respect the treaties, but I said that because of the treaty, you cannot give many Italians what the government said. You can't interpret my position, I say what I think. I must not debate that. I answered and that's enough.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me steal a few seconds of your time, but it is a matter of the utmost importance. The multinational Alcoa wants to close its two floors in Spain, in Avilés and in A Coruña, leaving hundreds of workers on the street. This company has received more than 1 billion euros in public aid and has acknowledged that the closure is due to the company not having invested a single euro in modernizing these plants. Yesterday, at the beginning of the negotiation, Alcoa proposes that she refuses to sell the factories, which she wants to close. Why? Because, coincidentally, where you have invested the money is in a factory in Saudi Arabia and what you do not want is to have any kind of competition; because, while receiving this aid with money from the Spanish state, he invested it in Saudi Arabia. That's why I'm going to ask you for two things. First of all, I don't care about the political group, I don't care what country they belong to, I ask for the utmost support to protect European industry, our workers and our communities. And secondly, to push for a common policy to defend our industry, to prevent companies that receive billions of dollars in public money from simply leaving, relocating and closing their factories and doors, leaving hundreds of workers on the street and leaving entire communities in the snout.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The European Council has listened to parliamentary groups, from right to left, to say with all due respect that their leaders have to listen to this Parliament, that they have to abandon paralysis and lack of solutions, because they are contributing to the total failure of European policy. And citizens need to know that it is the governments — which is not the Commission, which is not Parliament, which have done their homework — that it is the governments, most of the conservative governments that are slowing down the solutions of the European Union. Mr Tusk has been allowed to congratulate the Austrian Presidency on its great commitment to migration policies. It's a big joke. Because Austria is considering leaving the United Nations Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration. That's Austria's attitude. The leaders of the European Union are consenting to citizens getting away from everything we stand for here. And that is the responsibility of Mr Tusk, the Council, the governments, the Conservative majority currently leading the European Union. And we have to raise our voices against that paralysis that fuels the worst ghosts in the European Union.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The European Council has listened to parliamentary groups, from right to left, to say with all due respect that their leaders have to listen to this Parliament, that they have to abandon paralysis and lack of solutions, because they are contributing to the total failure of European policy. And citizens need to know that it is the governments — which is not the Commission, which is not Parliament, which have done their homework — that it is the governments, most of the conservative governments that are slowing down the solutions of the European Union. Mr Tusk has been allowed to congratulate the Austrian Presidency on its great commitment to migration policies. It's a big joke. Because Austria is considering leaving the United Nations Global Compact for Safe, Orderly and Regular Migration. That's Austria's attitude. The leaders of the European Union are consenting to citizens getting away from everything we stand for here. And that is the responsibility of Mr Tusk, the Council, the governments, the Conservative majority currently leading the European Union. And we have to raise our voices against that paralysis that fuels the worst ghosts in the European Union.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – I would like to comment on the second day of the EU summit: migration and internal security, external borders – these were the main items on the agenda of the EU summit of 18 October 2018. Our proposals for solutions, the european Parliament's decision – we have been stressing this for three years after every EU summit that ends without results – have long been on the table. But the heads of government and government are still unable to give a clear answer. As my fellow Members have also made clear, there is a consensus in the European Parliament: we have lost a great deal of time under the Austrian Presidency. This applies not only to the asylum package, but also to social Europe and the important reforms for economic and monetary union – here too, the European Parliament's proposals are on the table. Finally, stand up for a Europe that really protects socially!

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. Mr Tusk, I would like to hear you say that our heads of government have considered a migration policy 'in all its aspects'. I have read the Council conclusions and I see only three elements in them: cooperation with North Africa against illegal migration, tackling people smuggling and return. Important things, of course, but are these ALL aspects of a migration policy? What was it about addressing the root causes of migration? Short asylum procedures? Distribution? Resettlement? And above all: what was it about the dramatic situation in the hotspots? These elements were discussed in 2015 and 2016, and it is not because you are silent about them that the problems have disappeared.  I would also like to draw your note to the letter of 10 October which the rapporteurs of Parliament sent to Mr Kurz. Two and a half years after the Commission published seven reform proposals, the Council has not yet reached an agreement on any. Three provisional agreements with Parliament were even withdrawn. How is it that this was not discussed at a meeting where, once again, ALL aspects were discussed? The legislature will soon end, and without an agreement on these dossiers, the hard work of recent years will be cancelled. These are the aspects that should have been discussed.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, in May 2019 we have a European election and the top issue of migration remains problematic. There is an unfair burden-sharing between Member States and a lack of solidarity. The measures to strengthen FRONTEX and the Single European Border Guard are not sufficient, and the revision of the Dublin system has run counter to the rigidity of some Member States. At the same time, Turkey, which systematically disregards international law, escalating its challenges against my country of Greece, is implementing the 2016 EU-Turkey Agreement as they see fit! Flows of refugees and migrants from the Turkish coast to the islands of the North-East Aegean have increased significantly, and there are also daily arrivals of large numbers of foreigners at the Greek-Turkish land border in Evros. Colleagues, in six months we will be asking for the vote of European citizens. It is necessary here and now to respond to their demands, moving from general references to specific actions. We must prove in practice that the EU has the will but above all the power to enforce compliance with its decisions in all Member States without exception.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would like to pay particular attention to the three aspects discussed at the European Council, which seem crucial, especially from the point of view of our security. Firstly, reducing irregular migration by 95% compared to October 2015 is a very good result, but we need a systemic and above all effective way of preventing such situations in the future. The Council draws attention to this. It is particularly welcome that our leaders are aware of the shortcomings and shortcomings of the current regulations in this area and call for work to improve them.  Secondly, I welcome the strong emphasis on security in cyberspace and the call for the possibility of imposing sanctions on those involved in cyber attacks on Europeans or our infrastructure. The answer to such flagrant violations of our online security must be firm. Defence capabilities in this area should also be further worked on at a rapid pace.  It is also an important step to call for concrete action to combat disinformation and the possibility of manipulating social sentiment in Europe. We have a string of important choices ahead of us, and it is vital that public institutions and citizens themselves have the tools at their disposal to mark false and manipulated information online. The Council's call is a step in the right direction.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Council followed the pattern of other recent summits. Its members have addressed issues of great impact on the daily lives of people and businesses, but the lack of decisions capable of conveying confidence and strategic clarity has made it another moment that will go down in history as an example of the lack of ambition in the European Union's response to the challenges it faces.  I would like to stress the progress made in negotiating Brexit, safeguarding the basic principles with which it has developed the process, protecting the rights of European citizens, strife for a border model that does not weaken Ireland's full membership and establishing the lines of force that could lead to future partnerships between the European Union and the United Kingdom.  I also record the publicised intention of reaching an agreement by the end of the year on the Banking Union and continuing technical studies for the necessary reform of economic and monetary union.  The Council also took relevant measures in terms of internal security and control of migration flows, but the lack of an integrated and humanistic vision of the threats and opportunities posed to the European Union by the new geostrategic framework remained notorious.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Denis Mukwege and Nadia Murad have been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. In 2014 and 2016, the European Parliament had already assigned dr. Mukwege and Nadia Murad the Sakharov Prize for their extraordinary commitment to defending human rights.  I would also like to mention the case of Asia Bibi, a woman from the Christian minority who is at risk of being hanged in her country. Asia Bibi sparked the fury of some women for drinking from a source: according to these women, contact with Christian lips would make the water impeas. After being attacked and reported for blasphemy, Asia Bibi risks being hanged. I call on the Pakistani authorities to guarantee a fair trial for women and to avoid any form of discrimination or religious prejudice.  (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Bay, if you wish to speak on the waiver of immunity, I am sorry, but that is not allowed because the people concerned have been heard by the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and the ENF Group spoke on this case last Monday at 5.00 p.m., so there is no need to speak again.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Mr President, I had an agreement from President Tajani to speak on this point in the Conference of Presidents.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: And in fact you spoke on Monday at 5.00 p.m., so that speech is exhaustive on the matter.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as in previous years, due to the complexity of the procedure, the following technical adjustments will have to be applied. It is therefore a communication to my fellow Members. On the figures: the lines listed below will be adjusted in such a way as to correspond to the result of the BUDG committee's vote. Line 19 02 01, Amendment 1689: commitments will be increased to EUR 269 810 177. Line 13 08 02, Amendment 1658: commitments and payments will be increased to EUR 48 653 000 and EUR 25 888 246 respectively. Line 32 02 10, Amendment 1816: payments will be increased to EUR 18 807 975. Line 33 04 77 06, Amendment No 1753: commitments will be increased to EUR 1 260 000. On comments: In line 21 02 07 03, Amendment No 1700 will be corrected to ensure that the comment corresponds to the result of the BUDG committee's vote. Finally, line 15 02 77 23 (Amendment No 1666) will be moved from heading 1a to heading 3.  These are technical adjustments and nothing more.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am sorry for being delayed. I was wrongly informed but, on the other hand, I am very happy to have a full plenary session here. I am happy to see that.  (Applause) By the way, I was following the debate on TV so I saw that you have just adopted the amendments to the Council’s position on the draft budget for the financial year 2019. I take note of the differences in the position of our two institutions concerning the draft budget for 2019 presented by the Commission. Consequently, in my capacity as President of the Council, I agree that the President of the European Parliament convenes the Conciliation Committee, as required in Article 314(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We thank the Minister for his speech.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would just like to stress that in the last vote, qualified majority voting was, of course, necessary for some votes, and that, in vote 798, we must check whether the roll-call vote took place. 798, and it is a question of qualified majority voting in various votes. Thank you!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Rübig, thank you for that clarification, but of course there was a qualified majority, so everything is fine. 798 was voted by roll call and was rejected.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, then that’s ok; no problem.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: In the light of the decision to refuse discharge, in agreement with the chairman of the CONT Committee, I propose the following amendment to paragraph 4, which is necessary to bring the text of the resolution into line with the result of the vote. The text reads as follows: "The corrective measures taken so far have responded in part rather than sufficiently to the reservations expressed by Parliament in its decision of 18 April 2018 to postpone discharge." (Parliament adopted the amendment)

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: I don't know what I' – Today's vote welcomes the step forward taken by Ireland and Croatia to join the Prüm data exchange system. Protecting the European Union's external border is an urgent and vital matter. Today's vote is news to all traffickers, smugglers, members of criminal gangs and terrorists who are trying to profit from us or harm us with the news that the network for exchanging information between Member States is once again a little wider. And we tell you: we will catch you and affect you according to our laws. We will not allow your evil intentions to destroy our way of life based on Jewish-Christian values to become a reality. And I ask God, the father of ours, Mr Jesus Christ, to bless the European Union and its people.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I thank the plenary for its overwhelming support for this important directive. And now I would like to invoke our regulation, namely Article 59, paragraph 4, sub-paragraph 4, to ask for the green light to refer the matter to the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and then allow me to open inter-institutional negotiations at the beginning of November.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time. (The sitting was suspended at 1.39 p.m.)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: " I voted in favour of this report, which is a great work in progress. I congratulate Mr Daniele Viotti on his successful way of directing the negotiations between the factions. Despite the fact that in May 2018 the Commission's annual draft budget presented at the time was not ambitious. Furthermore, despite the fact that, following the Commission's proposal, the Council also proposed further budget cuts. However, I am pleased that the European Parliament's budget committee has been able to identify the importance for 2019. I also find it particularly positive that, in the system of pilot projects and preparatory actions, the concept of smart villages, which I launched as a pilot project in 2015 and is one of the most important rural concepts of the Socialists and Democrats, is now being supported on an increasing scale.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that the section of the general budget of the European Union has passed, because we have tabled a pilot project which concerns the protection of investigative journalists and, obviously, the freedom of the press in the Union. This pilot project has two very clear objectives: money for investigative journalism. They are investigating organised crime, money laundering, corruption – especially when it comes to politicians – and they need independent financial support, obviously, because otherwise they could no longer investigate, because governments are not funding them. And the second clear objective of this project is legal aid for them, because they are being sued, they are being investigated in many countries precisely to stop them from these investigations. I hope it goes all the way. I would also like to say that it is necessary, at Union level, to have – apart from this pilot project – a solid mechanism to protect investigative journalism. They are the most exposed today in the whole world. The currency of exchange on this battlefield with organized crime is death.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
