text: Mr President, EUR 250 million has been cut by the Commission from pre-accession aid for Turkey, another EUR 150 million has been cut by the Council and today we are also cutting another EUR 66 million. This money goes towards reform policy and we may have legitimate objections to the state of the rule of law, but this money goes both for the management of migration flows and for border management and for the integration of vulnerable groups and for civil society. The gleaming face of dynamic civil society, the faces of Turkey, will be dazzled by our own difficulty in being able to decide, because of our short-sighted decision. But all three billion euros that fall short of the European Union's agreement with Turkey (the EU-Turkey declaration) are becoming a game between Parliament and the Member States. We must state clearly that these will not be cut because to repeat the most competent lips from the Greek government that it is between us and the disaster is the joint statement with Turkey.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have supported the 2019 budget and I believe that it will ensure the guarantees we promise our citizens. It is primarily about a safe Europe, it is also about addressing the root causes of huge migratory pressure, especially from the Middle East and Africa. We want to promote economic growth, increase competitiveness and, above all, support young people. I therefore appreciate, in particular as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, the increase in funding for Erasmus+ and Horizon 2020. Both of these programmes have worked well and are effectively used. This includes, for example, the DiscoverEU project, which helps young people in particular to get to know eu Member States better. I am also glad that a pilot project called Jan Ámos Price has been approved, which is aimed at supporting teachers who are educating about the European Union.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, last Sunday there was a new jump on the melilla fence, with 200 people. Two people died, one of them on the Spanish side of the fence. Spain has expressly returned 55 people to Morocco. In August there were 116 people to which the Government expressly returned, hotly, to Morocco. The European Court of Human Rights found that the hot returns made by Spain on the border with Morocco are illegal, violate European directives and the European Convention on Human Rights. Today we voted on three reports on the Schengen Information System which increase the number of agents, weapons and deportations to non-European countries. That is, more outsourcing of borders, something criticized by social organizations and lawyers. The far-right project unfortunately crystallizes with the complicity of popular, liberal and social democrats, who continue to vote in this House in favour of strengthening Europe's strength and against human rights.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the general budget is one of the most complex and crucial files that Parliament is adopting this year. I am happy to see that we have gone much further than the Commission and the Council in our commitments.  I am speaking about the enforcement of the Youth Employment Initiative, Horizon 2020, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and other projects. The budget for next year must be tailor—made to address the needs of our citizens. Therefore I support the programmes that give the highest European added value. As the shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs to this report, I did my best to contribute to the chapter on security and citizenship. I specifically underlined the role of EU agencies, which are practical tools in solving security problems. We cannot give them big mandates and little money. We cannot do more with less. In addition, I initiated and supported several pilot projects. One of those is the protection of investigative journalism and media freedom in the EU. In some EU countries like my country, Latvia, it is crucial.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by From the point of view of the Committee on Culture, 6 points mean that the budget can be considered satisfactory. Firstly, the increase, of course, of Erasmus+ programmes, which we have been fighting for from the very beginning. The effect is more than satisfactory: 5 million more for Creative Europe. This is very important and very important, because there we had the greatest underestimation. €3.9 million more for the Creative Europe cross-sectoral instrument – a very good decision. And 3.3 million more for multimedia activities.  From my point of view, it is particularly satisfying to have nearly 20 pilot projects out of 29 submitted. This is the best result in recent years. And a million for special annual additional events. We have always had a gap here, and I am very pleased that it has also been filled.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the budget must adequately respond to the challenges we face and reflect our objectives and policies. That is why I fully support the position we have expressed in Parliament, in relation to support for competitiveness programmes.  So, encouraging new technologies, innovation, research and development - we cannot slow this down and we cannot agree with the Proposal of the Commission and the Council. Likewise, investment in youth, in the Youth Employment Initiative, must be accelerated. Rural areas are particularly prominent in our proposal. They're threatened with depopulation, emasuing, and we have to stand up to that.  Our proposal from the European Parliament is really trying to touch on all those key problems that are tormenting people in the European Union, and I hope that the Council will recognise this in dialogue with us and that the funding for these programmes will increase, in particular, of course, migration and security. There can also be no reduction for the surrounding countries, especially non-member states in Southeast Europe, which we must encourage faster change through the IPA increase.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, the budget we are voting on today is indeed very important because the withdrawal of the United Kingdom will limit our resources and once again in Europe we will be called upon to do more with fewer resources. But the reality is that this gap can be filled by European resources, that gap that cannot be easily filled is the gap in global competitiveness. That is why initiatives such as the Juncker plan, which continues in the form of InvestEU, are the ones that can really give Europe a big boost, give wings, as long as they appeal to everyone. In Greece, for example, we have had multiple results in transport investment and broadband networks, research and innovation. But we have not been able to have resources from the Juncker plan for small and medium-sized enterprises. We therefore need to encourage innovative investments, such as that made in Lithuania to produce energy from biomass and solid waste at the same time. We need to see how they are repeated and we need to adopt good practices. We need to respond to the new era by creating sustainable jobs.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I am delighted to support some of the aspects of today’s budget, particularly the propositions that put funding and resources behind the fine words that have been spoken in this Parliament to tackle the problems of sexual harassment. For too long we have had just words. After today, we will have what we need to address the problem, which is resources and people with the skills and the experience that we need to take that problem on, so I am delighted about that. The overall cost of the European Union budget per week per citizen is about a pint of beer. The cost of this Parliament is about a cup of coffee a year, but it is very important that we seek to bring down that further and I am delighted to see that propositions for a single-seat Parliament are going through Parliament today. It’s for far too long that we have neglected that issue and if the French are serious about it, and Mr Macron is serious about it, then he can take on this problem too, because it rests in his hands.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, I did not support this draft budget because, unfortunately, I believe that it sets a bad precedent on the eve of our agreement on the next budgetary framework after 2020. I think that if we are really serious about protecting the EU's external borders, then this should also be taken into account in this financial framework, and we should do it differently than by inventing other centralised authorities and agencies managed from Brussels. We should help, visibly, to help the EU border states that bear the greatest burden of responsibility, be it Bulgaria, Greece, Malta, Italy or Spain. I'm sure it would also be worth showing symbolically that we can save money. The fact that it is still not possible to establish one seat of the European Parliament in Brussels has already been mentioned here. I can also imagine cutting, for example, the budget for the European External Action Service. But I couldn't support a budget like this.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, this is the 20th time that I’ve sat here and spent two hours nodding through budget increases. In those 20 years, there’s been just one fixed rule of every EU budget, and it’s this: it only ever rises. We’re way past the point where people are trying to match spending to specific need. The EU is now seen as an end in itself. There’s a general mood in this Chamber – I think if you’re honest, you’ll all recognise it – that it is better for the EU to be doing something even if it does it badly, than for the nation states to be doing it more efficiently. Now in fairness, this is an attitude common to almost every organisation. Any bureaucracy over time becomes primarily interested in its own aggrandisement. Its primary purpose becomes to spend more on itself and its notional stated purpose becomes secondary – if you’re lucky. But you’ve just got to ask the question: is there any sum of money that is enough to sell a fundamentally flawed idea?

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, in today’s budget vote, it is highly regrettable that the shortfall in funding for the European Union Agency for Railways was not reversed, as proposed by the Committee on Transport and Tourism, in this Parliament. The agency must therefore be required to bear alone the recurring costs of a new information and communication coordination system, which is vital to railway safety. To answer the previous speaker, this is a specific new responsibility. It is required by European Union law and it will apply across Europe. Although the budget resolution amendment did highlight that extra funding for agencies with additional responsibilities must now be found, this on its own is insufficient. I call upon the Commission and the Council to follow that up with concrete action and find the money for the European Union Agency for Railways.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, this European Parliament has done its part in the work by approving and boosting the European budget for next year 2019 and so that there can be a multiannual financial framework.  Is it not time for the Council to be able to stop acting as the failed and paralyzing link in the European decision-making process?  Is it not time for the Council to listen to the European Parliament and increase the budget to 1.3% with own resources, such as the rate of financial transactions, as requested by this European Parliament?  Is it not time for the Council to unlock the Dublin Regulation, the solidarity necessary to give reason to the migration issue, and above all for it to send a positive message to the British Europeanists who have expressed themselves by a second referendum? I wish they had gone to vote when they had the time to have avoided Brexit (23 June 2016)! But Europeanists will be able to have a chance to support Europe in the face of Europhobia and anti-Europe in the May 2019 elections.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – I voted in favour of this report because I find it unacceptable to place any waste in the seas, but I absolutely believe that single-use plastics account for 70% of this. Unfortunately, in terms of this ratio, we would achieve a similar result if, for example, landfill sites were inspected in Hungary. I am also in support of a ban on the marketing of single-use plastics from 2021. Metal, wood or glass-based devices are the perfect alternative for all these products. In addition to the prohibition, however, we also need to work on solving practical problems, such as the problem of mixing the different categories of plastics and alternative plastics recycling currently used in the European Union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, the problem of plastic litter at sea and in the oceans is a problem that we can all see in our day-to-day life. In fact, the amount of plastic we pour into the sea is equivalent to one whole garbage truck per minute, roughly what this intervention will last. Finally, the European Commission has been concerned about the pollution caused by these plastics, but time is already pressing. And, to be honest, this proposal could have been much stricter. Drastically reducing useless food wrappers or plastic cups, setting collection targets for bottles or including cigarette filters in the Directive — as proposed by Parliament – are very positive measures. However, we must go further. Although the industry will have to start paying the costs of collecting plastics, the Commission has again not wanted to touch the benefits of large multinationals. Inevitably, the list of prohibited products should be increased in the coming years. All this, of course, if we don't want to end up eating plastic fish.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, I warmly thank the plenary for voting on the amendment I tabled for a major European programme to clean up the oceans and plastic continents. I think this is an important step forward, but it will not be enough because we need a radical change in our production methods to allow us to avoid the worst and that tomorrow our planet will be renamed the 'plastic planet'. We are in fact already in a major ecological disaster, with billions of tons of plastic accumulating in nature and in our oceans and, what is less visible but just as harmful, these microplastics that end up in the air we breathe or in the salt we eat. That is why we must now put an end to half measures and finally ban single-use plastics.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report on the reductions of plastics. I recently had the pleasure of meeting Winnipeg, a sea lion with a passion for recycling, at Colchester Zoo in my constituency. Winnipeg is a bit of an environmentalist and enjoys hunting out plastic bottles and putting them into the recycling bin near her pool. It’s a fun and splashy way of getting across a green message to youngsters. And the zoo are also taking practical steps in its cafés, like swapping plastic straws for paper and plastic ice cream spoons for wooden ones. There is a real wave of anger about the 12.6 million tonnes of plastic being dumped into our seas every year. 62% of people who watched the BBC’s Blue Planet programme who were surveyed said that they wanted to make changes to their daily lives to reduce their impact on the oceans. People want to dive in and make a difference. It is time to help protect sea lions, whales, penguins and their pals from the devastation of plastic pollution, to clean up our seas and save wildlife that’s hanging on by a whisker.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I supported the European Parliament's proposal to restrict the use and ban the production of single-use plastic products. Especially in those cases where we have affordable alternatives – cutlery, plates, straws, beverage mixing sticks or balloons – these are all things that can do without plastic. Although other types of plastics, such as oxodegradable disposable bags, will also fall apart, I still think that they need to be replaced and their use reduced here too. In the case of lightweight plastic bags, I respect the maintenance of exemptions for hygiene items and for the packaging of meat and similar foods. I also appreciate that the report does not neglect the problems of fishing tackle, which account for 27% of all waste.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The ubiquitous plastic has been polluting the environment for years, but I abstained on the report on reducing the impact of certain plastic products. The situation is also the result of previous strategies which, carried out without imagination, have led to pollution on an unimaginable scale. In Europe only, 15 tonnes of plastic are thrown into the sea every year and 8 million tonnes worldwide into the oceans, where all living organisms are affected, not only in the seas and oceans, but in birds that absorb plastics. In addition, the effect of microplastics on human health is completely unknown. Therefore, there is a need to reduce environmental disaster by effective methods.  However, I am in favour of leaving it to the Member States to decide on the choice of instruments to reduce the consumption of single-use plastic items. I would also like to leave the decision to introduce legislation on packaging collection and recycling. In addition to regulation, there is an urgent need for information, education, both for packaging manufacturers and the public around the world, and for researchers to be involved in reducing pollution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – In the world, more than a million plastic bottles are sold every minute, in fact, and this is also one demonstration of how plastic has become a daily life.  Of course, knowing that plastic is also the killer of our future, we must be aware that by 2050, if we do not change anything, there will be more plastic in the sea than there is fish, that this plastic, in fact, penetrates everywhere, is in food, destroys and kills animals, and it has also been found in man. So this microplastic, which is also the result of so much discarded plastic, poses a serious threat to our planet.  And at the same time, of course, we must be aware that there are alternatives and that, in fact, this fight against single-use plastics is also an opportunity for the economy, for new jobs, we just need to move on time and also invest resources in research on how to get to this goal as quickly and efficiently as possible, i.e. to make a stop plastics.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am in favour of taking care of the environment, about ecology, starting with myself, from simple behaviors in my own household. I must say that, for this reason, I had no doubt about how to react to both the amendments and the report itself – I supported them. However, I believe that in this matter we should be characterized by more rationality, more consistency, more determination. I am satisfied with the report itself and from the findings of today, but I would stress that our reactions in this area are unfortunately a little late. What do I pay attention to first of all? First of all, I pay attention to the production system itself. Such restrictions should be imposed so that less plastics are produced as a result of the production itself. The second element – equally important – is selection, also paying attention to what is already in the landfills – and then we will have a certain set of actions in this matter.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, up to 85% of marine waste is plastic rubbish. Half of this plastic rubbish in the seas consists of products designed to be discarded after a single use. The aim of the proposal for a directive is to ban certain single-use plastic products, such as cutlery, plates and straws, which can already be produced from alternative and durable materials.  The aim is to increase the collection rate of plastic bottles to 90% by 2025. This objective can be achieved, for example, by means of an effective deposit-based bottle collection system, which could be further enhanced by increasing the price of a bottle deposit to, for example, EUR 1.  I welcome the fact that product packaging is labelled with information on the adverse effects of littering and how the waste generated should be sorted. All actors must play their part in significantly reducing the amount of waste and the environmental load. The end result is a clear step forward and it was really easy to vote in favour of a good report.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, in Europe we may not be champions in plastic pollution but we produce a hundred and fifty thousand tonnes every year and throw them overboard and, unless major initiatives are taken at both European and international level, in 2050 we will have more plastics than fish in our seas. Today, of course, there is the target of recycling plastics by 65% by 2025 in terms of packaging and by 70% by 2030, as there are other individual targets. What matters and urgently, however, is to move towards immediate alternatives and replace conventional disposable plastics with those that are biodegradable or those that can become fertilisers. We must also change the consumer model. For this reason, I have launched the Fish or Plastic campaign with Colleagues Virkkunen and Ribeiro, and with the support of Vice-President Katainen. Consumers need to change. Above all, however, governments must adopt and implement immediate waste management plans aimed at the circular economy and, ultimately, replacing plastics with either recyclable or biodegradable plastics.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I am pleased today to support this ambitious report on single—use plastics. I believe that the European Union can – and should – lead the way in cleaning up the world’s oceans. The scale of the problem is staggering, with eight million tons of plastic waste ending up in the oceans every year. It’s an ecological catastrophe, but with firm action we can solve the problem. A lot of the plastic that’s in our seas from food and drink packaging can be replaced with something more sustainable. We can make sure that plastic bottles are recycled. Unless we act now with determination, the effect on our marine life will be drastic, and who knows where that will end. This report is a step in the right direction, but there is much more that we need to do. But we can do this. Finally, as a British MEP, I am delighted and proud of the role that the BBC, and Sir David Attenborough in particular, have played in bringing this problem to the attention of the world.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, in 1979, when my sister came home from a Girl Guides trip with a plastic spoon and a plastic fork, myself and my younger brother had a fight over who would get to keep it. The reason why we fought to keep it was because we had never seen one before. I won the fight. I got to keep this new lightweight, plastic, modern future for us. At the time we were worried; our main worry on this planet was a nuclear holocaust. Little did we realise that the plastic fork and spoon that I had in my hand was actually going to turn out to be more dangerous – and I say that now, even with who we have in the White House. By 2050 there will be more plastic in the oceans than there are fish by weight: 130 different marine species known to have ingested plastic. This proposal focuses on the top ten single—use plastics: cotton bud sticks, cutlery, plates, stirrers and straws. It would not take a genius to replace the plastic in the cotton bud with wood. My mother was not a genius to use proper cups and plates at our birthday parties. It wouldn’t take me to be a genius to use proper cups and plates at future birthday parties. More of this: this is what the Union should be about, not war and not about finance.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my satisfaction with the adoption of this report by Parliament on the Plastics Directive. A legislative proposal that is immersed in the Action Plan for the Circular Economy and the Plastics Strategy. It contains a number of measures which I believe this Parliament has improved. Therefore, the work we have done has been satisfactory in eliminating those single-use plastics.  I would especially like to highlight some of the most significant aspects, in my opinion. Prohibition measures are taken when we have other alternatives that are much more sustainable. Therefore, those that are not sustainable will be banned. Secondly, labelling shall indicate the negative environmental impact and the presence of this plastic on the product.  Thirdly, the obligation of Member States to collect 90% of plastic beverage bottles and, fourthly, one very important thing: if we do not all become aware of the importance of plastic reduction, we will not succeed. It is something that we must remove from our usual use.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, this report is an important step to prevent the negative and harmful impact of plastics on the environment. Invented in the mid-19th century, plastic has been mass produced since the early 1950s, with an exponential rise in production in the last 15 years. Over eight billion tons in barely 65 years, resulting in more than six billion tons of waste. This is an alarming figure, and tackling the plastic problem is a must. This throwaway society is turning our oceans into one great garbage bin, with plastic responsible for 85% of our marine pollution. If we do not take action, by 2050 there will be more plastics than fish in our oceans. I fully support the proposals to introduce new rules on the use of plastics and a new strategy for plastic in the circular economy. I encourage the Commission to support businesses and technological innovations which aim to substitute the plastic used in certain products. The protection of our environment is our responsibility, and the EU should lead the world towards a cleaner and greener future.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I was very pleased to support the report, which talks about a way to ban the reduction of plastics we use for single use. I am pleased that the European Union remains the continent that makes the most of this. We are not the biggest emitters of the sea, the oceans with plastics, but we are certainly the ones who have the clearest vision of how to prevent this.  On the other hand, we have very clear measures in the area of waste management and the direction in which we need to go, that is to say, first of all, the least possible use of plastics and, on the other hand, what we have, is produced in such a way that it is possible to use it multiplely and, above all, that recycling is possible at the end of the life cycle.  There are two things that are very important: first of all, to make people aware that we will change in our behaviour. Our youngest, who are changing habits, play an important role here. On the other hand, it is important that we invest in the development of new technologies that will implement materials that will be significantly more sustainable and replace these great enemies of our continent.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this draft report. In my view, the ban on the sale of disposable plastic products is a good step, as the low price and the almost unlimited availability of these leftovers over time have made rather problematic waste, which we cannot effectively dispose of today, rather than handy helpers. Indeed, this discovery has become more of a nightmare. Sadly, however, this revolution has kind of got out of hand, it is truly alarming how much plastic, combined with inadequate recycling morale, is infesting our seas, our environment. Plastic pollution undoubtedly requires a global solution, given its cross-border nature. And it is undoubtedly necessary to take measures not only national, but also regional and international. I understand the objections of many critics that banning straws, beverage mixers or balloon sticks in the EU will not solve the problems on the other side of the globe. But it's important to really start doing something, because time is running out.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I also voted in favour of this report and consider it extremely important. In short, I say to all critics who think that there is nothing to be done to regulate the issue of plastic use, especially disposable plastics, to study the reports on the state of the environment, the state of the world's oceans and seas. We as responsible politicians are forced to try to do something about quantity, with the production of disposable plastics, especially when certain types of plastics can be replaced by other materials that are either natural in nature or much better recycled. I therefore supported this report, of course it will not solve the problem of plastic waste, but it is a clear first swallow, it sets out the direction we should take in the future. The European Union is founded on values, one of those values is the protection of the environment, which is why I think that we are obliged to accept this for future generations.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I was very pleased to vote in favour of this report. As the EPP negotiator for the Committee on Fisheries on single—use plastics, I am conscious of the wide-ranging effects of our excessive plastic production and pollution. We are creating unnecessary, harmful waste every day and an EU—wide approach to tackle this is long overdue.  We have to take advantage of the alternatives to single—use plastic. The EU should take leadership in this area and there is an economic opportunity available in producing innovative, reusable products. Studies show that up to 30 000 new local jobs could be created if the EU acts on this. Plastic pollution has a significant impact for citizens, marine life and the environment at large. In my own constituency, in Ireland South, the coast and seas surrounding the island of Ireland are our greatest resource and they need to be protected. I welcome the ambition to reduce the littering by more than half for the most common single—use plastics. The damage to the environment otherwise would be in the region of EUR 22 billion by 2030.  – Níl am le spáráil. Go raibh maith agat a Uachtaráin.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, plastics are among the biggest polluters in the world. The ways in which they are made, manufactured and used are not sustainable and efficient. In addition, products made partly from plastic are almost never recycled.  I voted for the ambitious proposal to reduce the use of single-use plastics because I believe we need to set ambitious targets for young Europeans and future generations to have a cleaner environment and waters.  Environmental protection is a shared responsibility in society. I believe that manufacturers should be invited to produce more easily degradable packaging material. It is not sustainable to increase the cost of waste collection at the expense of citizens or to rely on shares and activities only of volunteers. It is the responsibility of both the state authorities and the local authorities to inform their citizens that plastics carry many risks and dangers to human health after they fall into the soil, water and hence our food.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. Chairman, I have, of course, supported this proposal from the European Commission, because I consider it very good for the protection of our planet, above all our sea. I find it an excellent proposal for single use of plastics, but of course we need to find alternative ways of manufacturing to replace these products that we are talking about here.  I would never like Europe to become a symbol for banning baby balloons, releasing balloons, but at the same time I am sure that Europe must lead the way in this fight. It is impossible to know that three-quarters of the waste in the sea comes from plastic, and even worse is the second data: by 2050, if we continued at this rate, there would be more plastic in the sea than fish, which we cannot possibly allow.  This is especially important to me because I come from the Adriatic Sea, which we share together with your Italy and I am sure that we must protect it, that we must preserve it, and who else but us in the Union, and I hope that the Member States will follow this directive and will introduce all these measures that we propose today.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Reducing plastic is a challenge, but it is also a necessity for us. We're actually tone down the plastic garbage. This rubbish is everywhere. This action to reduce plastic is absolutely necessary and absolutely necessary. In Europe only, fifteen tonnes of plastic are thrown into the sea every year, and there is talk of eight million tonnes of litter being dumped into the oceans worldwide. Please note that 70% of all waste in the seas is plastic waste. Some single-use plastic products for which there are readily available and cheap replacements should simply be withdrawn from the market. We must pay attention to the fact that, however, preventive measures should also be taken to make people aware of the harmfulness of plastic. Of course, I am also very much in the process of reducing the number of plastic bottles that are consumed in millions as not billions of tonnes worldwide every day. I believe that this is the right direction, although I believe that the objectives unfortunately set out in a way that is too general and difficult to achieve raise doubts. So we should detail these objectives so that we can be effective.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, the debate on the European Asylum Support Office comes at a time when an OLAF investigation is under way into various former and current members of the European Asylum Support Office. The key word, then, is the word trust. It is necessary to restore trust with our citizens. It is necessary to be completely transparent. For this reason, it is urgent to have a clear action plan with regard to the recovery of irregular payments, with regard to the financing of operational support activities of the Office in reception and identification centres for irregular migrants and/or refugees in certain Member States, such as Greece. It is necessary to strictly observe all competition procedures with regard to Community public procurement legislation at the same time. It is necessary for citizens to believe again that the European Asylum Support Office manages their money with absolute credibility and transparency.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: As we have said, the explanations of vote scheduled for today will go until tomorrow.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 153a) on evaluation of the Lisbon Treaty (2018/2888(RSP)). I should like to inform Members that for this debate there is no catch-the-eye procedure and there will be no blue cards, so no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ten years have now passed since the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and it is therefore necessary to take stock of the current situation in the EU. Economic and social data do not lie and tell us that today we are worse off than we were ten years ago, with unemployment rising, wealth falling and the debt-to-GDP ratio amplified by more than twenty percentage points over ten years. This is the reality of the numbers, but beyond these clear macro-indicators is the reality of daily life, which shows that citizens are increasingly in difficulty and how much differences and mistrust between the countries of the Union are also exacerbated, resurrecting and reinforcing feelings of fear and mutual mistrust that we believed had long been buried. It is clear that the Treaty and the EU have failed in their objectives: there is no prosperity, there is no economic cohesion, there is no social or territorial cohesion, no much-vaunted solidarity between countries. It is not surprising, moreover, that one of the objectives enshrined in the Treaty is to have a highly competitive social and market economy. How has this principle been translated into practice? This has resulted in the sacrifice of young people, workers and pensioners to the preserve of leniate neoliberal policies. There have therefore been youth unemployment, wage cuts and pension cuts – the only recipes brussels has been able to impose on the Member States. Over the past ten years, the Treaty and the EU have not been able to give a concrete answer to the three major problems facing European citizens today: the enforcement economic crisis, the internal security crisis and border protection against illegal immigration. Not only has nothing been done, but European recipes have even made the situation worse. I wonder how the European Union can improve the situation if a democratically elected government cannot even establish its own economic measures but must always be blackmailed by one or other EU Commissioner, who, having failed at home, now wants to decide at home. I wonder what power Junker, Dombrovskis or Moscovici have in deciding the future and hopes of millions of young people, workers, pensioners and the unemployed in Italy and elsewhere. The arrogance with which you want to continue on a vision of a centralizing Union, with more and more powers and competences taken away from national governments, is leading Europe to collapse. Perhaps it is appropriate to get out of your head the mantra of 'more Europe' than 'there is no alternative', which for you is the solution to all the problems but which in reality was only the sublimation of an undemocratic system to the detriment of the freedoms of the citizens and peoples of Europe. I ask you if you have ever wondered why, when European citizens were allowed to give their opinion directly on EU-related issues, the outcome was often quite different from what you expected. The latest Eurobarometer says that less than half of Italians see benefits in the EU but 60 % support this government that you oppose. What do you want to do? Respect democracy and the freedoms of peoples or take them away from them once and for all?  For you, the hands of history are now inexorable. Those who supported this failed idea of Europe will be wiped out by the popular vote. For many years in these classrooms you have ostracized, mocked, mutilated us. We're going to get our revenge in May. The political shock that will erase you will allow Europe, the real one, to rise from the abyss in which your unholy choices have brought it.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for inviting the Presidency to your monthly topical debate.  The Council has not yet discussed the evaluation of the Lisbon Treaty as such. The Council implements the Treaty with a view to achieving results. We believe our focus should be on delivering results for our citizens, in particular, right until the end of the present term. Be assured that the Austrian Presidency will be focused on this. On this I would simply note that the ordinary legislative procedure, which is now generalised after Lisbon, works well – and I would like to thank the European Parliament for the good cooperation – and that the relations between the Council and Parliament on the whole have indeed improved.  Beyond this, there is certainly a debate about the evaluation of the Treaty and, more generally, about the future of the Union. We appreciate that Parliament has been working on several reports on certain aspects of the Treaty. I am sure that in today’s debate a variety of views will be expressed, based on respective political perspectives.  That said, I will listen to your debate attentively. Thank you for this opportunity.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of The Commission. – Mr President, frankly, I prepared for a debate about the Lisbon Treaty. I was waiting for Mr Zanni to go onto the Lisbon Treaty. He went onto many things, very interestingly, but not onto the Lisbon Treaty. I will stick to my brief anyway.  The Treaty is a reflection of what Member States collectively want and require from the EU. They have come together and pooled sovereignty because they see there are challenges that no one Member State can address acting alone. As Jean-Claude Juncker said in the State of the Union address this year, and I quote: ‘European sovereignty is born of Member States’ national sovereignty and does not replace it. Sharing sovereignty – when and where needed – makes each of our nation states stronger.’ End of quote.  Too often the discussion on sovereignty is a pretext for the question of how we can stop things, but the real question we should ask is: how can we act effectively and legitimately in the face of challenges or crises? I also want to react to some of the things Mr Zanni said. There is no imposition. Every single Member State has signed and ratified the Treaty. You can’t afterwards say, ‘I’ve signed and ratified, but I will not apply the Treaty’. We are based on the rule of law and that means that this Union can only function if we can accept that those who sign and ratify the Treaty also apply the Treaty. If we have a problem with that, the Commission can intervene and at the end of the day, it’s the Court of Justice that will rule on this. That is the essence of how we constructed the European Union after the Second World War. Creating the impression that this is an imposition from outside is, I think, fooling your own people and it is irresponsible. It can create a certain feeling of ‘we’re being dictated to from outside’, but it is not a reflection of reality, and it is also hiding away your own responsibility. You have a responsibility vis-à-vis your colleagues in the Council, vis-à-vis the European Parliament, vis-à-vis the Commission, but you certainly have a responsibility vis-à-vis your own signature, your own ratification, and I think we should be talking about that more.  I also believe that if you look at the number of Treaty changes we have seen over the years, you see that, given the complexity of the challenges and the complexity of working together and having to tackle issues no Member State can tackle on its own, the need for decision through qualified majority voting (QMV) has increased. I hope we can use the coming time to look into areas where QMV can be increased, especially in foreign policy. If you have to take decisions on international human rights, or if you have to take decisions on commercial issues, I think QMV could be a helpful instrument. Again, and I come from a country where the temptation of thinking that the veto was the best thing you had has sort of waned. People understand that a veto can only give you the instrument to stop something temporarily, but it doesn’t give you the opportunity to act, to actually do something proactively, and so I think the discussion of QMV will have to move forward.  On issues such as taxation, there is no way we can muster enough strength against the huge corporations that can negotiate tax deals with individual Member States that de facto mean they don’t pay any taxes if we don’t do this at the European level. We need to do this at the European level, and for that I think QMV would be important as well. I also want to mention briefly the task force on subsidiarity and proportionality that Jean-Claude Juncker created last year. Yesterday in the Commission work programme, we set out in broad terms how we believe the task force needs to respond to the questions that were put on the table by Member States, by national parliaments and by other stakeholders such as regional and local authorities. We will prepare this for the Bregenz conference that will take place soon. The core of the issue is that we need to make sure that all those who in the end have to work with legislation are also involved in preparing the legislation, helping us to evaluate the legislation, to make sure that we avoid duplication, to make sure that we avoid unnecessary complexity. It is now also my experience that the issue is not, in general, should competences be returned from the EU level to Member States? We've challenged everyone to give us some examples, and the examples are few and far between, but not really very concrete.  The real issue we need to tackle is: how do we legislate? How do we do this? Can we not do this in a way that is less complex, that will help local and regional authorities to have ownership of these processes? Where can we evaluate existing legislation to make sure that we take out what is no longer necessary etc.? We should get out of this logic that the only thing we could do is do less. We need to do things Europe needs to do, and we need to stop doing things that are nice to do. We only need to do what we need to do. I believe that if we start from that premise, we will understand that there is a tremendous amount we still need to do, and I couldn’t end my intervention without referring to the momentous decision this Parliament took today to embrace the plastic strategy. It is now up to the Council to do something that a vast majority of Europeans want us to do, and they want us to do it now.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I will speak on the Lisbon Treaty as well. I believe that it has brought immense progress to the functioning of the EU in terms of efficiency, democracy and also transparency. But it maintained and enhanced the system of intergovernmental policy coordination, which was very different from the Community method, and for many of us this has been a disappointment. As a result, important policy decisions and actions are based on the voluntary commitment of Member States, with all its consequences. We saw during the time of ‘polycrisis’ that this working method does not work when key challenges are at stake.  The Committee on Constitutional Affairs has proposed – and the whole House accepted when voting through a series of reports last year – the logic to first explore fully the potential of the Lisbon Treaty and only then to reflect on the changes to the Treaty that would be necessary to attain desiderata the boundaries of the Treaty of Lisbon do not allow to be pursued. But we all know that today unanimity makes Treaty revision virtually impossible. There is a long list of issues on which the Union has moved forward, building on the unexploited treaty potential – PESCO is a recent example here – but the list regarding unused Treaty potential remains even longer: the passerelle clause that has never been used; the European Parliament’s right of inquiry and its right of legislative initiative; reinforcement of the rule of law framework; transparency of Council legislative decision—making; and accession to the ECHR.  Without doubt, within the Lisbon Treaty framework, we can move forward on completing reforms of the EMU. All we need is the political will. In this House we have called for the use of QMV in the Council, but also for the general use of the ordinary legislative procedure. Eventually all decisions, including on the MFF, should be taken by QMV, even if a very high one in some particular cases.  So yes, indeed, we can clearly use the existing unexploited potential of the Lisbon Treaty to improve the governance of the Union and its institutional set—up. I believe that this will make the Treaty of Lisbon more relevant to the challenges that our policy—making will face in the years to come.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I too thought Mr Zanni had turned up for the wrong debate, but then he moved very quickly onto the old clichés about the European Union becoming some sort of centralised superstate. We hear a lot about false news these days, but really, this is a false narrative. Just look at the facts: this Union, its central administration, the Commission, has fewer employees than the city of Leeds in my constituency. Its budget is scarcely 2% of public spending – 98% is national. No legislation can be adopted without the approval of both this elected Parliament and national ministers – members of national governments, accountable to national parliaments – meeting in the Council. It’s not actually possible for this Union to act in areas that the Member States don’t want it to act in. It’s in those areas where we need joint action.  I was Parliament’s rapporteur on the Lisbon Treaty. It was a series of reforms to make the Union work better and to improve its accountability, a series of reforms that needed the grand slam of ratification by every single Member State to get through, so again, a very high level of consensus about it. What did it do? Firstly, it made our Union work better. As Mr Timmermans has mentioned already, more majority voting, fewer vetoes, but a qualified majority still needs a very high threshold in the Council. It has allowed the European Council to choose who chairs its meetings, instead of having a Buggins’ turn rotation with a new President every second meeting. It allowed us to have one external representative – the High Representative – instead of two as we used to. It rationalised our work, but it also made the Union more accountable. Prior scrutiny by national parliaments – every legislative proposal goes to them first. They have an eight-week period to look at it before we begin on it.  Election of the President of the Commission by this Parliament; the Council to meet in public when adopting legislation; the whole budget subject, and others which I can’t list because of lack of time; many other democratic improvements.  This narrative is false.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: for the ECR Group. – The European Union's fundamental problem is non-compliance with rules and agreements. Schengen, Dublin, Maastricht, Lisbon – virtually every single treaty has been significantly violated by someone. I recall Article 125 of the Treaty of Lisbon, according to which each country guarantees its own obligations; In the meantime, Article 123 of the Treaty of Lisbon, according to which the European Central Bank must not buy public debt, has done so for an unimaginable EUR 2500 billion. When not complying with the rules, the European Commission's popular solution is to invent new rules for which it does not equally want to comply with them. Overall, the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact have been violated more than 150 times. 150 times, and Mr Juncker and his predecessor, Mr Barosso, have not joined the sanctions for a single time. Conversely, when Mr Juncker was asked two years ago why France might not abide by these rules, he replied: "Because it is France." That's coming back to him like a boomerang now. From Italy came the draft budget, which is a pure provocation for the other Member States, along with the comment that no one takes Mr Juncker seriously anymore. Of course, Italy's behaviour makes a promise to all the other Member States, so I appeal, first of all, to the rules before inventing new ones.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, the Treaty of Lisbon is rightly regarded as a turning point in European integration. Mainly because it enabled the EU to function after the historic enlargement of the former Eastern Bloc in 2004. It has also enabled new forms of merger of Member States, including enhanced defence cooperation. Today, almost 10 years after its real effectiveness, however, we need to set up a mirror. Have we really brought the Union closer to its citizens? Are we more actionable? Are we ing more national parliaments involved in decision-making? Do we really strictly follow the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality? To me personally, this is the only conclusion – Europe, which has now been through several crisis moments, needs reflection. We cannot continue as if nothing were going on, we would be putting the whole European project at risk. I would very much hate for brexit to be the only real result of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We need Europe. But if we want to preserve Europe, we urgently need to reform it, we must make it more democratic. Parliament must finally be given the rights that a Parliament has in a genuine democracy, e.B. a right to apply for new laws, e.B. the possibility of taking decisions in foreign and security policy. After all, in a democracy, Parliament should be the highest body.  The Commission must become an elected government, and the European Court of Justice must confine itself to guaranteeing compliance with the existing treaties. It must be governed by existing laws and must not change or develop the laws. This lack of understanding of democracy has been one of several reasons for Brexit, and many convinced Europeans also desperately want reforms in the EU. We need Europe, but we need a democratic Europe.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: on the efdd group. – Mr President, the Treaty of Lisbon does not set a balance of power, mutual control of institutions, which we otherwise normally use at the level of associations, state institutes and international organisations. Let us start with the Commission: pursuant to Article 17(1) of the Basic Regulation, it is not the first time that the commission has been not in a good place. It is therefore the first time that the Commission has been in a state of interest. Note, in the whole Treaty of Lisbon, it is not said that the Union should serve the people, it serves itself. We can prove it with other quotes. Article 17 of Regulation No 1260/1999 shall apply to the following: 3 says that "members of the Commission are selected in such a way as to be completely independent". Completely independent of the citizens of the Member States, of normal people. It explicitly states: "The Commission carries out its functions in complete independence. Members of the Commission shall neither request nor take instructions from any government, body, body, office or agency.". This means that the Commission is completely cut off from the people. A political system that disregards people's interests is considered an authoritarian system. Some argue that, after all, the Member States decide what the Commission is allowed to do.  Council: in the Treaty of Lisbon, Article 4 of the Treaty of Lisbon, the European Parliament and the Council adopted a directive on the implementation of the Lisbon Treaty. 3 states: "Member States shall facilitate the performance of their tasks and shall refrain from any action which might jeopardise the achievement of the Union's objectives." So states must not promote their own interests and those of their citizens in the Union. At this point, I will quote the President of the European Commission, Mr Juncker. Ing to the Prime Minister's Assembly, he said, "Stop listening to your constituents." We can go on like this, we could prove that the Treaty of Lisbon is a totalitarian system similar to those in communist countries.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, first of all, the Lisbon Treaty is tainted from the outset by a violation of the sovereignty of the peoples, since its twin brother the draft European constitution has been rejected by several peoples, including that of France, the Netherlands and Ireland.  In spite of this, a treaty is being applied that codifies ultra-liberal economic and social policies, and competition for all against all is the guide to all choices, even if it means deepening social, territorial, unemployment, precariousness and poverty. National budgets are put on a diet, but that is not why we reduce debts. The urgency, therefore, today, is to re-found this European construction by involving the peoples for a new social treaty, democratic and ecological to face the enormous challenges before us: to build Europe of work, to combat tax evasion, to tax behemoths that do not participate in the common good in the European Union, to defend and create new public services, to use the monetary creation of the central bank for human development and environmental transition, to be an actor in the global cooperation of disarmament and peace.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, in June 2005 I voted against the Dutch referendum on the European Constitution, now known as the Lisbon Treaty. And with me, the vast majority of Dutch people were against it. I was a civil servant at the Home Office at the time and my fellow civil servants had a lack of understanding. Why did the population not like the expansion of power in Brussels? The House of Representatives decided that the people were too stupid to have an informed opinion and the major parties, including Commissioner Timmermans, ignored the outcome.  The Netherlands joined the Lisbon Treaty in a single vote. That was illegal, because contrary to the Dutch constitution, but yes, everything for the Good Cause, right? A decade later, the population appears to have been visionary. The EU has pulled everything towards it. The Netherlands is not about anything anymore. No more about border security, no more about migration, not about his own government budget, not about free political discussions on the Internet. I would say that – certainly with the latter – the European Union is starting to get pull from the Soviet Union, but yes, my lawyer told me that insulting the Union is a criminal offence. Inconceivable. So you cannot vote against the Treaty, but you can insult it. You wonder: will you be condemned by the European Court, that other tentacle of the European octopus? Did I say "visionary"? Fortunately, the Treaty appears to have had its longest time. Britain is done with it. Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Italy, all of them are fighting with the European Commission. And next to that, Romania, Bulgaria. Spain does not, despite the bludgeoning of Catalan voters. Fighting the voter's opinion is okay. In Spain, but also in the Netherlands. In that respect, not much has changed in the last decade.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the Treaty of Lisbon is not entitled as a Constitution, but is covertly a never-before-seen Constitution and the European institutions treat it as such. With the adopted policies and the solomon, creative interpretations of the Treaty, the existing form of the Union is incompatible with the theoretically intended objective. We do not have a Union of democracy and security, but an institutional enforcement and attack on national authorities through controlled procedures where EU law takes precedence over national law. The Treaty was used to lose the national identity of the Member States and their sovereign rights. It has contributed to the intimidation of Europe and will contribute to the legislative decline if it is not amended. An immediate revision of the Treaty and a cessation of the expansion of the competences assumed by the Union are needed. Repatriation of powers to national capitals, respect for the decisions of the democratically elected governments of the Member States, recognition that the Union, as it operates, is not a European Union and will not be.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The European Union has become democratic with Lisbon. All the institutions are democratically legitimised – through the election of the citizen, the election of this House or the election of national parliaments on the Council side. This also applies in particular to the Commission; There is nothing to interpret. In some areas, we have more rights on these issues than some national parliaments, and that should not be discussed away. It serves people, it benefits, it creates jobs, it avoids crises, it helps to deal with problems. We have overcome the 2008 financial crisis and no one has gone bankrupt – with solidarity. We need to improve the instruments. To do this, we need greater decision-making and more codecision skills. That is why the Passerelle must be used. That is why the Council must also act here. I consider that the Council's behaviour today is contrary to the Treaty. Even in those areas where majority voting is foreseen, the principle of consensus is agreed and majority voting is not used. I consider this to be contrary to the Treaty. The time will come when we must complain that the Treaty is not being used to bring about the capacity to act – the capacity for action that we need so that we can solve today's problems – with migration, internal and external security, climate change and many other issues – to the better situation of our citizens. Citizens expect Europe to be more capable of acting. That is the main reason for the criticism of Europe today that we are not delivering. To achieve this, we need improved decision-making structures that are possible in the Treaty of Lisbon. I believe that we should make greater use of this in an increased way. I believe that when it is said here 'do not serve man', it means that the Commission is independent of instructions, lobbyists and others, that is meant, not the stalact that you, Mr Pagne, have told the present. And this European Union serves the people – the first sentence of the Charter of Fundamental Rights is: 'Human dignity is inviolable'. But you have never appreciated this dignity of man with your political clique.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, I also know the Lisbon Treaty quite well because I was part of the team of the Portuguese Presidency in charge of completing the negotiation of this Treaty in Lisbon back in 2007.  Let me make a clear point. The problem we have is not with the Lisbon Treaty. The problem we have is with the kind of policies we need to implement in order to deliver better European solutions. Let’s be fair: when we focus on the Treaty, the Treaty has involved important progress when it comes to democracy. First of all, the fact that this Parliament has extended co—decision in many, many new areas. This is really deepening European democracy. Second, the Lisbon Treaty could pool sovereignty where this is needed: when we address climate change; when we negotiate trade agreements; when we affirm our monetary sovereignty. In all these areas we need stronger European sovereignty. This does not go against national sovereignty. This is to strengthen our control of the situation.  I am now addressing the part of Parliament and those Members of the European Parliament who are taking a position against the European Union and the treaties of the European Union. You are wrong. This is not the problem, and the solution is not to withdraw from the treaties. The solution is to change policies in favour of more economic and social convergence and more tax fairness. That’s for sure. So this is the way to go.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Well, it is that we are trying to talk about the Treaty of Lisbon from practically two extreme positions. Some say: the Treaty of Lisbon is great, cacy, we are going further; others say that it is hopeless and should be tossed and thrown in the trash. I don't think so.  The problem with the European Union today is that the Treaty of Lisbon is often not respected, and I have the impression that real power in the Union is quite like the laws of the Treaty of Lisbon, that, in fact, today the two main states in the European Union have the main position in European policy-making, and this is by no means somehow rooted in the Treaty of Lisbon.  Of course, this treaty needs to be improved, because the powers between the Head of the European Commission and the President of the Council have not been clarified. We remember in this Parliament the war between Mr Barroso and the Then President of the Council and the fact that they were sometimes not here because they boycotted each other. This needs to change.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in times of evaluation of the Treaty of Lisbon, a conclusion that stands out: we are a long way from the promises and hopes it embodied. Quoting a poet Portuguese, the European Union must be fulfilled.  If integration has advanced with the single market and its political configuration in the economy as well, albeit with hesitations and contradictions, in the fields of justice and the courts, which are the other pole of the democratic binomial rule of law, nothing has been relevant.  Justice, especially criminal justice, is too important a value in the process of European integration and cohesion to be left to the exclusive care of the Member States. A state will only be the rule of law if it is a democratic state and will only be democratic if it is also the rule of law.  It is therefore urgent that Eurojust be transformed into a Union Public Prosecutor's Office, the establishment of a European court with exclusive jurisdiction to adjudicate a catalogue of cross-border crimes in the European Union.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, it is a pain for us when we talk about the Lisbon Treaty because this treaty is first and foremost a violence, a violence against democracy, since it sat on the 'no' vote in the French referendum. This treaty is also the questioning of the budgetary sovereignty of states, it is the preference for absurd rules - think of Berlin, rather than the happiness of the people -; it is the submission to ordoliberalism that closes the door, throughout Europe, to social progress. And in its practice this treaty will have organised the questioning of public services, the capture of the commons, it will have organized endless austerity and taken care to make the European Union a paradise for lobbies and for tax evaders. Jean-Claude Juncker said there can be no democratic choice against treaties. For my part, I say that there can be no democracy and no progress in these European treaties.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, it is very interesting to listen to this debate, because there are views, attempts to repeal the Treaty of Lisbon only after trying to significantly strengthen the federal character of Europe and amend it. As a political realist, I think that the treaty is working in principle, and I think that there is not much political will for some significant and significant change at the moment. This means, for my part, "Let us work with the current text of the Treaty of Lisbon." In my opinion, considering major changes is politically unrealistic at the moment, but let us try to make better use of things that may not have been fully exploited and are contained in the Treaty. For example, the consultative role of national parliaments in adopting new legislation. This is an area where we have large gaps and where the treaty could be better used in the future. Of course, I see things there that I think are not very good – strengthening the qualified majority. The 2015 vote, the quotas, turned out to be a political mistake. But these are small things that do not need to be changed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Zanni, do not fear: we Europeans, we pro-Europeans, also take up the challenge of the forthcoming European elections. There will be no anti-European majority in this Parliament. Of course, we too want to change the Treaty of Lisbon, but for the better. We need to give sovereignty to the European Union in areas where states are no longer able to manage it on their own and there are many of them, from the currency, to economic policy and the social policy framework, to justice, defence and foreign policy, to security, to which you care a great deal, and then the single market, of course, the environment, protection against globalisation. In all these areas, we believe that the Treaty of Lisbon allows us to move forward, to move forward by fully applying it, but we also believe that changes to the Treaties are possible and necessary. Many people have dealt with the subject of democracy. In order to make democracy work properly in Europe, we need to have full codecision. Here I am addressing the Council: democracy is majority voting, it is the ability to take decisions and to move forward, not to be blocked by unanimous voting. It is also, of course, that of the European Parliament's legislative initiative, it is that of a better relationship with the national parliaments, which must monitor the application of European rules by their governments. It is also certainly to achieve a genuine codecision process through the use of the bridging clause or the amendments to the Treaties. I therefore believe that the time has come, ten years later, to reflect, but to think seriously, about what the Union's own competences are and what competences should remain with the Member States, including by returning what it might have bordered on. We are sure that the pro-Europeans will win at the next elections and, as I said, we will take the challenge, we will take it forward and we will win it.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Romans said: Pacta sunt servanda - treaties must be respected. You, Commissioner, are holding the rule of law like a glorriole; you always refer to it. But when it comes down to it in the European Union, the Treaty is not being respected. In monetary policy, the no-bail-out clause has been wiped off the table. Madame Lagarde said: we had to break the treaties in order to save the euro. Monetary union does not act under the rule of law, but is opportunistic. What do we have to do to save the euro?  If you look at the policy of Mr Draghi, who is also violating Article 123 by buying government bonds via detours, we know all that. But this is not monetary policy. This is an attempt to keep the eurozone together by the wrong means, and you see that time and again.  This morning you spoke of the european Union facing major crises. Yes, we are in the process of producing these crises through this policy. Mr Timmermans, stick to the rule of law!

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I must honestly say that I have heard a lot of absurd and abstruse things today. It almost seems to me that the Treaties of the European Union have been made by some Martian people and imposed on the governments of the Member States. The opposite is true. It is the governments that have made these treaties as they are today. At that time, we in Parliament had very different ideas as to how we could do this. Therefore, the real problem in the European Union is not our Treaties; these are these populists who want to bring division into society, these are those governments that are unwilling to finally shape a policy in the sense of the European Union, and who are thinking only of themselves, not of their citizens, but really only of themselves and not of the progress of the European Union. It is time for the sense of responsibility of all politicians to be awakened and for them to reunite this society and not always divide it with slogans that are empty, divide them, so that in the end we have no possibility of a future. We need to change our policy.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – I am very pleased for this debate today. In my opinion, we must ask whether the Treaty of Lisbon is indeed a Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or practically almost a Constitution, but which has not been validly approved by the citizens of the Union. We can all see that the intention of an ever closer Union, more and more of the Union – that this idea has cracks.  That is why we in the European Christian Political Movement, which is a party in the European Parliament, consider it crucial to amend the Treaty of Lisbon with redefixion into a strong Confederate structure and the place of the federation. We believe that we need to reform the European Union so that it returns to its Jewish-Christian roots by focusing on basic and primary tasks. We want no more Europe, but a better Europe. Principles such as subsidiarity, solidarity and diversity should be interwoven with values such as freedom, stewardship, responsibility and human dignity. But above all, I want to stress, let us finally give a place to God in our legislation and name it as the supreme authority of our European Community, because it will establish absolute values of good and evil.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to remind those Members who have promoted this debate that on several occasions in this House and in the committees we have questioned the meaning of the Treaty, the possibility of using it to the full for the potential it has, how to change it – I am thinking of the Brok, Bresso and Verhofstadt reports: I am sure that you have made a very great contribution to this work. , because it is not in the space of a debate, but in this constructive work that you make your contribution. I don't think I've seen any signs of your presence in that job. That is why I think that today's debate is entirely instrumental. Ladies and gentlemen, you will have learned what the game is for populists, anti-Europeans or Eurosceptics, from time to time: it is to always indicate a new target, today the target is the Treaty, yesterday it was the Commission, tomorrow it will be the euro, the day after tomorrow Moscovici or Juncker or the ECB, in which yesterday we would have had the opportunity to include an Italian name, about our country. So I think that this is the instrumentality of a debate, we want to show that in Europe, with the Treaty of Lisbon, there is no democracy, there is no prosperity, there is no sovereignty in foreign policy. I, on the other hand, think that there is, because I do not want a Europe of Putin and Trump, I want a sovereign Europe on behalf of all its peoples in foreign policy. So I think that this debate has a limit, which I want to unveil here, which is an attempt, we will see in the next few days, it is Europe... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the Lisbon Treaty is unadjusted by the political reality of the European Union. We know how it came about and that it is a minimally corrected European constitution rejected by the peoples of Europe.  As such, the Treaty is practically a framework for a European federation that does not exist and has created a legal-political vacuum in which the Union institutions clash with each other for power and influence. This is felt before every election, but also after, when the Commission is drawn up and its priorities are agreed. Competition for power among the EU institutions paralyzes the Union for a moment. That can't be good.  We need a clear framework, simpler and more efficient, but to agree on it, we must first agree on the direction of the European Union. As many in this house are also advocating further political integration and, consequently, the European federation, and there are more and more of us who are resolutely resisting this, I doubt we will reach a consensus soon.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, I am convinced of one thing: nationalists threaten European integration. Their lies, the politics of the worst they lead, their hold on society, mean that more and more Europeans are losing confidence.  They corrode our minds, fragment our societies. Their lies and spurious arguments produce nothing but fear, hatred and violence. So what to do, my dear colleagues? To defeat them, we must first expose them to light, like vampires, show their true face. In the French Socialist delegation we are scrutinizing their vote: strengthening gun control to fight terrorism, they are voting against; social protection for truck drivers, the principle of 'equal work, equal pay', they vote against; measures for equality between women and men, they vote against; all measures to combat pollution, including plastic today, they vote against; strengthening the borders of the European Union, they are voting against, ladies and gentlemen! They claim to protect, they destroy. This is their real face, look at them every vote and you will see that the far right leads to the ruin of Europeans. Another future is possible, I am not talking about liberalism, but a third way, that of social progress, humanism, solidarity and it is embodied by the socialists.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Treaty of Lisbon has its prehistory. This prehistory is the rejection of the Constitution for Europe by the French, by the Dutch, the compatriots of President Timmermans. The history of the Treaty of Lisbon is, and it is, above all, Richard Corbett, that Gordon Brown has unfortunately resigned, as has the leaders of other European countries, to hold a referendum. If there had been a British referendum then we would not have Brexit today. But this treaty is a valid law. Unfortunately, this right is not treated as a right by those who are supposed to exercise it. We have heard President Timmermans today: a qualified majority would be useful, we hear Mrs Sophia in 't Veld working on a mechanism for monitoring democracy, we hear that Article 7 is insufficient. Ladies and gentlemen, in the classic concept of the rule of law, power is content with the powers it has, not thinking about how to enlarge it. Law is a way of regulating, in the case of treaties, relations between states, and not a tool for increasing one's power.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, as a member of the Convention on a European Constitution, held 16 years ago, I well understand how the Lisbon Treaty was shaped to carry over the main conclusions of that failed constitution. Yet it had been intended to transform the EU from a top—down construct to one that directly related and responded to the concerns of European citizens.  The Lisbon Treaty aimed to strengthen the bottom—up dimension of the Union and make citizens feel it was really theirs, so the functions and powers of the European Parliament were increased. Today, the members of this parliament, mindful of their increased powers, try to make them stronger. Members of this parliament diligently work on new proposals and laws intended to promote the welfare of all citizens. Still, EU institutions, this parliament included, are even now seen by citizens as top—down arrangements.  Many in this parliament fear, as we have just heard, that in the next European elections abstentions will be numerous and so—called populist extremist parties will achieve a record success. We need a radical evaluation of how this state of affairs has developed – one that does not rely on the repetition of exhausted pro—European creeds and dogmas.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
