text: –Mr President, it must be remembered that the Treaty of Lisbon, adopted during the Portuguese Presidency of 2007, was an important step in the construction of Europe, which overcame several years of institutional deadlock, made it possible to enhance European citizenship and fundamental rights, strengthen the European Parliament and democracy and simplify the decision-making processes of our institutions. I had the honour of participating in the European Council which approved the Treaty of Lisbon and in the signing ceremony that took place at the Jerónimos Monastery. All the problems have not been solved, but I also know how difficult it was to reach that political agreement. Therefore, ten years later, more than a complicated new process of treaty reform, what we need is to harness all the unteus of the Lisbon Treaty to improve the functioning of our institutions and strengthen the European project. The Treaty of Lisbon is not the problem, it remains part of the solution.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, I would like to remind you that the Lisbon Treaty was a clever solution to the failure of the Constitution, but I would like to remind my colleagues that the Treaty has been ratified by the European people, because many countries had already approved it — the European Constitution itself. In this regard, I would like to remind you that the Lisbon Treaty itself represents a solution to what has been a perfect storm of the European Union. Europe has been through a perfect storm in recent years, and the Lisbon Treaty has served to navigate these turbulent waters of economic crisis, migration crisis, terrorism, etc. What's more, it's served and served. What's more, it has a journey, because you still have to delve into it. And, what's more, it has to be changed in some things that experience is showing us that it claims changes. For those of us who believe in Europe, for those of us who want Europe, for whom we feel European, it is a perfect instrument that we want to preserve.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – The Treaty of Lisbon was born at a time when the Member States of the European Union agreed on essentially everything on the principles. The first Vice-President referred to the fact that this was accepted and ratified by the governments without exception. Today, however, we are living in a different time, today there are Member States, national governments, which are fuelling illiberalism and populism instead of common European values, and they say that European values and traditions are no longer important to us, the West is declining and is fuelling similar nonsense, spreading the growing anti-Europeanism, anti-European Unionism. I think that it is absurd that the Prime Ministers of the Member States in the Council are constantly able to block decisions and bills that would be important for the whole of Europe because of their own self-interest. I think that if we are serious about rethinking the Treaty of Lisbon, then this is where we need to start working. We must make it clear that Europe only has a chance if we seek greater cooperation, as much cooperation as possible in as many areas as possible, and a clear rejection of populism and illiberalism.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I already said this morning that the origins of European integration is the wish of the European people to negotiate their differences around the conference table rather than on the battlefield.  But if you look at Europe today, the challenges we face are global challenges and the one question you can ask your citizens – and I am sure of the answer you’ll get – is, do you honestly think you can face the migration challenge on your own as a Member State? Do you honestly think nationalism is an answer to the challenges of economic change in the fourth industrial revolution? Do you honestly believe that being on your own will make you stronger in facing the challenges of President Putin or the challenges of a President Trump, who wants to change the international system? Do we honestly believe we will be stronger on our own? I don’t think there is a constituency anywhere in a Member State that truly believes that, and I’m afraid the British people today are learning this the hard way. I believe that if we take that as a starting point, the way we transform our rules, the way we apply the Treaty to face these challenges and to come up with real results for our citizens, is going to determine whether we’ll get support for this. I think debates about abstract notions such as sovereignty are distracting people or they are causing alarm.  I do maintain that you can have a theoretical approach to sovereignty and to saying I want national sovereignty. Theoretically, technically, yes, national sovereignty, but I think it was Michael Heseltine who said that ‘a man alone in the desert is sovereign [too]’. He dies of thirst but he’s sovereign. Sovereignty should also be a material issue. Does it give you the power to act and to change things the way your citizens want things changed? Then the answer will be very clear: only if we act collectively can we shape the world according to the values we share in a world that is changing so fast. I wish that could be the starting point of our discussion about what we need in a treaty.  There are still ample opportunities in the existing Lisbon Treaty to move ahead. Let’s try and use those opportunities first, and if they are exhausted we can talk about treaty change. But we haven’t exhausted the possibilities that are on the table with the existing Lisbon Treaty. Let’s do a great service to our citizens and use those opportunities to actually change the world in the direction they want.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I regret that not all of us have utilised the time for evaluation of the Lisbon Treaty, which was the topic of this topical debate, but of course there is freedom to approach it in one’s own way. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - The European Union is based on the idea that decisions are taken at the level of as close as possible to the citizens themselves, and which also respects the national sovereignty of its Member States. The boundaries of the Union's competences are determined by the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. Everything that can be achieved at the central level of a national state, its regional or local level, should be accomplished there, as required by the treaties, and the institutions of the European Union must ensure that this is respected.  Unfortunately, we have recently witnessed numerous examples of fundamental principles being violated, the competence of the Union's actions exceeded and state sovereignty being violated. In addition to requesting the activation of Article 7 against some Member States without valid arguments, Parliament has in many of its resolutions and reports indusled areas which are the exclusive competence of the Member States – such as the health or education system.  Such conduct calls into question the union's survival as it violates the treaty and does not respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – The signing of the Lisbon Treaty took place at a time when members of national minorities in Central and Eastern European countries were still experiencing the positive effect pre-accession had on the respect for their rights. These citizens were also extremely enthusiastic about the prospect of the EU internalising the principles of the pre-accession when, for the first time in the history of the Union, the Lisbon treaty introduced national minorities as a protected ground in Article 21 of the Charter and also mentioned the respect for the rights of minorities among its founding values. The years that passed since then gave way to disillusionment in the heart of many citizens, as the EU not only restrained from adopting legal acts for their protection, but it also failed to sanction Member States when they started curtailing their already acquired rights. At a time when definite failures are daily experienced in the compliance with the founding values of our Union, it is time this glaring omission in the EU legal framework was set right. This is what more than 1 million citizens also requested using the novel ECI instrument of the same Lisbon Treaty.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Court of Auditors’ annual report – 2017 (2018/2760(RSP)).

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the Court of Auditors. Mr President, Madam President, rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Oettinger, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and the rapporteur, Commissioner Oettinger, for the work she has done on this report. As a former Member of this House, I know all too well that the European Parliament is currently in a very labour-intensive phase. Parliament is currently working at full speed to launch a large number of other pieces of legislation before the elections. I would all the more like to thank you, as President of the European Court of Auditors, for the time you have taken here in plenary for the debate on our annual report. We have presented our annual report to give you our assessment of the state of financial management of the European Union in 2017. This means that the discharge procedure is now formally initiated, the last in this parliamentary term. For 2017, as in previous years, we conclude that the EU's annual accounts give a true and fair view of the financial situation of the European Union. As last year, we are giving a limited and not a failed opinion on the regularity of the payments underlying the 2017 financial statements. In other words, a significant proportion of the 2017 expenditure we are looking at does not have a significant error rate. I am referring to expenditure based on payment entitlements, i.e. expenditure on programmes where beneficiaries receive payments if they meet certain conditions. These claims-based payments accounted for more than half of all payments from the EU budget in 2017. In addition, irregularities in EU expenditure have also continued to fall. The estimated error rate for payments in 2017 was 2.4%, down from 3.1% in 2016 and 3.8% in 2015. This shows that the Financial Management of the European Union is clearly moving in the right direction, thanks – and I should like to make this quite clear here – to the continuing joint efforts of the Commission, the European Parliament, the Member States, but also the Court of Auditors. Let me give a positive example of direct payments under the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which accounts for a very large part of the relevant MFF heading. For these direct payments, we concluded that they no longer have a significant error rate.  At this point, however, I would also like to point out that there is often enough information available to prevent, detect and correct a significant proportion of the errors we have detected. If this information had been used by the Commission or the national authorities, an even larger part of the European budget would have recorded an error rate below the materiality threshold of the Court and the Commission. In short, what we discovered could have been discovered by others. Ladies and gentlemen! Now is the time to go one step further. The management and control systems have improved – for us, as the Court of Auditors, this is now an opportunity to make these improvements available for our audits.  For 2017, we have tested a different approach in the area of cohesion. The most important change was that we reviewed and tracked inspections and inspections previously carried out by the expenditure authorities. With this new approach, we, as MEPs, want to provide you, as MEPs, with better geographical and fund-specific insights for the whole of the European Union in a cost-effective way. In the coming years, we will also extend this approach to other areas of expenditure, provided – and I stress this explicitly – the necessary conditions are met, i.e. the data available to us also have sufficient reliability.  Mr. President! I have read with great interest the survey results of the Parlameter 2018 that you have recently published. Certainly, I am optimistic about the future to see that membership of the EU and the euro has strong support – among the majority of the citizens of the European Union. At the same time, however, there are also large discrepancies in support – depending on the country. Both annual budgets and the Union's long-term budgeting are distribution instruments. Decisions in this regard often involve political complications for those Member States which, in their opinion, have 'gone badly away'. Whatever political decisions, it is important for us at the Court of Auditors to ensure that the the citizens of the Union – whether in Bucharest, Helsinki, Lisbon, Berlin or Paris – can get their own picture of this and can therefore be confident that EU funds have been used not only properly, but also sensibly. We call this process "performance audit" or performance audit, and I can assure you that you will see an increasing number of these exams in the coming months and years. This is a direction that has been consistently pointed to by the Court in the many discussions that I have had in this House, but also in many national capitals, and I think that is a very important task. Ladies and gentlemen! The Court has shown that various Member States are having difficulties in using the European Structural and Investment Funds in a good and timely manner. In this respect, it is to be welcomed that the Commission has proposed a series of measures for the next financial framework, which should contribute to a better use of cohesion funds.  In the coming days, we will publish our detailed opinion on the relevant legislation. At the same time, the European budget remains under severe pressure, given the level of payments to which the EU has committed itself in the coming years. These so-called outstanding commitments, or RAL, are expected to increase even further by the end of 2020. We believe it is essential that this growing volume of outstanding commitments should be the main focus of the next multiannual financial framework. The total budget of the European Union represents only about 1% of the gross national income of the european Union as a whole. It is important that the funds of the European budget are used effectively. At the same time, however, we must realistically assess what can be achieved with the funds entrusted to us. The European Union can only win or retain the confidence of its citizens if it actually fulfils the expectations it has raised. We must prove to our citizens that the European Union can deliver on its commitments efficiently and in a way that actually makes a difference.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Mr Lehne, Member of the Court of Lazarou, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In the context of the Commission's annual accountability, the annual report of the European Court of Auditors plays an important role in the discharge procedure. We are grateful for the expert, objective assessment presented by the Court for the 2017 financial year and the Commission's accounts to us today. In fact, I believe that we can present good results to Parliament, the Council and the Court in terms of budget implementation and clearance of accounts, in the use of our budgetary resources. The Court of Auditors therefore also confirms improvements in financial management, and the error rate it estimates is lower than ever.  I want to make a contribution to continuing to learn from the experience and constructive critical advice of the Court and Parliament and the Council, and thus not at the end of a good development in the management of the budget. The annual report shows that we are transparent in the implementation of the budget. An unqualified opinion of the Court on the reliability of the annual accounts has now been issued for the eleventh time in a row. The Court recognises that the budget is an important instrument for achieving Europe's political objectives and that it helps – the budget – to achieve real added value in the interests of our citizens.  In addition to our traditional long-standing tasks, such as the common European agricultural policy, such as the still important cohesion policy, we have set priorities in the area of infrastructure and the development of efficient cross-border infrastructure across the continent over the past year. We have funded more important projects in research than ever before, and we have tried to tackle the migration task that has become a priority over the last three years, not only politically but also financially. We believe that the European budget will deliver concrete and good results for our citizens and have been achieved in the last year. The Commission also continues to see a focus of its budget implementation on keeping the risk of errors under control and further reducing it. This is about errors in the Commission and mistakes on the ground. Our aim is to make mistakes avoidable in the first place, so that they do not have to be corrected in the first place. We are therefore working closely with the Member States and with recipients. We provide assistance, we provide training and set up help desks to ensure that shared management – even beyond the European services on site – ensures the appropriate expertise in the implementation of the budget. You can't avoid all the mistakes. That is why we need sound correction systems when something has gone wrong. These corrections do not occur until some time after payment, which is also due to the multiannual nature of the European programmes.  In the management of our budget, we in the management of our budget want to ensure that, after a programme has been implemented, after a programme has been completed and after all the controls have been carried out, the remaining error rate is less than 2%. We reached the target last year and estimate the remaining error rate at around 0.6%, which is well below 1%.  I would like to add that mistakes can be due to fraud, waste and inefficiency. But there may also be mistakes that arise negligently, which have nothing to do with fraudulent intent, corruption or infidelity and still need to be corrected. The President of the Court of Auditors mentioned the outstanding commitments, and we also discussed payments at the interinstitutional meeting last week. We are monitoring the situation very closely, partly because Parliament expects this to be done. We are fully transparent about the outstanding commitments. The sum of around EUR 270 billion is not a surprise at this stage of a multiannual budgetary framework, but can be explained. EU financial assistance needed to implement programmes on the ground will be disbursed to Member States and other beneficiaries. We do not withhold any money. But it is important to note that the duration of many projects extends over several years from the initial planning to the start of construction, implementation and clearance of accounts.  As a result, commitments may not be made until a later financial year, even after the multiannual financial framework has been completed. This phenomenon also occurs in national budgets, but to a much lesser extent there.  The current state of play in the commitments to be made is not surprising and the implementation of projects on the ground has picked up speed. I can inform you that the Member States are now carrying out project selection as planned, that the budget has now reached full speed, and this also applies to the implementation of the current budget for 2018. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which You and we are currently in the middle of negotiations for the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027. I would like to thank the House – Parliament – for its efforts to quickly establish a position that you intend to adopt here in Parliament next month. The Commission's proposals contain many elements which will bring improvements with regard to some of the aspects identified by the Court. Firstly, a smaller difference between the level of appropriations for commitments and the appropriations for payments, from the outset. Secondly, more flexibility. Thirdly, N+2 instead of N+3, as is currently the case, so that the incentive to avoid delays increases, and then a greater focus on performance and results. For this we need yours – the support of Members – for these points, and we also want to include the Court's opinion on them. I would like to thank President Lehne, Mr Lazarou, your staff for the work the Court has done to make further improvements in the management of European finances. It is my and our overarching objective to have a budget that achieves results and real added value and that is managed well and correctly. Your constructive participation is necessary. We look forward to constructive cooperation with Parliament, the Council and the Court for the forthcoming discussions on the 2017 budget discharge.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: We will now proceed with speakers on behalf of the political groups. I have to highlight that we are somewhat behind schedule – itʼs a long agenda this afternoon and this evening – so I will have to be strict on respecting the time slots.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Lehne. This year, as the Commissioner has already mentioned, the topic of discharge is being discussed mainly in the context of the debate on the next Multiannual Financial Framework between 2021 and 2027. Why is this debate important? Because the EU budget is the most important instrument the EU has in hand in implementing its strategies and objectives. If the budget is not drawn down properly, effectively and its use does not add value, then the EU loses its meaning. I therefore see the need for fundamental budgetary and administrative reform. The need to simplify bureaucracy in the first place. Secondly, a reduction in the number of institutions and bodies. Thirdly, improving communication with the ordinary citizen, offering greater transparency. An EU citizen should understand, understand internal processes that should be much simpler and more readable. Projects must also be better presented, have more added value, have vision and have, ladies and gentlemen, above all sustainability.  The European Court of Auditors rightly warns the President that we must deal with money realistically, not set impossible targets. On the contrary, we must build citizens' trust through successful projects and build on some strong, long-term strategy. We want a clear vision from the new European Commission next year of where we are going, what we want and what we have lacked so far. This vision should bring the remaining Member States together and take the wind out of the sails of eurosceptics. The key to the implementation of this mandate, and that is the last sentence, Mr President, is that the Member States have the necessary expertise to achieve the European objectives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Once again, colleagues, I donʼt want to be impolite but I will have to come in when your time slot ends, so please try to avoid that situation.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I would like to welcome and thank mr Oettinger's speeches, on behalf of the Commission, as well as Mr Lehne and also Mr Lazarou's presence by the Court of Auditors. I would also like to thank you for the possibility of this debate being held in the presence of a large part of visitors, citizens of the European Union who have access to this debate. The Court of Auditors' annual photo of the European Union's dynamic and multiannual budget is now much closer to the reality of that budget than, for ever-increasing and more complex ambitions, it remains only 1% of the European Union's GDP and in relation to which we are concerned that flexibility and financial engineering will become escape elements. And we say this less than nine months after the European elections, criticism, and in the midst of debate on the Multiannual Financial Framework. In view of the debate on the financial future, we welcome the two most important recommendations. Firstly, that the European Union must not promise anything it cannot deliver, which in political policy would be, rather, that the European Union must give itself sufficient means for the promises it makes to its citizens. We also reflect the challenge of the growing gap between increasing commitments and poor payments, which leads precisely to the end of the outstanding budgetary commitments in a new high. We must therefore make this rebalancing a priority in the next financial framework.  We congratulate ourselves — albeit prudently, as always in budgetary control — for this second year in a row of an opinion with reservations, but not unfavourable. The level of irregularities has continued to decline, and we welcome this, but we are also aware - Commission and Council, we recall - that using the available information we would have been even better off. And there we have to keep improving, just like in the resolution of errors in the refunds part, without going to the flat-handed part for everything, and we must certainly improve our predictions.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. For 23 years now, in principle, when the Court began to draw up statements of assurance for the annual report, the opinion has always been negative. Now, for the second year in a row, the Court is iassing a qualified opinion on payments, so there is progress. Let us remember, however, that this is still not a clean opinion, that is, pure regarding payments. This could have been granted if the estimated level of error did not exceed the 2% threshold. What is worth highlighting, in my opinion, is that there is a growing progression here, because in 2015 we had almost 4% of this payment error (3.8%), in 2016 – 3.1%, well now – 2.4%, so it is clearly better.  On the other hand, it is worth pointing out that the biggest problem is in terms of reimbursement payments. Here, the situation is much worse, as this includes spending in the areas with the highest error levels.  Finally, it must be said that this Court's report is sound. Thanks to the President and his team and on behalf of the ECR Group, we declare our cooperation in further annual reports. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to ask the honourable Member – because he mentioned the reduction in the error rate – whether a zero error rate means that the Court of Auditors is not auditing or that no mistakes are being made. It is, of course, a success for the Court of Auditors if the quota is high. Of course, if no mistakes happen, it is actually clear in itself that a high error rate can also be combined with intensive testing and zero mistakes not only with the fact that no mistakes are made.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Eine gute Frage, good question, Mr. Well, of course, It seems to me that here it is more intellectual consideration than practical. On the other hand, I think it is necessary to seek to lower this threshold, but I do not believe too much in ideal situations. This is not possible, although It seems to me that step by step needs to work to improve these results, because this increases the credibility of our European institutions, and I think that is important.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – Mr President, President Lehne, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Court of Auditors' annual report for 2017 is the second report in a row that contains a statement with reservations about the reliability of the transactions carried out instead of a negative one. What is more, the estimated level of error in expenditure from the European budget is 2.4%, and last year it has once again come close to the materiality threshold. This means that more than 97.5% of European funds have fulfilled their purpose and purpose flawlessly. Individual projects have shown that they have brought European added value and contributed to the common political and economic objectives of the European Union. I believe that further reducing the administrative burden and overall simplification will continue to contribute to reducing error rates and raising the standard of living of Union citizens. On the other hand, however, it should be noted that, across all Member States, the overall absorption rate of European MFF funds was 16%, significantly lower than in the previous period, when absorption was at 22%. This increased the remaining commitments to more than EUR 267 billion. I believe that it would be appropriate to focus more on the cost-effective, efficient and efficient use of these European funds, so that they do not become merely a statistical indicator of the ability of Member States to draw on the allocated allocation in its own right.  The main reasons for the under-implementation include, in particular, the late adoption of legal acts and the difficulties in introducing new requirements related to the new Multiannual Financial Framework. Logically, this implies that we must learn lessons from this situation and prepare the next Multiannual Financial Framework in advance. Because only timely and proper preparation and sufficient communication with beneficiaries can lead to an effective, cost-effective and efficient investment from our common European means.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Thank you, Mr President. Ladies and gentlemen, First of all, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors – not only members of the Court of Auditors, but all their staff – for the wonderful work they are doing. The situation is improving: margin of error 2.4 this year. In 2014, that figure was 4.4. But at the same time, ladies and gentlemen, I read in the Court's report that in a large proportion of cases the Member States, the regional authorities, and even the European Commission when it comes to the European Development Fund, had information, had enough information, to ensure that certain payments should not have been made. This is a debate on responsibility and I ask rapporteur Ayala Sender that we include this in the discharge and that we look for a method to oblige and possibly penalise it if it is not taken. I would also like to point out that some 267 billion in payments were open at the end of 2017. This is going to be a political problem, because by the end of the multiannual budget we will not be able to deliver all the payments and not all the promises. I ask that we have a serious exchange of views on this in this discharge exercise as well.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in 2017, out of a budget of approximately EUR 140 billion, the EU spent 52.8 billion on agriculture and rural development. This equates to less than half of one per cent of Member States’ GNI. As auditors, concerned where funds are spent, this represents outstanding value for money. The fact that 500 million citizens of the EU have access to quality, affordable food is perhaps one of the greatest achievements of the EU. The error rate in direct payments (Pillar 1) is below 2%. With improvements in the control systems – both the Integrated  Administration and Control System (IACS) and the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS) – this is expected to improve further. The error rate in Pillar 2 is higher, and while we must be aware of this and work to improve it, it should come as no surprise. We should bear in mind that Pillar 2 schemes focusing more on environmental issues are inherently more error-prone and less easily quantifiable. We face huge challenges in this area and we must continue to set the bar high and assist our farmers as they take on new challenges in climate change mitigation. We must resist the urge to focus solely on error rates in this sector, which may have the unintended consequence of lowering ambition in order to comply with targets in this vital sector. These things must be kept in mind in the upcoming CAP. With the Commission’s proposed new delivery model, will it lead to the much-touted simplification at farmer level? How will fragmentation of one of our oldest policies under the banner of subsidiarity lead to better outcomes in an area where we must work together across the EU, namely climate change mitigation? And finally, from an auditor’s perspective, there are hard questions to be asked of the direction of this CAP reform. Look at it closely. It’s going to be a disaster.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is quite worrying that the audit assessment is negative with regard to the payments relating to the costs of the European Asylum Support Office. In particular, this judgment concerns public procurement, recruitment procedures and payments made – we read in your very serious report, for which I congratulate you – systematically in breach of the rules. The question arises, some of our fellow citizens would say, whether there is anyone who controls the operation of this body and of the agencies in general that are in the process of being operated, perhaps even before these distortions, in this case serious ones, take place because of the sensitivity of the institution. As far as operation is concerned, the controls on another very important agency, the EMA, which has been decided by procedure to be reviewed and reconsidered in Amsterdam, is there anyone, I would say, who is monitoring the progress of the construction work? To me they are very slow compared to the program, almost stationary. We should check ex ante, so that we do not have to make unpayed payments and damage that affects European citizens, health and pharmacy... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I do not read the Court of Auditors' report and the error rate in such a way that the administrations are getting better. I read the report in such a way that administrations are slowing down. And the fact that we naturally have too much money in the system is probably true, because those who do not spend this money – and this can be seen from the court report that this money is not needed at the moment, because there is still so much old money. That is what is actually worrying about it. And that it is so, we also have a share of responsibility for this. I believe that if we were to focus on what is actually being done on the ground, we would do everyone involved a favour. We need to focus on reality, and it looks like Poland has still not called up EUR 27.3 billion – EUR 27.3 billion in this financial framework – italy 15.6 billion 15.6 billion would be a great amount for growth and employment, would be a great amount for Italian industry, the Italian economy. So I propose that the Italians, the Italian Government, be encouraged to use this money: stop! I would also like to say that the report shows that we have old problems, for example in the Czech Republic. The Czech Republic pays a high price for corrupt structures, and I can only say that these structures must be remedied, otherwise the entire population will pay its price. That is what we will be looking after. I am a little concerned that the current debate on the error rate ignores how well-calculated this error rate is. Yes, Mr President, I say it quite frankly, because prepayments, budget support, financial engineering instruments – all these things are parameters with which you can rock and use them differently. In other words, this reduces the error rate, which in turn does not mean that the administration is actually getting better.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Of course, as the President said, we are talking about one percentage of our national product or national income, but this is the one percent that is going to change the face of the European Union. This is our public money, and the fact that you care that it is spent legally, and in addition to it effectively, that is, this performance orientation, I would pass on the plus side.  I would distinguish between two different things in this annual report. Namely, to thank the Court of Auditors for simply know what is going on, and you are presenting this picture to us. Secondly, the conclusions that we should draw for ourselves, namely, as Mrs Gräßle said, for example, to speed up, rhythmically arrange the repayments of the funds that are foreseen for the Member States. But it is neither the fault of the European Commission nor of the Court of Auditors that the Member States are laying it out like this. Finally, briefly, because time is running out, I would like to stress the importance and importance of the European Court of Auditors' cooperation with national courts, because that can help us all.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The falling error rate in recent years is undoubtedly good news. The Commission deserves credit for this. It is to be hoped that this trend will continue. For example, more cases could be submitted to OLAF. I think 13 out of over 700 are decidedly too little. Nevertheless, the work of the auditors is also to be praised in principle. For this reason too, we are calling for the Recommendations of the Court of Auditors to be implemented. It would be even more important to apply the value for money principle, that is to say, to favour projects that have a higher useful value. For example, European taxpayers' money would not have created motorways in Greece, where there is now minimal traffic. There are certainly many other places where motorways would be better used by European taxpayers' money.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank the Court of Auditors for presenting its report on the 2017 financial year, as well as the twenty-seven special reports also made during this period. As the Commissioner and other colleagues have pointed out, I think we need to congratulate ourselves on this significant reduction in the level of overall error in payments. I think it is also important to underline the importance of the mid-term review of the current financial perspectives introduced greater doses of flexibility into the Community budget; I do not know whether enough to address the challenges which, in a pressing way, weigh on the challenges facing the European Union. I would like to share the concern expressed by Mrs Grussle regarding the level of accumulated or deferred payments, problems which will also be complicated by the prospect and the dimension of completion which the Brexit negotiation also entails. As regards everything relating to the fulfilment of the Court of Auditors' observations, Commissioner, it must be said with satisfaction that the Commission has completed seventy-five of the hundred observations and has left only six un fulfilled in any way. As shadow rapporteur for the other institutions, I would like to say that we will continue to try to improve things in this procedure, trying to address the inadequacies and trying to get the taxpayer's resources used in the best possible way.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Lehne, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. We have heard it several times now: the error rate is declining – until the last time to 2.4% in 2017. But what conclusion can be drawn from this? One conclusion – as many newspapers have read – is that 2.4% is equivalent to EUR 3.3 billion, which seems to have been completely muddied. The headline and the coverage suggest that they were simply carelessly put in the sand or misused. Over EUR 3 billion is certainly not peanuts. But it must be made clear that where people work, mistakes, mistakes, e.B. inineligible costs or insufficient documentation, also happen.  I meet regularly with people from my own country who keep telling me how complicated European funding programmes are, and we are currently working to simplify these support programmes. To talk about cheating or sloppiness is definitely not enough. Another way of concludeing is to say that the Court of Auditors' annual report confirms that 97.6% of all cases were unobjectionable. Of course, this does not fit into the plan for the EU critics. But it means that 97.6% was used correctly. With so much bad news, you can't be happy about it.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors. As coordinator for regional policy, cohesion, I would like to make a few comments. First of all: good. A lower error rate this year. The turnaround also in budgeting, the performance budgeting is made. First the money went very easily to the Member States, now there has to be an agreement in advance and then we also look in advance whether there is that commitment. A new practice has been introduced. Second point: indeed a late start-up. The Member States are only now gaining steam. And the result is that money remains in that European coffers and it flows back to the Member States. And it's inevitable: in 2–3 years we'll get that whole pile of bills again. Good thing you come up with suggestions to do something about it. Thirdly, you are right to say that there is sometimes too little coherence between, for example, research policy, Horizon 2020, and regional funds. Horizon 2020 looks a bit like a beautiful Airbus that hangs in the air, but has no view of the landing strip. And there's a lot we can do about that. You point this out, and I think it is also very good that you are saying that you will be making further recommendations within two weeks. We'll look into that. But we are on the right track and we just have a good chairman. Thank you, Klaus-Heiner.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, there is one central finding in the Court’s report. In the fifth year of this period, we are twice as bad at properly appropriating funds in comparison to the previous programme period. I feel that the Commission is not paying sufficient attention and taking responsibility, its responsibility, for this totally unacceptable situation. The Commission takes the kind of attitude that it knows about this ‘retard’ and is taking it into consideration and doing what is necessary. It is not enough! There should be a sense of real urgency that growing inequalities are the central threat to the very future of the Union. So there have to be extraordinary efforts, driven by the Commission, to overcome this totally unacceptable situation.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, this 2017 audit marks one of the largest year—on—year improvements, and I think for that we should give credit to the Commission and to Commissioner Oettinger. But especially I want us to give credit to former Commissioner Georgieva. She was the one who laid the foundations, and she, I think, deserves our special recognition. As in previous years, the auditors have commented on the high number of instances where the Member States did have sufficient information with which to identify and intercept errors at a much earlier stage. As President Lehne said earlier, had the Member States done that, the overall result would have been significantly better. It’s important that the public have confidence in the integrity of European expenditure, so audit reports do matter. Therefore I take this opportunity to call on the Member States and ask them to accept their responsibilities – but I also ask them to act on their responsibilities. Finally, as ever, may I express my thanks to Mr Lehne, President of the Court of Auditors, and his team for a job well done.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors, who gave us a precise and careful picture of the use of the Union budget in 2017. It is comforting to know that there has been a steady improvement in the overall picture, with a rate of error on payments gradually decreasing over the last three years. For my part, I would like to stress the importance of the audit, for example in the areas of security and citizenship, which, although representing a relatively small part of the Union's budget (around 2 %), touch on particularly sensitive issues that are felt by European citizens. In this respect, but more generally in all areas of expenditure, I believe that the recommendations presented by the Court of Auditors deserve careful consideration and require a precise assessment of the performance and European added value of expenditure in order to ensure the most correct use of the Union budget.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: "Allow me to summarise what I have to say in three points to the point. First of all, allow me to say that, in agreement with many of my colleagues, it is quite clear and unethly that the European Court of Auditors is doing an excellent job, above all. The presentation on the closure of the EU budget for 2017 supports this finding. Allow me, Mr President, to pay my respects to you, to all the members and staff of the Court of Auditors. Secondly, allow me to say that although we are politicians and we can make bad news out of good news at the end of a sentence, and sometimes we try to make good news out of bad news at the end of a sentence, it is by no means detrimental that the error rate identified in the European Union budget, as examined by the European Court of Auditors, has decreased compared to previous years. At the moment, it's 2.4%. A further reduction would be justified, but this is in any case a positive trend.  Last but not least, if there is one area where a erroneous, irregular or corrupt payment from the European Union budget is unacceptable, it is the area of migration. The report prepared by the European Court of Auditors has revealed serious shortcomings in this area, so I can say that it is our shared responsibility to examine separately the issue of irregular use of money in the area of migration in the parliamentary inquiry into the Court's report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I want to congratulate the Court of Auditors once again for a job well done. I think it is really significant that the error rate continues to fall and we need to welcome that as real progress that has been shown. The most important job of the job of auditors is to shine a light on public expenditure as it relates to European funds, and shining a light must lead to change, it must lead to new practices. As other colleagues have said, it must lead to less bureaucracy, not more bureaucracy. We have to do things differently, and in any new budget we have got to prioritise new areas of public expenditure.  As we go forward to the multiannual financial framework (MFF )for the next seven years, let us agree that earlier rather than later. Let us also ensure that we breach the 1% cap, which many Member States do not want to breach, because that will show real solidarity to the 27 Member States that remain within the European Union, and it will also show real determination to be ambitious on European projects that can lead to a better, stronger single market.  I also think it’s important that we highlight in this debate the way in which we can change attitudes and change procedures through better public expenditure. A new MFF must be about new priorities; not just the same old systems but new priorities. That is the best way to respond to the concerns of EU taxpayers.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On the occasion of this report, I will focus on cultural issues. I was supposed to have a voice as a representative of this committee and give a short opinion. Firstly, I draw attention to the new programmes that are emerging. They are pleased, for example, with the start of the implementation phase of the European Solidarity Corps. This is, I recall, two and a half thousand internships – it is worth noting and it is noted with such a positive opinion. The low absorption rate and insufficient geographical coverage of the two instruments, but above all the erasmus+ student loan guarantees, may be of concern at all times. Here corrections are necessary. The second concern is the still low success rates of projects funded under the Europe for Citizens programme and the Creative Culture sub-programme. I would remind you that there, respectively, we have twenty percent and fifteen percent absorption among good proposals, that is, those proposals that have been positively evaluated. I pay attention to this.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, I am actually also contributing today to all the congratulations with the very good procedure for assessing your report. And I would also like to mention that I believe that the joint work with the Committee on Budgetary Control, its principled position for a number of years, almost two terms, has made it really true that the results that have been mentioned here have been truly translated.  However, I believe that there is one problem that should be addressed in the future, which has been going on since the 1970s: that is, the reliability of data from Member States. Perhaps, Mr President, you are well aware of what I am talking about, that the data that is available today is not reliable, but from them we sometimes make certain reports. At the same time, our lives are going forward and certain priorities will change in the future: especially if we are talking about financing defence spending, there will also be special maintenance, the closure of nuclear power plants, which is a very complicated issue in order to control the use of money, and, of course, our aid and support funds. I therefore congratulate and thank you once again for the report presented.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the role of the Court of Auditors is indeed important as it monitors how European Union funds are spent. That is why it is a given that transparency must be ensured and we must monitor how accounts are closed. We consider, of course, that the error rate at 2.4% is still high. We want it to fall below 2% and that is why we have reservations. At the same time, I think it is important that the Court of Auditors is seriously examining the irregularities that have taken place, and indeed serious irregularities, in the area of the operation of EASO, the European Asylum Support Office, and that is where you must insist. As well as insist on monitoring how funds are spent on the part of NGOs, why NGOs are partying at the moment. We have too many complaints in Greece, it has already undertaken an investigation or OLAF and we want an answer to this question, Mr Lehne, afterwards, when you speak again. We must also be concerned about absorption, but this concerns Italy and Poland in particular.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, I thank the Court of Auditors for the well-prepared report, very detailed and exhaustive, and I am pleased that the Court of Auditors is increasingly focusing on auditing the results achieved, as the key question is whether our citizens, our farmers, entrepreneurs and young people benefit from investment or whether it is better to change certain programmes, if necessary, to abolish or replace them with other programmes that will better and more respond to their needs.  You have pointed out that management and control systems are improving. There are fewer irregularities. This pleases us all, but it is important to accelerate the system, colleagues have pointed it out, make it more useful and functional. With your reports, you can help a lot to improve the system, not only through the legal, efficient and effective use of funds, but also in a timely, particularly underlined, use of EU money.  You can, say, help us use technical assistance across different programs to build administrative capacity in areas that audits clearly lack the knowledge needed to spend public money wisely, purposefully and timely. That's why I'm looking forward to your special reports and a new approach to the work.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I have listened carefully to your speeches. We will evaluate them and come back to them in the course of the further discharge procedure. I am grateful for the recognition given by many Members to my staff in the Commission services for their proper budget implementation. I can also accept and accept the expectations of many Members here, and I think some critical remarks are worth considering. Thank you very much for the factual debate! If we still see in 2018 that some of the programmes have been delayed, what are the reasons, and what are the consequences for the next budget framework? Firstly, since the current budgetary framework was only adopted by the Council and Parliament in mid-December with all the implementing rules, it was the first year and also the second year of the budgetary framework, so the years 2014 and much of 2015 were a lost time. Only in 2017 did all programs record full travel speed. This can be noted in particular for 2018 and for the implementation of the budget this year. Secondly, N+3 does not put a great deal of pressure on us to submit invoices quickly and to request reimbursements. Only a few months ago, we practically completed the 2007-2013 budget framework. Only now do the authorities also have some room for manoeuvre to apply for and obtain approval from the current budgetary framework. Therefore: N+2 instead of N+3. And our joint recommendation – that of Parliament and the Commission – to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that the next budgetary framework can be adopted along the way to the next election. This will allow the preparations to use the programmes from 1 January 2021. This lesson must be drawn from the deliberations of the current budgetary framework, from 2011, 2012 and 2013. Thirdly, simplification of the rules for our programmes. With our proposal for the next MFF, we have clearly combined simplification – simplification. Finally, the Member States would have to designate their competent authorities much earlier. In some cases, some Member States and regions only designated the authorities responsible for implementation and programme implementation at the beginning of last year. These lessons can be drawn from the current budgetary framework. Next time, the delay will certainly be much reduced and the benefits of the Commission's and the Union's budget programmes as a whole will arrive much earlier and more strongly with citizens, the labour market and European economic competitiveness. Thank you very much for this advice!

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the Court of Auditors. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank everyone for their support for our work. Mr Lazarou, who, as the main rapporteur in the House, has done the essential work in drawing up the annual report, and I will gladly pass that on to all my fellow Members and staff in the House.  Mr Czarnecki raised the issue of the fact that for 24 years now, since the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty, we have had to make the so-called statement of insurance as the Court of Auditors. We have delivered a negative verdict of this for 22 years and a limited positive judgment for two years now.  I think this is a really positive development. I would like to emphasise this once again: this is not due to miscalculation or downcounting the error rate, but is simply due to the fact that the data have actually improved. We have made significant progress on the issue of compliance within the European Union, although I do not want to rule out the possibility that the picture may not look so good next year. This is also due to the fact that this year we have, of course, had a comparatively small share of cohesion expenditure and cohesion expenditure tends to always have a slightly higher error rate anyway. It cannot therefore be ruled out that the picture may not look quite as good next year as it has been this year. I would perhaps like to make another comment on the error rate. This is not an exact calculation – and this is often unfortunately misunderstood – is a mathematical-statistical method that you, as a politician, all know from opinion polls, where a sample is taken, and on this basis is then calculated what the probable error rate is. But this always has a variation range of about +/- 1% on average, and therefore it must be said quite clearly that if one makes concrete statements about concrete percentages from a certain limit, i.e. below the materiality limit, then they have a relatively small actual statistical value. As a farm, therefore, we are increasingly considering – we will reconsider this again next year – whether we should not completely save ourselves all the statements that are below the materiality limit and delete them altogether. This is an issue that we will discuss, simply to avoid further misunderstandings in this context. The issue of RAL, the rest of the liquid, has, of course, played a major role in the debate. I would like to make it quite clear – in order to avoid misunderstandings again – that RALs are normal, as Commissioner Oettinger quite rightly said. What worries us is the sheer dimension that we currently have RALs in the order of double the annual nominal budget.  Of course, this is also a consequence of the N+3 rule. The N+3 rule was introduced in 2008 or after 2008 in the context of the financial crisis because Member States had problems co-financing or financing projects. But the financial crisis was ten years ago. That is why it might now be time to think about returning to normal conditions and thus avoiding such an increase in commitments in the future. I think Mr Flanagan, Mr van Nistelrooij and Mr Hayes have made reference to the MFF anyway. You can assume that in the next few days we will decide on the individual opinions, the opinions on agricultural policy, cohesion policy. Because the desire is your own, we are happy to make it horizon and other topics that are important to you. I would like to mention the error rate, because Mr Kohn was right to raise the issue, and I am very grateful for that. If we find an estimated error rate of 2.4%, that does not mean that EUR 3.3 billion has been wasted by the European Union from EU funds. That does not mean that. This simply means that we have found errors in the issuance of these funds, either legal, usually legal or accounting deficiencies. That says nothing about the usefulness of expenditure. These funds, even if they have been flawed, may have been spent in perfect sense. It is just as conceivable that funds that have been lawfully spent have been spent in absolutely pointless terms. This is a compliance check. So we are doing nothing but checking whether things are right in legal and mathematical terms. The other theme of meaningfulness is examined in performance, i.e. in Audit reports, which, incidentally, we are already producing in large numbers – up to 50 per year – at the moment as the European Court of Auditors. The performance share also plays a certain role in the annual report. We are currently considering internally how we can improve this in order to give you better information about it in detail. The issue of value for money has also been raised here; European added value is also an issue that plays a major role in the issue of performance and is very limited in the issue of compliance.  Mr Ashworth was right to point out that a large part of the responsibility also lies with the Member States. I think that is correct and that should not be forgotten. The Commission is not to blame for everything. It must, of course, stop the Member States from doing things properly. In this respect, it is always in business in terms of data reliability. I would also like to say something about this, because it is also mentioned time and again. Rest assured that we only use data from the Member States and the Commission for our audits, which we personally believe to be reliable. All other data on which we have doubts are not consulted, but our own data collection takes place on our own. I can say to Mr Marias that the report on NGOs is in its final phase, and it will come soon. I hope that you will be able to draw conclusions from this. Mrs Maletis was quite right to raise the issue of often lack of or insufficient technical support. We made a report on this some time ago on the JASPERS programmes and we have also made some critical comments on how this can be improved. As you can see, the Court of Auditors is trying to keep you all up to date so that we can improve our overall work. Our criticism does not serve to bring anything down, but our criticism serves to improve the situation, to put our finger in the wound, but in the sense of healing, not in the sense of destroying.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Annual Report of the European Court of Auditors is a good opportunity to recall how the European Union generates its budget. In 2017, the Union budget amounted to €137.4 billion, the largest of which, €78.4 billion, was paid by Member States in direct proportion to their gross national income. In addition, €20.3 billion was paid from customs duties and €16.6 billion from VAT. Thus, the total EU budget represents no more than about 1% of the eu-wide gross national income.  At the same time, it must be borne in mind that it is budgetary expenditure that is an important tool for achieving the EU's policy objectives. Therefore, the high level of outstanding budgetary commitments, which have risen to a record high of €267.3 billion, is very worrying. Member States shall not use the budget allocated to them to achieve their objectives. I am very concerned that my country, Poland, has not yet used EUR 27 billion for structural investments. This money would certainly contribute to a better economic development of the country. Member States should therefore better forecast expenditure and better manage the risk of a backlog of payments should be a priority when planning the future Multiannual Financial Framework 2020-2027.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I should like to begin by thanking the Court of Auditors for its work. The annual report drawn up by the Court of Auditors is indeed a document of great importance to the European Parliament, as it facilitates our work and provides many elements for assessing aspects of EU expenditure and identifying the problems to be solved. The 2017 Annual Report found some improvements compared to previous years, primarily the fact that, in general, the estimated level of error for payments made is constantly decreasing. This is a step in the right direction. There are, however, a number of critical points: for heading 3 (security and citizenship) and heading 4 (Europe's global role) it has not yet been possible to detect the error rate, which leads to a serious lack of transparency and control of expenditure. In some areas, such as rural development, significant error rates and well-known problems persist, both of which need to be addressed and resolved as soon as possible. I hope, in order to ensure that citizens are properly spent, that measures are taken to improve the situation.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Alessia Maria Mosca and Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the import of cultural goods (COM(2017)0375 - C8-0227/2017 - 2017/0158(COD)) (A8-0308/2018)

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after lengthy negotiations, we are finally debating today the adoption of the regulation on the import of cultural goods. I would like to begin by thanking all my fellow Members for the hard work they have done over the last few months. Some studies indicate that the illicit trafficking of works of art is second only to that of weapons and drugs. Images of the destruction of the Palmyra site by Isis are still alive in our eyes, but talk of destruction is inaccurate. It was a real dismantling: the most precious finds were stolen and sold on the European square. After depriving the Syrian people of their history and culture, European buyers contributed to the direct funding of a terrorist organisation. The illegal trafficking of works of art is a crime against humanity because it deprives us of our common artistic heritage and history, but it also threatens the security of European citizens, contributing to the financing of terrorist activities. Not only that: by promoting tax evasion and money laundering, the illegal trade in works of art threatens our social model.  The new regulation will therefore contribute to this threefold battle by imposing transparency and greater controls. It was not an easy task. Although we all agree on the urgent need for action, we have had difficulty in establishing the right balance between the need to put a stop to these illegal trades and the objective of not burdening private operators and customs with unnecessary red tape. We have therefore introduced facilities for small and medium-sized enterprises, an electronic registration system that can facilitate the procedures and value thresholds that will allow for more targeted application, imposing controls only on the most valuable goods. In addition, starting with the UNESCO Convention of 1970, the text we have proposed will be more consistent with international conventions and Union regulations. By applying the same annex to the Export Regulation and drawing on the experience of customs officials and art markets, implementation will thus be easier. The final text is balanced, as demonstrated by the very large majority that supported it. The European Union will equip itself with a state-of-the-art instrument capable of combating illegal trafficking without curbing lawful trade, which is a source of employment and growth. After approval, we will have to ensure that the application is as uniform as possible. We cannot allow internal competition between European ports to create free zones. We must combat internal fraud, such as that perpetrated, for example, by the BRITISH authorities in the Eu ropean budget from 2011, which is why we will be entering a due diligence system, that is, a list of equal documents for all that customs authorities will be obliged to request. To our British friends who are frightened by the effects that the regulation will have on the London art market after Brexit, I would like to remind you that you cannot enjoy the benefits of a community without being part of it and if you want to avoid double controls you have to be part of the single market. Once again, European trade policy is an alternative to both protectionism and unbridled liberalism. A strategy based on our values: trade cannot, in fact, be free from social, human and environmental rights. With tomorrow's vote, we will be adding another element of sustainability to European trade policy, another brick to make our common home more worthy for the men and women who live there, a further effort to make globalisation a fairer and more humane process. This is the Europe we want, a Europe that protects without closing in on itself.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, we’ve had some tough negotiations over the last few months, thatʼs fair to say, and the text weʼre voting on tomorrow is not perfect. But our discussion showed that we all share the same goal: workable legislation that targets the illicit importing of cultural goods for terrorist financing without overburdening customs authorities or small businesses. For that reason – unlike the Commission – we recognise the need for value thresholds on most items. We already have value thresholds in the export regulation. For imports, clearly, higher-value items are of greater interest for terrorist financing. So for the Commission not to follow that precedent and to have no value thresholds on a regulation that applies to the whole world – low- as well as high-risk areas – made little sense. Customs authorities are already overwhelmed and unable to check most imports. So to work, this regulation needs to focus on higher-value, higher-risk goods. That is how we deal with customs issues throughout our legislation: risk-based, intelligence-led checks. This proposal – let’s not forget – was originally drawn up in light of Isis’s control of large areas of Syria and the potential for them to traffic antiquities to fund their activities. Global strife, however, constantly evolves, so our work here needs to be better than just press-release politics, and legislation needs to be fit for changing risks. Importantly, in the Parliament text we also recognise that there are legitimate movements of goods for museums and art fairs that we shouldn’t in any way hinder. Creating long delays to imports would have simply moved these fairs outside Europe, where there is often less oversight. In the Parliament we agreed from the start on a digital-led approach. Cultural objects cross borders repeatedly, so information needs to be exchanged to allow previously-vetted goods to circulate freely. A fully-electronic system is therefore critical and, given these rules will not be applied until the early 2020s, continuing with a paper system, I think, would look ridiculous. We also recognise that small businesses will need help in complying with this regulation. Many cultural goods, such as sub-genres of books or types of antiquities, are sold by highly-specialised companies, so micro- and family businesses are at the heart of the trade. The scope is fundamental to the potential burden of this regulation, but we have also proposed targeted measures to further help small companies meet the demands on them. Cooperation with third countries will also be vital to tackling illicit trade. So I strongly support the provisions we introduced in this regulation to bolster efforts being made to improve the capacities of countries that are struggling to preserve their cultural heritage. By complementing those efforts with sensible import rules, we can act to resolve the whole supply chain for illicit goods rather than just isolating Europe from a global problem. As I said at the start, although we’ve made significant improvements, this text is not perfect. For example, there is still some potential difficulty in cases where provenance is hard to determine – of which there will be many when dealing with ancient artefacts. This is particularly the case for low—value archaeological items, which fall under the scope of the final text, regardless of whether they are from high- or low-risk areas. It should be possible to import items which have been held legitimately for decades without the cooperation of source countries which lack documentation to judge the original export’s legitimacy. Otherwise, we risk overburdening customs authorities and importers with an unachievable proof requirement that could clog up the system and fail to deliver on the regulation’s aims. I am optimistic, though, that, through constructive negotiations with the Council, using their first—hand knowledge of customs operations, we can streamline this proposal and emerge with a final law fit for purpose. We want to avoid a ʻfortress Europeʼ approach and unworkable requirements that might prevent the profiteering of Isis but also devastate the responsible family businesses that make up the vast majority of the trade in Europe. If I can just make one point in response to Ms Mosca’s points: for the UK this is a classic case in point. If these rules are too overburdening for European producers and the UK is outside that market, I can guarantee you that the trade will move to the UK, and no one in Europe or the UK will be thankful for that. I won’t. I want to see us working closely together, and this text is absolutely vital to make sure we get this right in order to do it.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: cult rapporteur. – Mr President, this Regulation is a novel proposal, since there was no legislation in this regard, only the Export Regulation, which relates only to European goods. And I think it is especially relevant as it is this year, 2018, the European Year of Cultural Heritage. In the Committee on Culture and Education we had two objectives: on the one hand, to prevent terrorism, organized crime and money laundering from being financed by the illegal sale of cultural goods from third countries; and on the other hand, ensure the preservation of the cultural heritage of these countries. In addition, we had to combine these fundamental objectives, so that the European art market would not be harmed by too strict regulation, which would complicate the legal and regular market for European traders, auction houses and museums. It has not been an easy task, as there were many conflicting interests, but I believe that we have managed to agree on a balanced text, so we welcome the success of the objectives it set out above.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in recent years, the world has witnessed the destruction of priceless archaeological sites and monuments and the looting of cultural artefacts by warring factions and terrorist entities worldwide.  There is evidence that some of those artefacts are sold and brought into the Union, with their proceeds potentially used to finance terrorist activities. For instance, early in 2018, a Spanish antiques dealer was arrested in Barcelona for his alleged participation in a wide international network trafficking antiques. The investigation appears to show that these works of art were stolen from archaeological sites in Libya. They were looted by the terrorist organisation Islamic State and were especially intended for the financing of terrorism.  Another example is the seizure by French customs authorities two years ago at Charles de Gaulle Airport of looted cultural goods which probably came from the war region in Iraq and Syria. The Commission is very engaged on the issue of cultural goods trafficking.  The Commission is also fully engaged in the fight against terrorist financing and presented an action plan aiming to reduce the sources of revenue of terrorist organisations in February 2016. Within this context, the Commission made proposals to the Council and Parliament to strengthen customs controls in two areas, one on the control of cultural goods at import and another one on controls on cash entering and leaving the European Union.  The proposal on cash controls has led to the adoption of an amended regulation, soon to be published in the Official Journal. The Commission welcomes the successful effort of the co-legislators on that matter.  On cultural goods, the Commission adopted in July 2017 a proposal to prevent the import and storage, including in free zones, in the EU of cultural goods illicitly exported from third countries. The measure aspires to protect cultural heritage, to combat illicit trade in cultural goods, especially archaeological objects and parts of dismembered monuments, and to strengthen the fight against terrorist financing. At the same time, the right balance between safeguarding of common cultural heritage and avoiding undue burden on trade was fully taken into account.  At present, the EU applies common rules on the export of cultural goods and the return of cultural objects unlawfully removed from the territory of a Member State. However, with the exception of two specific measures prohibiting trade in cultural goods with Iraq and Syria, no common rules exist regarding the import of cultural goods into the EU customs territory.  The Commission’s proposal came as a response to a call for action from the European Parliament and the Council, from international organisations and from governments of the Member States. Our proposal provides a common definition of cultural goods deriving from the 1970 Unesco Convention and the 1995 Unidroit Convention, listing categories of objects which are of importance for archaeology, prehistory, history, literature, art or science.  Furthermore, a minimum age threshold of 250 years for such objects is introduced. This allows focusing on cultural goods considered to be the most affected and vulnerable to illicit trade. It also minimises the impact on national authorities and the art market in terms of operational and compliance costs as they already have experience with these thresholds, which exist in US legislation. The proposed regulation establishes a system of import licences and import statements that are required, depending on the category of the cultural goods concerned. The import licence, which implies a higher level of scrutiny, would target the cultural goods most at risk.  Exceptions to this rule are introduced in the case of the temporary admission of an object for scientific or academic research purposes and cultural exchange, or for cultural goods at minimum risk of destruction sent to the Union for safekeeping by a third country’s public authorities.  In order to improve the ability of customs officials to recognise suspicious shipments and to cooperate more efficiently with other law enforcement authorities in preventing illicit trade in cultural goods, the proposal also provides for the organisation of training and capacity—building activities for customs and other law enforcement authorities and awareness-raising campaigns aimed at potential buyers in the Union.  The brief summary I have set out focused on the main elements of the proposal.
