Let me recall that this is an essential piece of legislation to combat trafficking in cultural goods, deprive terrorists of a source of income and protect cultural heritage.  Before I conclude, please allow me to thank both rapporteurs, Ms Mosca and Mr Dalton, for their constructive cooperation. I am happy to give you the floor and I am looking forward to your interventions.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, during our work on this file, our objective was to prevent the import into and storage in the EU of cultural goods illegally exported from third countries, but also to reduce trafficking and combat financing of terrorism and, obviously, to protect cultural heritage, especially archaeological objects in countries affected by armed conflict. During our work the most important and, at the same time, the most challenging issue was the scope. Luckily, we managed to achieve a good compromise, covering all those goods that deserve special protection, but at the same time limiting the scope as much as possible to those cultural goods most affected by illegal trafficking. I believe that it is extremely important not to overburden market actors and disturb the licit trade of cultural goods in the EU, therefore, I am very happy that red tape for the art market will be avoided, in particular for SMEs. This will be possible through the establishment of an economic threshold in addition to the 250—year threshold, which means that not all goods with zero value will be covered by this regulation. To give you an example, without an economic threshold, books from the 18th century which are worth nothing would fall under the scope and administrative costs would probably be higher than the value of the book itself, and that would kill the market. We need common rules to ensure effective protection against the loss of cultural goods and the prevention of terrorist financing through the sale of looted cultural heritage to buyers in the EU. This is the first step towards well-balanced legislation which will protect cultural heritage while enabling the stakeholders concerned to keep trading without barriers.

name: Arndt KOHN
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Tomorrow, the trialogue mandate for the regulation on the import of cultural goods will be voted on. Why does the European Parliament take care of the import of illegal cultural goods from third countries? After drugs and weapons, the illegal trade in cultural goods is considered one of the most lucrative transactions on the black market, possibly also used to finance terrorism. But what is at stake here is that centuries-old testimonies of human civilisation may be lost forever, sold on the black market, or disappear ingesbly to free ports or cellars. We are not playing the world police, but the principle must apply: culture is worth protecting all over the world. We must therefore not allow cultural goods worthy of protection to enter the market illegally in the European Union. Better customs rules help to combat organised crime, money laundering and tax evasion. The text as voted on in committee is, in my opinion, balanced and takes account of all interests equally. The bureaucratic burden on the art trade will be relatively low. An import licence will only have to be presented for a fraction of all imports, because it mainly concerns archaeological goods. It deliberately does not include every family heirloom. There is an age and value limit for all other cultural assets. All that would have to be done for them is a self-declaration, which can then be used to act legally. Customs officials must also have a legally sound basis for action in order to be able to withdraw illegally imported cultural goods from circulation. This dossier is making a valuable contribution to this in 2018, the Year of European Cultural Heritage.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as Chair of the Delegation for relations with Iraq, I of course share the objective of tackling terrorist financing. However, I cannot share enthusiasm for this report. Its excessive scope captures too large a volume of cultural goods, with the potential to create disruption to legitimate trade, not to mention burdensome, even unworkable, customs procedures.  The original aim has been totally lost amid a desire to control the art market. This is of course of considerable concern to the UK with its prominence in the art world. Items that bear no relation to stemming terrorist finance, even for example a map of 1900s America, would be caught up in this regulation. It is a sledgehammer to crack a nut.  I had initially proposed to limit the scope of the proposal by recommending an age and value threshold. Instead, this requires an extensive list of documents to prove origin, otherwise they will be treated as illicit imports. Overall, I wish we had a more balanced approach that would help combat terrorist financing, but without creating such impractical red tape. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, David, for taking my question. I liked what you said, a lot of what you said made sense. Would you agree with me that there is an enormous danger that ordinary people dealing in the art market in small ways – in ‘déballages’ in France, in small markets – are going to be crucified by this ludicrous law, again, this neurosis about terrorism. It is pure Orwell!  There are ways of doing this. At the moment if auction houses see something that should not be on the market, they will inform the authorities. Surely, do you not agree with me that there is enough legislation, we do not need more?

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Mr Coburn, I know that you deal with antiques and are an expert in this area. Yes, I am worried. I have a wonderful grandfather clock. I have no idea how old it is, it is probably 17th century, and I could never prove where it has come from if I were to move it somewhere under these new laws. I also have some stuff from a prime minister, I am related to a former prime minister from before 1900.  So I feel that this is going too far and is impractical, it won’t work and it really doesn’t help. I’m all in favour of cracking down on terrorist financing. This does not help.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me begin by expressing my amusement at hearing two Brexiteer colleagues being worried about red tape. I guess they would prefer to roll out the red carpet for terrorists. That is something that we should not do. We have to be very serious about the problem that the trade in illicitly obtained cultural goods presents. Over the last few years, we’ve seen that, for terrorist groups like Daesh in search of income, actually, there has been a prospering market of stolen cultural artefacts that links organised crime, money laundering and the financing of terrorist activities across the world. Europe and also the United Kingdom are not free of the risk of becoming a part of such schemes. That is why we had to take action. Only in 2016, for example, two Syrian freezers were seized at an airport in France. Daesh has emerged as one of the key players. It is also destroying, looting and trading cultural goods for profit, but let’s not forget that they also do this to stamp out cultural identities as part of ethnic cleansing, which is among the most significant crimes that we know of. We need to tackle the illicit trade in cultural goods with trade measures and by harmonising rules and building on what we already know without burdening galleries and museums. We have come to a common definition of what cultural goods are and identified those most at risk, and are making sure that we have checks on the origin licensing schemes without placing unnecessary burdens on sellers and SMEs. It’s a success in the fight against terrorism.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking as shadow rapporteur for the INTA Committee for the GUE/NGL Group. Already at the stage of the joint work of the two INTA/IMCO committees, I welcomed the European Commission's proposal to regulate the import by the Union of cultural goods, with the aim of preventing and blocking the illicit exchange of works of art. I would also like to stress the need for such a regulation when we vote in plenary. I think that the text has been improved by the drafting of the two committees: for example, the minimum age of 250 years for works of art proposed by the Commission has been removed, and this allows us to have a wider margin of control over figurative works of art, for example, which may be more recent but not of lesser value. We have also agreed on the easing of procedures, moving from the double licensing procedure to a single one. A website will be set up if the Commission, as I hope, wants to take parliament's position on making information searches easily accessible. I would just like to add a political and cultural assessment. Access to the use of works of art is one of the forms of citizenship building. Making this access accessible to all and all and not letting the arts become contraband goods, especially in those countries suffering from conflict situations, is the duty of these institutions, it is the duty of the European institutions.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the import of finds, artifacts and works of art into Europe is a very delicate process because without controls you can import counterfeit goods, stolen items or even sold to finance terrorist organisations. Whereas previously each country applied different rules, with this regulation we will establish a standardised identification system, we will give appropriate tools to customs authorities to recognise and stop fraud and illegal products, demanding the same controls and training throughout the Union. We also want to provide adequate assistance to those small businesses operating in the art market so that they can continue their honest work without being overburdened with bureaucracy.  Thanks to this regulation we hope to stop the black market in art. That is why I thank the co-rapporteurs and assure them of the support of me and my delegation.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you therefore want to protect the heritage of Syria and Iraq today. It could almost be laughable if it wasn't so tragic. If you wanted to protect the ten-thousand-year-old cultural heritage of these regions, you should not throw it under the bombs, nor leave it at the mercy of Daesh and islamist barbarians who were re-established as rebels for the occasion. On the other hand, it seems that the Commission is no longer even concerned with controlling the entry of people and goods, ladies and gentlemen, it is the responsibility of the States. It's a sad paradox! You who encourage illegal immigration and dogmatic free trade every day, you here profess a "almost" protectionism that leaves dreamy. How do you intend to enforce these perfectly derisory measures? By lowering nation states, you have wiped out their customs administrations. Only they could have acted, in truth, only states could act. You will not have the means of your futile policy, you do not give yourself the means, you advance according to your urges or wishful thinking without men or means. So can we just note, raise or appreciate this act or these efforts. I don't think so. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is indeed the year of cultural heritage, so you are defending the cultural heritage of humanity while you are selling off that of Europe, you are selling off that of my country and my France. Our villages, our steeples, our history, our monuments, our arts and crafts are looted and you neglect them, you sell them blindly and often out of contempt. So we might as well say that this is not the... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: 'blue card' question. "Mrs. Jamet, I have a question. Do you think that nothing should be done, that it is better to wait and leave the market without regulation, without observing what will be used for terrorism? Do you think it is better?

name: France JAMET
text: answer 'blue card'. "Of course not madam, I don't think that's enough. I think that well-ordered charity begins with oneself and I also think that the writer said: "God laughs at men who deplore the effects of which they cherish the causes".

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank you for the good and constructive cooperation on this dossier. Although we all had a common objective, it has certainly not always been easy to find compromises in this dossier. However, I believe that we have a very balanced text – which, according to The ECR opinion, certainly still has one or two shortcomings, but I believe that we have a very good, constructive and balanced result here as a whole. With the Import Regulation, we want to achieve harmonisation of the import rules of cultural goods in the EU, originating not in the EU. This, too, has been misrepresented time and again in the past. We must make this particularly clear here once again, that it is precisely cultural goods that originate in a third country and not in the EU, and the watch of the British great-uncle or grandfather may not fall under that. The general aim is to prevent the illegal importation of cultural goods from a third country and the storage of these goods in the EU, to curb the illegal trade in cultural goods, to combat the financing of terrorism and also to protect cultural heritage – not only our own, but that of humanity as a whole. I think it is right that we have limited the scope as far as possible to the cultural goods that are most affected by illegal trade and which are also of particular importance for cultural heritage. This will prevent unnecessary red tape for the art market, for small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as for customs and national authorities. We have introduced a minimum age, we have introduced financial thresholds, and the International Museum Council's Red Lists (ICOM) are also considered to be additional filters to really limit ourselves to goods that are worthy of protection. So we have achieved a balanced result that i.m. everyone can live with. I hope that we can enter into negotiations with the Council as soon as possible in order to achieve protective and good legislation here.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you know that the illicit trade in cultural goods has characterised the history of all conflicts. Today, more than in the past, this trade is a source of funding for criminal organisations, terrorism and armed groups, as the war in Syria has unfortunately shown. This measure is a further piece of a strategy that the Commission and this Parliament have put in place in this parliamentary term on the traceability of goods entering the European Union, starting with the measure we have taken on minerals from conflict zones. Only through certain specific and harmonised customs procedures at European level and effective coordination between the competent authorities will we be able to prevent the entry of illegal cultural goods into our single market and, last but not least, also to protect the cultural heritage of the third countries from which they come. Finally, allow me to thank the co-rapporteur Alessia Mosca and the rapporteur of my committee and my kohn group for their work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, cultural heritage is one of the key elements of culture. It contributes to the preservation of historical memory and national traditions. For this reason, cultural goods must be protected from illegal ownership, from looting, from their illegal export, and this applies, in my opinion, and must concern all looted cultural goods, regardless of a time limit, even those found in the European Union. Because we are talking about Iraq, but we are forgetting and closing our eyes to what is happening here in the European Union. Once again, I raise the question of the return of the archaeological treasures looted by the Nazis of Greece during the German occupation of 1941 to 1944. These looted treasures are found in museums in Germany. As early as 1946 the Greek Ministry of Education has compiled a detailed list of these archaeological treasures stolen by the Nazis. Under the UNESCO Unidroit Convention 1970 and Directive 93/7/EEC, these looted archaeological treasures must return to Greece. So I ask you, Mrs Bulc: what is the European Commission going to do to return to Greece the Greek archaeological treasures looted by the German troops? I want an answer to that question. Let's not just talk about Iraq. Let's see what's going on here in Europe.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the illicit trafficking of antiquities is estimated at USD 6 billion per year, of which part is certainly contributing to the financing of terrorism. We have rules to prohibit the trade of cultural goods with Iraq and Syria and we also have legislation that regulates the export of cultural goods, but no rules regulating the import of cultural goods into the EU. This gap obviously has to be filled. Unfortunately, the text we have in front of us today is far from perfect. I would prefer a less detailed text that did not impose on the art importers the requirement to provide documents that sometimes they cannot have, and that lets customs authorities concentrate on the goods that can – and could – contribute to the financing of terrorism. I hope these flaws will be corrected in trilogue, introducing smooth dialogue and user—friendly procedures for art importers that will allow them to safely import cultural goods into the EU and, for the goods that run a higher risk of being exposed to illicit trade, setting up a more thorough procedure so that custom authorities have the power and means to properly check the goods in question.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, I very much support the adoption of this regulation, which is clearly aimed. It cannot deal with the situation of Greek archaeological sites, but I consider them to be a very important part of the measures, now, right now, to deal with the fight against terrorist financing. It should be remembered that a huge number of cultural artifacts come from the Middle East region, which is the cradle of our civilization as well. So, as one colleague said, it is sad to watch the suffering of people fleeing the Middle East, but it is also very sad to see irreplaceable cultural values disappear in these areas and abused to finance Islamic State and other terrorist groups. Unfortunately, it is in this area that the biggest problem is with terrorist groups.  This year we have the European Year of Cultural Heritage and many cultural monuments from ancient time, from the beginning of Christianity are subject to illegal treatment in countries outside the EU, such as Syria, Iraq, and we understand them as part of the wider context of Europe's cultural heritage. The regulation in the European Parliament version defines very well the different categories of cultural goods, taking into account unesco's recommendation to apply as a time limit for older monuments 100 years precisely for the most endangered goods. Therefore, this regulation, I think, is worth supporting, and it will be one of the possible instruments to reduce the financing of terrorism.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Commission's legislative proposal on the protection of cultural goods is primarily aimed at preventing the financing of terrorism. There is no question that this is a very central and important task. But we must go a step further, because the robbery and trade of historical cultural goods are causing irreparable damage to all of humanity and its cultural memory. As long as it is possible to trade lucratively with illegally acquired historical cultural goods and to make money without great risks, looting will continue in the future. Consequently, the protection of historical cultural goods starts where they are in demand, that is, on the European private collectors' market. Above all, it is a question of the public having the right of access to objects that are relevant to cultural heritage. These objects must be able to be used for education and also for academic research. I am glad that the LIBE Committee's call for restitution has been included. The return of illegally excavated, stolen and traded objects would thus be secured.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Polish delegation has so far supported the Commission's original text because we recognise that the looting of works of art, especially from areas affected by armed conflict, is a shameful practice that can further finance international terrorism. But in Parliament, this Commission text has been broken, m.in. the scope of the Regulation has been over-extended to include all international trade, which can paralyse customs authorities. Additional obligations have also been imposed on the Union in the form of the protection of cultural heritage in third countries, which is imprecise and may, for example, imply the financing of suspicious projects from the Union budget, moreover, without adequate supervision of them. In addition, as Poland in particular points out, there is, for example, no adequate IT system for registering and operating import declarations. In conclusion, we support, in principle, the fight against abuses and crimes of trade in cultural goods, but real solutions must be developed that our institutions will be able to meet. Hence our abstention from parliament's text.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the illegal trafficking of cultural goods is a serious problem within the EU, on a global scale. It is important to step up the fight against this dangerous phenomenon, including through legislative means. It is therefore a good thing that the European Parliament's proposal for a trilogue negotiating mandate with the Council represents an extension of the existing legal protection of cultural heritage in the EU Member States as well as to the cultural heritage of third countries, as the rules on imports from third countries are not harmonised at EU level. By contrast, common rules for the export of cultural goods already exist in the form of EU regulations. As regards imports of cultural goods, only two specific restrictive measures are in force at EU level in relation to Syria or Iraq. So the general adjustment seems to be lacking and quite strongly. From the proposal put forward, I promise to break the link between the illegal trade in cultural goods and organised crime and the financing of terrorism, while at the same time ensuring legal certainty for the legal market for works of art. The need for coordinated and effective action at EU level is also due to the lack of sufficient capacity by the competent authorities of third countries to combat the illicit and illegal trade in cultural goods, and they are also often exposed to corruption or other forms of maladministration. It should be remembered that when cultural goods are torn out of the environment, the locals lose their customs and monuments or memorable and places of worship. In order to apply the common rules effectively, it is also appropriate that imports of particularly valuable cultural goods should be subject to uniform controls when entering the customs territory of the Union.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a country's cultural heritage, in particular its archaeological finds, its works of art as well as its oldest objects, represent the roots, the historical memory, the identity of a people. With the adoption of the regulation on the import of cultural goods into the EU, the European Parliament, taking on board the line expressed by the CULT Committee, gives concrete form to these words. The European Union has a duty to oppose the illegal importation of cultural goods and to have harmonised rules to protect and protect not only its own, but also cultural goods from third countries, especially those in conflict. Moreover, cultural goods are often stolen and smuggled to finance terrorism, but also for the purpose of money laundering and circumvention. By substantially amending the Commission's proposal, which proposed a minimum age threshold of 250 years in order to define a cultural asset that falls within the scope of this regulation, we have lowered the limit to 100 years, thus bringing us into line with the main international conventions (UNIDROIT, UNESCO, The Hague Convention) and with our existing regulation on the export of cultural goods. Precisely because cultural goods are not just any commodity, we have introduced the need to establish a simplified electronic procedure and a set of rules and documents to demonstrate the lawfulness of their import into Europe. (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I will repeat here what my precious speaker said, my colleague Polčák and my colleague Šojdrová said beautifully. I welcome and support this proposal for a regulation, which, when it is discussed in committees, in the IMCO Committee, of which I am also a member, has taken on some of the other useful changes for the practice. It is obvious, and the reasons have been said here, so I will just repeat this, that we need a uniform arrangements for the European Union at a time when we have uniform arrangements for the export of cultural goods, we need to have one rule on the import of such cultural goods.  In recent years, the intensity of the need for such regulation has increased. It is not only about the illegal export of cultural goods from elsewhere and the cultural heritage of certain countries, especially third world countries, being damaged, but, as has already been said and emphasised here, trade in cultural goods has become a way of financing various terrorist and other illegal activities in recent years. And so there needs to be a stricter regulation, a clearer adjustment, an adjustment that will be applied equally in all parts of the EU. This therefore needs a single regulation, which is on our table here. As I have already said, I welcome the adjustment brought about by the discussion of this regulation in the relevant committees. The IMCO Committee has contributed to the fact that certain inferior works or less old works are excluded from the proposal, and I think that is certainly to the benefit of the cause.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you have heard, the two co-rapporteurs have defined very precisely and very effectively the size of this market, its characteristics and, above all, the distorting phenomena that have taken place within the market over this period of time. I would therefore like to confine myself to highlighting three aspects, quickly. The first is that we are finally overcome the paradox that there was no european structure, a European framework for regulating the import of cultural goods, and i hope for a very short time. That it's not here is really significant, unfortunately. The second is that this lack has allowed for illegal activities such as those that have been mentioned by my fellow Members. So, to ensure that imports have the same conditions as we need to move in the right direction for exports. The third thing, not to be underestimated, is that a legislative system such as the one we are debating will also make it possible in this area to combat the phenomena of tax evasion and avoidance that have so penalised the European economy.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Together with Silvia Costa of the S&D group, we were applicants in 2017 for a pilot program that upupposed the construction of such educational modules, especially for the police, in terms of moving on this market of illicit trafficking in works of art. I am very pleased that this programme is being implemented in 2018, but it is worth expanding. On the other hand, going back to today's debate, I will emphasise four elements which, in my opinion, are extremely valuable and are contained in the document. Firstly, establishing a common definition of cultural goods in transport is an important issue. Ensure that importers are careful when purchasing cultural goods originating in third countries. The third element is the definition of standard information for the purpose of certifying the legal origin of cultural goods. Finally, the introduction of effective deterrents, above all discouraging illegal trade.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it is the first time that you have adopted common rules aiming to halt the illegal import and trafficking of cultural goods from outside the EU, often linked to terrorist financing and other criminal activity. These new laws will make it harder for criminal elements to profit from the export of cultural goods from conflict areas, as has previously happened with treasures looted from Iraq and Syria. Cultural appropriation, modification or destruction as a result of occupation is never acceptable.  I wish to mention a specific example from occupied Crimea, where culture is a matter of great concern, especially regarding the conservation of Ukrainian cultural heritage, the illicit trafficking of cultural property and illicit archaeological excavations. The Russian occupying authorities have registered the illegal appropriation of the 32 historic buildings of Khan’s Palace in Bakhchysarai, and launched large-scale restoration works in total defiance of international law, including UNESCO conventions. This threatens the integrity of the palace, which constitutes a site of national significance for Ukraine, as well as an integral part of the cultural heritage of the Crimean Tatar people.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a sad truth that war, among many other horrific crimes that accompanies it, also leads to the pillaging of cultural heritage. Czech countries have their experience with this, which to this day the unnamed State of the European Union must beg to lend us our own property for a limited period of time.  Today, however, the problem of plundering cultural heritage is on a more and dark level, and that is that it is related to the financing of terrorism. It is no longer enough for terrorists to trade drugs, weapons, people, and now they are trafficking rare artifacts, thereby robbing future generations. At first glance, this may not seem very important, trafficking in human beings is, of course, a much more serious crime, but monuments are often symbols that are related to our identity. Cultural heritage is one of the fundamental parts of civilization and belongs to the cultural memory of humanity. Terrorists do not have a culture and they do not belong to civilisation, and therefore they should not profit in any way in monuments, and we must prevent them from doing so in any way.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, well Iʼve listened to this and I cannot believe my ears. Everyone says, ‘it’s all about terrorism’. Pure George Orwell. The best way to prevent the theft of archaeological objects is to rely on auction houses and the antiques trade, and bringing in all these regulations will simply destroy the antiques trade. It won’t help it. It won’t help you get these things back. It’s total nonsense. I don’t really know what you think you’re talking about. You really don’t understand it. It’s really about socialists terrified that people might pass their wealth on, through antiques, to their children. The gentleman up there mentioned that earlier. He was the only one that told the truth. That’s what you are all worried about. You’re terrified somebody might pass on something to their children, and that’s why you’re so worried. But in the meantime, you’re going to destroy a lot of pleasure for a lot of people. A lot of people like to go to flea markets at the weekend and buy things. Well, that’s all going to be destroyed if, every time somebody sells a horse brass or a candlestick, they have to get 500 years’ worth of provenance on it. It simply won’t work. This shows no common sense, no understanding and there’s utter paranoia about terrorism. If the terrorists want to make money, go short on the markets just before they commence an act of terror. That will make the money for them. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David COBURN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first let me thank again both rapporteurs and all of you for your active participation in this debate. Allow me to stress one more time that with the legislation we are discussing, we cover only antiques and valuable works of art from impoverished or war—torn countries and regions, which are often illegally acquired, sold and imported into the European Union. In addition to damaging or destroying the archaeological sites and the artefacts themselves, illicit trade in looted cultural goods has also been identified as a source of income for organised crime groups and terrorists.  Before I conclude today’s discussion, please allow me to respond to some of your comments.  First, regarding old books. These are not, I repeat, not, placed under import licence requirements. Only a signed declaration or minimum information will be required. On the topic of value thresholds, the proposed regulation does not provide for minimum value thresholds, but provides for a high age threshold of 250 years instead. Neither Unesco nor Unidriot nor the Hague Convention provide for minimum age limits. Parliament’s proposal for shorter minimum age limits comes from the EU Regulation on the export of cultural goods and ranges from 50 up to 200 years. That being said, the Commission could consider minimum value limits as well.  Mr Campbell, you do not need to worry about the grandfather clock. The proposed regulation’s scope does not include European cultural goods created or discarded in the territory of the Member States, so no worries about that.  Let me also stress that the proposed regulation does not concern the cultural heritage of Iraq and Syria. On those we have EU measures prohibiting trade – an embargo basically. The comment related to Iraq was, therefore, completely misplaced.  I would also like to stress again that there is already EU legislation about the return of EU cultural goods between Member States. However, the Directive in question does not have retroactive effect and could not be used for the return of looted art during the Second World War. In this particular case, this would be a matter of negotiation between two Member States and can take place anytime.  A common EU-level approach based on everything that we have heard so far is necessary to ensure that imports of cultural goods are subject to uniform controls along the EU’s external borders. The Commission proposal is a follow—up to other EU initiatives aimed at strengthening the fight against terrorism financing, indeed precisely to prevent the import and storage in the EU of cultural goods that have been removed from a third country illegally and thereby combat trafficking in cultural goods, deprive criminals, terrorists and other warring factions of a source of income, and protect cultural heritage.  From what I have heard today in the debate, I can say that the Commission welcomes most elements of Parliament’s position, which will be put to the vote in the plenary tomorrow.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank all my fellow Members for this interesting debate, which has shown broad support for this proposal. Of course, everything can be improved but, as my fellow Members have pointed out on several occasions in the debate, we have tried to introduce an innovative instrument incorporating methods of collecting and exchanging information, which can be good practice, without burdening small and medium-sized enterprises, while guaranteeing fair trade but, above all, guaranteeing the protection of the cultural heritage of the various peoples. , which is the root of the identity and cohesion of societies. I am sorry that some of my fellow Members are talking about the neuroses of terrorism, we would like it to be neurosis. In the meantime, we believe that limiting forms of funding is our duty, first and then, and an effective way of combating the spread of these organisations. We are therefore confident that a compromise text can also be reached in the Council soon and that the European Union will soon be able to equip itself with this important instrument.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for all their statements. We all have the same goal here, namely to tighten rules to prevent the illicit import of cultural goods, and there is clearly consensus for that across the House. But that doesn’t mean that we support all and every measure that is proposed, particularly those that could punish legitimate traders or keep European cultural heritage out of Europe. That’s what a lot of this text does, and we’ve got to be very careful to make sure it doesn’t do that. The grandfather clock, for example: if that goes outside Europe, you may well not be able to bring it back in. Similarly with the point that Mr Marias was making: if those go out of Europe and you can’t get the approval of the source country to get a licence to bring them back in, under these proposals you’re going to struggle to get European goods back into Europe. No one wants that. I know no one in this House wants that. That’s the point that I’ve been trying to make in these whole discussions, and that’s the problem we still have with this file as it is now. Yes, we need to be very, very strong on terrorist financing and we need to make sure we clamp down on that illicit and serious organised crime route into Europe. But let’s not punish legitimate arts traders, people that have got books – because some books are still covered by this – and a whole range of other European artefacts that we want to make sure can come back into Europe legitimately. That’s all I’ve asked throughout this process. We have a proposal on the table that I’m not 100% happy with. I’m not going to oppose it and I hope that, in the negotiations with the Council, we can come together to get a final agreement that does look along those lines: do what everyone in this room wants to make sure that we hammer down that potential loophole on terrorist financing but that we do not hurt legitimate traders and legitimate people that have legitimate European cultural heritage.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 25 October 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. – Trafficking in cultural goods – from illicit archaeological excavations to the trafuge of works in war-affected territories – is one of the main criminal trades (as well as a source of terrorist financing), but also a serious threat to the world's cultural heritage. This regulation finally introduces a series of measures to prevent the illegal import into the EU of cultural goods illegally exported or stolen from third countries, firstly by strengthening customs control at borders and then by requiring importers to prove the lawful origin of imported cultural goods, namely the legality of export from their country of origin or export. Also very important is the rule providing for technical and financial assistance instruments for SMEs operating in the art market to ensure the effective implementation of the regulation, as well as telematic cooperation measures between Member States and their customs. Stopping the black market in cultural goods means not only combating illegal activity, but above all protecting the cultural heritage of humanity, and therefore the history, traditions and identity of all of us.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. How can we forget the methodical and skilfully planned sacking of the Baghdad Museum, rich in a thousand-year history? Unfortunately, tragedies of this magnitude are no longer rare, especially in a Middle East destabilized by systematic Western interference. The latest avatar is looting by the Islamic State, which is said to have derived about 20% of its revenue from art trafficking, including the site of Palmyra, which has been elevated by UNESCO to a World Heritage Site.  Moreover, even the famous "Arab Spring" saw the Cairo museum stripped of fifty-four priceless objects. The extent and opacity of the sprawling networks at work in this traffic require a concerted Response, both European and international. I am thinking in particular of the UN resolutions establishing moratoriums on works from Iraq and then Syria, while today other parts of the world are experiencing similar tragedies.  I am also thinking of the existing conventions, whereas the main one, that of UNESCO in 1970, has so far only been ratified by about 120 states. Certainly, this text is a step in the right direction, and is balanced and without prejudice to the art industry and its small businesses.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – It is very important that the European Parliament and the Council have adopted a European Agenda on Security to combat illicit trafficking in cultural goods. This initiative aims to prevent the import and storage in the EU of cultural goods illegally exported from third countries, which is likely to contribute to reducing the illicit trade in these goods and protecting cultural heritage, especially in countries affected by armed conflicts.  To this end, the above Regulation proposes establishing a common definition of cultural goods, defining standard information confirming the legal origin of a product, introducing effective measures to discourage the illicit trade in cultural goods, and promoting the active involvement of stakeholders in the protection of cultural heritage.  Moreover, importantly, the principle that the introduction of cultural goods into the customs territory of the Union is permitted only if an import licence has been obtained or a declaration from the importer has been made. In order to avoid circumvention in cases where the exporting country is not the country in which the object originated, a distinction should be made between whether or not it is a signatory to the 1970 UNESCO Convention, where there is a provision to combat illicit trade in cultural goods.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – a report by Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Report by Françoise Grossetête, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, on the authorisation and supervision of veterinary medicinal products (COM(2014)0557 - C8-0142/2014 - 2014/0256(COD)) (A8-0035/2016), The report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the manufacture of medicinal products (COM(2014)0558 - C8-0164/2014 -2014/0257(COD)) (A8-0046/2016), the placing on the market and use of medicated feed and repealing Council Directive 90/167/EEC [COM(2014)0556 - C8-0143/2014- 2014/0255(COD)] - Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Rapporteur: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (A8-0075/2016)

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I come before you satisfied with the work done in recent years with regard to the Report establishing Community procedures on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and the establishment of a European Medicines Agency. Please allow me to take a look back at the work done with my colleagues and the collaborators involved in this, while thanking them for their consistency and dedication, but also for the spirit of collaboration and constructive cooperation. This is because the result of our work is spectacular, with positive implications for national authorities, patients, human and veterinary doctors, farmers and consumers. In September 2014, the Commission presented a proposal that centralised authorisation for the placing on the market for veterinary medicinal products was decoupled from that for medicinal products for human use, which involved amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. whereas, in order to ensure that the provisions of this Regulation are complied with, it is necessary to establish a Community procedure for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and to establish a European Medicines Agency; Although Parliament adopted our position on 10 March 2016, interinstitutional negotiations did not begin until January 2018. The Interinstitutional Agreement was concluded on 21 February 2018 with regard to the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 726/2004 and 5 June 2018 for VMP. The final text was approved by Coreper on 13 June 2018 and on 20 June 2018, following a consensus among the main political groups in the ENVI committee, the result of the trilogues was adopted unanimously.  The final agreement resulting from the negotiations included a number of improvements to the Commission's proposal relating, in particular, to the Agency's revenue and sources of revenue. With regard to the determination of the fees due to the European Medicines Agency by industry, we have agreed with the Council to respect the current practice of codecision. We have also won concessions from the Council on the European Parliament's amendments on the determination of the Agency's revenue sources, the frequency of reporting of The AMR by the EMA, the research of innovative methods and alternatives to animal testing and alignment with the financial regulation. The European Medicines Agency remains responsible under the centralised authorisation procedure for both medicinal products for human and veterinary use.  We have concluded an additional agreement with the Council to bring the provisions on amendments and sanctions of Directive 2001/83 of the Lisbon Omnibus into line with the provisions agreed in the EMA Regulation. As shadow rapporteur in the Grossetête report, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and colleagues on a very good collaboration and a result commensurate with the work done. The new regulation on veterinary medicinal products COM(2014)0558, as a result of interinstitutional negotiations, covers all avenues for granting authorisations to place veterinary medicinal products on the market, ensuring the protection of animal health and therefore also human health, the fight against antibiotic resistance and the competitiveness of farms and the veterinary medicinal products industry.  This interinstitutional Agreement also facilitates the movement of veterinary medicinal products throughout the European Union through better authorisation procedures and clear and up-to-date retail regulations. The main improvements to the Commission proposal resulting from the trialogues were those relating to the AMR package, online sales, pharmacovigilance, data protection, specific procedures for authorising the placing on the market for minor species or exceptional circumstances, environmental protection, homeopathic products. Of course, they represent only part of the success achieved for the six trialogues, 8 meetings of alternative relations and 23 technical meetings.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, it is with the satisfaction of the duty accomplished that I see this vast project to be completed today. Four years, we have been working for four years on this overhaul of the "veterinary drugs" regulation with this triple objective of protecting animal health, and therefore of human health, the fight against antibiotic resistance and the competitiveness of our farms and our veterinary medicine industry. We can say this without blushing, the result is a great step forward for public health. I would like to thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs, Commissioner Andriukaitis and the Bulgarian Presidency, all of whom have achieved this excellent result. For beyond farmers or pet owners, the use of veterinary medicines concerns us all. It has a direct impact on our environment and our diet, in short: on our health. The major challenge of this revision was the fight against antibiotic resistance, while the World Health Organization continues to make alarming findings. According to the WHO, the resistance of antibiotic infections could soon cause more deaths each year than cancer. However, the fight against this scourge must begin in farms where antibiotics have long been used for purely preventive purposes. Thus, in 2015, the use of antibiotics in veterinary medicine was still twice as high as in human medicine. This regulation should make it possible to change this state of affairs in a lasting way through finer surveillance, enhanced supervision of the use of antibiotics, and a ban on the veterinary use of antimicrobials of critical importance to human medicine. It should also be remembered that the first solution is prevention, thanks in particular to biosecurity measures. Antibiotics should only be used as a last resort and under no circumstances to compensate for non-compliance with good breeding practices. Our agricultural model has to adapt to that. These new rules, I would like to stress, are not intended to stigmatize farmers and farmers, whose difficulties we know, but rather to help them to better care for herds, and because antibiotic resistance is a global phenomenon, we were keen to impose in the text the reciprocity of our standards for the use of antibiotics. It's a major success. There will be no more meat imports from countries that continue, for example, to allow antibiotics as growth factors. Gone is the hypocrisy of imposing standards on our breeders that others do not respect. Europe is changing the rules of the game and they will now be the same for everyone. In addition to the issue of antibiotics, the text of course includes other important advances. Through targeted incentives and reduced administrative burden, it will, among other things, stimulate innovation in the veterinary market, which is facing a real problem of treatment availability. It is therefore a comprehensive, cross-cutting approach that promises to transform the world of animal health for the long term and for the better. These changes will benefit all the players in the sector, including farmers and veterinarians, but also for all our fellow citizens who are committed to knowing what they find on their plate. Above all, with its particular conception of health and environmental issues, Europe is thus determined to be at the forefront of the fight against antibiotic resistance.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I too welcome the report of the Regulation on the manufacture, marketing and use of medicinal feed, and for the result achieved together with my colleagues, Mrs Grosset-te and Mr T.N.Sescu. I think in the end the result is pretty positive. After four years of the launch by the European Commission of a package of proposals to update the legislative framework for veterinary medicinal products, stricter standards have been proposed in order to advance the fight against antimicrobial resistance and improve the availability and correct use of veterinary medicinal products in the European Union. The proposal on medicinal feed is part of this legislative package. These feeds — medicinal feed — are a route of administration of veterinary medicinal products, an effective tool for the treatment of animals in communities. As already indicated, the proposal on feed is connected to the new legislation on medicinal products, to the three Regulations. This proposal aims to update the 1990 Directive, which is obsolete in many of its provisions, and to advance the internal market for medicinal feed through legislative harmonisation which will now be established through regulations. The new text regulates the production, marketing and transport of medicinal feed, as well as the correct administration of both animals intended for human consumption and in pets. I would remind you all that, in addition to the specific provisions contained in this text, medicinal feed is also subject to other general legislation on the hygiene and labelling of feed, rules on the marketing and use of feed and additives in animal feed. The first-reading agreement aligns the feed regulation with the agreement on veterinary medicinal products reached by Mrs Grosset-te. We have put a lot of emphasis on coordination, making our trilogue decisions subject to decisions and advances in veterinary drug trilogs as the main instrument. Everything relating to the authorisation and requirements of the veterinary medicinal product applied to feed is regulated in the general text on veterinary medicinal products. We have paid particular attention to the coherence of the provisions designed to increase measures against antimicrobial resistance. In this regard, the ban, which had been in force for years, on the use of antibiotics as promoters of growth is reiterated. Some important provisions: the preventive use of medicinal feed with antibiotics is prohibited. Prophylaxis is prohibited in the European Union. Metaphylaxis is reduced to cases of high risk to animal and/or human health under close surveillance, and express reference is made to the international dimension in the fight against antimicrobial resistance, as set out in Article 118 of the Medicines Regulation. In the context of international cooperation, and in line with the actions and policies of the World Health Organization and the World Organisation for Animal Health, progress in reducing the use of antibiotic-containing medicinal feed should be taken into account on a global scale for animals and animal products from third countries exported to the European Union. Cross-contamination in the manufacturing process has also been a very important issue, and EFSA's proposal will remain within four years.  Finally, thanks to the general coordination with the other two rapporteurs, we have achieved more than optimal results, I believe. I believe that we have achieved an ambitious regulation which will give consumers more confidence in the European Union's livestock products and help us achieve a triumph in our fight against antimicrobial resistance.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, today we are debating a package of proposals for new legislation on veterinary medicines. This includes the Commission’s proposal for new rules on veterinary medical products and medicated feed and amendments to Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 on the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products and establishing a European Medicines Agency. Four years, as mentioned before, of discussions between the co—legislators have made many improvements to the initial proposal put forward by the Commission in 2014. I believe the text before us today provides a legal framework that is modern, innovative and fit for purpose. The package contains very concrete measures to promote more prudent use of antimicrobials in animals and strengthen EU action against antimicrobial resistance. These measures are designed in line with the one-health approach, recognising that human health, animal health and the environment are interconnected. They follow the comprehensive EU Action Plan on Antimicrobial Resistance. You will remember that Commissioner Andriukaitis came to discuss it in this House several times, including last September in this plenary, when Ms Kadenbach’s own—initiative report on antimicrobial resistance was adopted. I’m very grateful to the European Parliament for its valuable support and intensive work during the negotiations, particularly that of the three rapporteurs: Ms Grossetête, Ms Aguilera García and Mr Tănăsescu. Thank you. A few words on the individual components. First, on the key elements of the proposal for veterinary medical products. The text lays down a vast array of measures to tackle antimicrobial resistance. They build on the one-health approach and include: first, a ban on the preventive use of antibiotics in groups of animals; second, restrictions on metaphylactic use; third, the possibility to reserve certain antimicrobials for human use only; fourth, a ban on using antimicrobials to promote animal growth, adding to the 2006 ban on antibiotics as feed additives; fifth, other measures aimed at the prudent and responsible use of antimicrobials. In an ambitious move, the rules on growth promotion and antimicrobials reserved for human use in the EU also apply to non-EU operators exporting their animals or animal products to the EU. In addition, Member States will be required to collect and report data on the sales and use of antimicrobials in animals. This valuable data will support the design and implementation of targeted policies against antimicrobial resistance in the future. The text also aims to the stimulate innovation and improve availability. It provides for a simplified assessment procedure and a data protection period which may be extended by up to 18 years under certain conditions. This will facilitate the development of new antimicrobial veterinarian medicines, both generally and those more specific to mirror real diseases in major species that may not be developed under current market conditions. These measures will be supported by: first, clear and fully-harmonised labelling requirements; second, a simpler system for variation decisions; and third, a risk—based approach for pharmacovigilance and controls. The proposal for medical feed will also make an important contribution to the EU’s work on antimicrobial resistance. It will ensure the economically-viable production of safe medicated feed adapted to the optimal local situation and support innovation in medical pet food. A new area it covers is chronically-diseased pets. The proposal creates the legal framework to enable pet owners to administer veterinary medicines via pet food. Once the new regulations are adopted, the Commission will begin urgent action to support its implementation, notably through delegated and implemented acts. To accompany this package of proposals, the Commission will have two formal statements to make with regard to the reports of Ms Grossetête and Mr Tănăsescu. These have been provided to Parliamentʼs services for inclusion in the record of this debate. The first one concerns veterinarian medical products. On this, the Commission acknowledges the substantial input in terms of resources required by the Member States to implement the new rules on the collection and reporting of data on the sales and use of antimicrobial use in animals. It also underlines its commitment to providing the necessary technical support to Member States to design and implement policies on antimicrobial resistance. And the second concerns the proposed amendments to Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. On this, the Commission will clarify the transition arrangements and state its regret that the alignment of existing provisions with the Lisbon Treaty could not take place under a single legislative instrument. Dear President, honourable Members, to summarise: the adoption of these new regulations on veterinary medicines will mark a major achievement in this field. They will help consolidate the EU’s position as a world leader in acting against antimicrobial resistance and contribute to global progress in this critical area. They will also deliver a stable and harmonised marketplace for veterinary medicines and medicated feed in the EU that encourages innovation and competitiveness and contributes to greater animal health and welfare and food safety. Thank you again for all the dedicated work and I look forward to a positive outcome in tomorrow’s vote. Statements by the Commission  (in writing)  Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on veterinary medicinal products COM (2014)558 final – 2014/0257(COD) “The new EU Regulation on veterinary medicinal products requires Member States to collect and report data on sales and use of antimicrobials used in animals. The Commission considers this information essential to identify possible risk factors for development and spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR), monitor trends in antimicrobial consumption, target relevant policy measures and assess their implementation. Although the implementation of this legal requirement is foreseen through a gradual (stepwise) approach, it may require substantial input in terms of administrative, human and financial resources. The European One Health Action Plan against AMR recognises that in order to deliver long-lasting results and create the necessary impetus, it is important that the EU legislation related to AMR (including, inter alia, on the use of veterinary medicines) is adequately implemented. In this context, the Commission has committed in that Action Plan to engage in supporting Member States in the implementation of EU rules, including by providing technical support through the Structural Reform Support Service (SRSS) for designing and implementing policies against AMR.  Furthermore, the Commission will explore the possibilities for supporting this data collection in Member States in line with its proposals made in the context of the future EU Multiannual Financial Framework.” *** Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of  the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004 laying down Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and establishing a European Medicines Agency  COM (2014)557 final – 2014/0256(COD) “The Commission recalls its position that when adapting existing Commission empowerments to Article 290 and 291 TFEU it is not an appropriate legislative technique to provide for transitional provisions that would state that Commission acts adopted previously under those empowerments will continue to apply unless and until repealed. In the Commission's view such provisions state the obvious and would not be coherent with other legislative acts and are liable to induce legal uncertainty at a broader level. The Commission regrets that only part of the existing regulatory procedure with scrutiny empowerments in Directive 2001/83 and Regulation 1901/2006 will be aligned in this instrument, while the rest of the empowerments remain to be aligned in the context of the negotiations on the Omnibus alignment proposal (COM(2016) 799). In the Commission’s view the full alignment should have taken place in one of the two instruments.”

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Agriculture. – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your instructive words. Indeed, I believe that the European Parliament has managed to put forward some important points. Firstly, it is the separation of the registration of veterinary medicinal contributions from the registration of medicinal products for human use. Furthermore, I would like to highlight the way in which the fees paid by pharmaceutical companies to EMA for obtaining and maintaining a Union authorisation for veterinary medicinal products are paid. In doing so, the specific needs of SMEs have been taken into account, a separate procedure separate from that procedure for the authorisation of medicinal products for human use is being introduced for the marketing authorisation of veterinary medicinal products, as I have already said. And this new centralised registration system should provide a greater guarantee of expertise and efficiency. We have therefore ensured sufficient financial coverage of EMA's work and the European Parliament has also promoted regular reporting on antimicrobial resistance and the allowing of alternative testing methods. These are all advantages, I think very clear and I am very glad that we have achieved this result.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the AGRI Committee – Mr President, antibiotic-resistant bacteria pose a significant threat to public health. As we know, around 25 000 people die each year in the EU from superbacteria. It is good that changes are now being made to this development.  The way we treat our animals also says a lot about ourselves. The welfare of farmed animals is also in the producer's interest, as a well-off animal produces better. The main reason for antimicrobial resistance is the overuse of antibiotics in livestock farming and also in health care. For the first time, this Regulation establishes common rules for the animal use of unnecessary antimicrobials. Thank you for the extensive work that the rapporteurs have been doing for years. Excessive use of antimicrobials really must be abandoned. Once the regulation enters into force, it is prohibited to prescribe antibiotics until the animal has been examined and also found sick. In Finland, this has been a policy for a long time, and it is important that the same rules are brought to the whole eu.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The well-being of animals and humans is closely linked. The risk of antibiotic resistance is therefore problematic for both. This makes it all the more important that we now take countermeasures in veterinary medicine if we do not want to run the risk of antibiotics completely losing their effect. The package now before us sets the course for even better animal health in the EU and creates safety for people. I would like to highlight three successes: antibiotics must under no circumstances compensate for poor animal husbandry conditions. In other words, preventive use is prohibited, herd treatment is only permitted if there is no other suitable alternative. There is nothing to replace good and species-appropriate animal husbandry. Secondly, the use of antibiotics from human medicine is further restricted in veterinary medicine. Thirdly, the mixing of pharmaceutical feed and non-target feed should be avoided. In this way, antibiotics are only used in a targeted manner. Many thanks to my fellow Members for their good cooperation.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to congratulate rapporteur García on her work and thank her for her excellent cooperation as rapporteur from the shadows. This Regulation has succeeded in harmonising the use and marketing of medicated feedingstuffs at European Union level. It is extremely important that there is once again a ban on the use of antibiotics for prophylactic purposes. Small and isolated holdings will only be able to optimise their animal husbandry conditions if established control systems are maintained. At the same time, the prescription, production and use of medicated feedingstuffs should be carried out in accordance with the instructions and under the supervision of a veterinarian. Note that Member States in cooperation with operators are responsible for developing expired medicinal feed collection systems so that they are destroyed in maximum safety after expiry.  The labelling method is to be made in a simple manner, understood by end-users and will necessarily include a warning on the possibility of contamination of persons who are in the vicinity of animals treated with medicated feedingstuffs. At the same time, we have ensured – as is normal, moreover – that products from third countries are covered by this Regulation. These products must take into account future European Union rules on medicated feedingstuffs. Otherwise, the health of European consumers was at risk and farmers in the European Union would have been put in the situation of deep unfair competition.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much, Commissioner. Some time ago, here in the House, we adopted by a large majority the European Parliament resolution on combating antimicrobial resistance within the framework of the concept of 'health'. I believe that the package we are discussing today meets many of the demands and proposals it contains. One of these is the targeted use of antibiotics. One of these is the investment in research and development for the provision of comprehensive, modern and good medicines for veterinary medicine, for animal husbandry. Because we know that even if the best technical conditions are met and animal welfare is respected, it will not be possible without medication. However, it should be done without antibiotics in many areas, and it should be possible above all without the use of so-called reserve antibiotics or critical antibiotics. I believe that this is one of the essential points we are discussing here today, that these antibiotics can only be used for veterinary medicine in very rare – precisely described – cases in future. We think and speak in the One Health approach, which means that we cannot forget here that the question of future agricultural policy will also make a significant contribution to what our animal welfare looks like, what use of medicines we have and where we can do without antibiotics in the future, especially in metaphylaxis. Another important point that has been raised today will be our trade relations, because it is not acceptable for us to put high hurdles on our agriculture and then not to see these hurdles in imported meat.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I fully support what our rapporteurs have set up on veterinary medicinal products. I am pleased that the Commission and then the European Parliament have taken up work on this important subject, and even more so on the fact that it has completed it. It's a great success. I am a doctor, so I think it is extremely important that the regulations on veterinary medicines have nevertheless been clearly separated from the rules on medicinal products for human use. I believe that the negotiated regulations are good because they strike the right balance between the need to increase efforts to combat antimicrobial resistance and, at the same time, avoiding – as is often the case – excessive administrative burdens. I am sure that the European Parliament has also struck a balance between the use of appropriate incentives for the research and development of innovative medicines, while at the same time guaranteeing free access to generic medicines through appropriate safeguards and patent regulations. This, after all, is of great economic importance for agriculture, for example.  The report adequately highlights the role of prevention and metaphylaxis and demonstrates an appropriate cascade of possible use, in particular antimicrobials in animals. It also identifies an issue concerning antimicrobial medicinal products for which a kind of responsibility is taken by data collection, sales monitoring and justified use with a prescription or authorised persons.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I would also like to thank all the rapporteurs in advance. We even have three today: two for the legislative body and one for a resolution. I think this is a really good day today to combat antimicrobial resistance. Today, in a way, we are celebrating the conclusion of trialogue negotiations, and I think it is very good that we have managed to do so. On the one hand, we have now, in fact, separated veterinary medicine and human medicine. We have also said that there must be separate product lines that are available. I believe that this has been an important prerequisite for getting to grips with the problem. We need antibiotics. We need them in humans and animals, but we want them to work. That is why it is important to use it sparingly. Especially in the case of animal husbandry, as my colleagues have just mentioned, it was really common for a while to give antibiotics prophylactic/preventive. This is, of course, not good for the animals or for the people who may eat the meat afterwards. It is good that this practice has been closed for some time. It is now quite clear that we have regulated this by law. We have also regulated through the laws where a veterinarian must be involved and how he must be involved. Of course, vets are always there when it comes to medicines. We have also regulated that antibiotics can be given in a herd even when some animals become ill and the whole herd is in danger of becoming ill. So a lot of it is actually regulated. I believe that if we implement all this as we have decided, if it is implemented later in the Member States, then we have a good chance of actually combating antibiotic resistance.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think we agree that we have taken a great step forward on one of the most pressing human problems, namely antibiotic resistance. Although we have achieved success in reducing the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry in recent years, it is still twice as high in some countries as in human medicine. That cannot remain the case. We risk losing, that antibiotics can be treated in the future, and this is a problem that we are addressing now. Prophylaxis is prohibited, and that is a good thing. And it is now being regulated even more. But we are also approaching the subject of metaphylaxis. I also think it is important that, if one of 30 000 chickens is ill in a stable, the whole barn can then be medicated, but that measures must now be taken to be able to separate the animals. More precautions must be taken. This is a very important step, because otherwise metaphylaxis would have virtually replaced prophylaxis. We need a very clear data collection of how much is being used so that we can track whether consumption is going down. And we must also realise that, before antibiotics are used in the future, it will be very clear that a veterinarian will have to check whether it is really necessary to use these antibiotics. We have really taken a big step forward in many areas. And I would also like to stress once again that it is also a great success that we regulate imports. The same applies to European farmers. This, too, is important in order to implement this ambitious approach also among the farmers and to find understanding there. That is why we welcome this and hope that we have indeed taken a major step forward.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to extend my warmest thanks to an excellently strong negotiating team that was able to work energetically to the end in this long process. According to the International Health Organization (WHO), antibiotic resistance is one of the largest global health threats. Some actors already compare antibiotic resistance to a climate change-length problem because it is global and challenges us everywhere.  In 2017, more than 750,000 people died worldwide from bacterial diseases that could no longer be treated with antibiotics. At the latest, it should also wake us up to even more active action in every Member State. The development of new antibiotics is also a real challenge. Do we have enough input and joint research to create new antibiotics in the world?  Growth-accelerating antibiotics are still used in the food of farmed animals in much of the world, especially in the USA and Brazil. Chinese agriculture, too, has been a heavy user of antibiotics, which has led to the emergence of a whole antibiotic resistance drive in Chinese agriculture. It is important that imported products are also on the same page as the European way of life. Thank you all again.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, this new regulation reaffirms the commitment of member countries and their citizens to the reasonable use of antibiotics and veterinary medicines in livestock. Colleagues from the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, who like me participated in the study trip on Brazilian agriculture, found that this approach is not at all the same on the other side of the Atlantic; similarly, Canada and the United States are very lax in this area, allowing their breeders to use antibiotics as a growth vector or they are overcoming the terrible sanitary conditions of giant farms by massive use of drugs for prophylaxis. In order to preserve the health of our compatriots, the European Union must enforce its standards for the use of veterinary medicines and must clearly ban the importation of products from animals raised under conditions that do not meet these rules. As with cloning and growth hormones, we must remain firm and not tolerate any flaws in these devices. I will conclude by saying that in a very tense context for our breeders, we must above all inform our fellow citizens of the care that is taken to livestock in our European countries with very strict and protective standards for human health.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the issue of veterinary medicinal products is extremely important and affects the health of citizens in various direct and indirect ways. Firstly, we must admit that on the scale at which animals are reared in this day and age, farmers face the risk of rapid transmission of diseases which entail enormous economic damage for them. But the answer to this risk should not be the reckless use of antibiotics, as has been done so far, given antibiotics in the water that animals drink and in their food. Given that with these practices already microorganisms have developed antibiotic resistance with potentially devastating consequences in the future. Moreover, it is well known that through the tropical chain there is a possibility that substances of veterinary medicinal products will be passed on to humans, with whatever risks this poses.
