New forms of livestock farming, mainly organic, should be supported, but in any case far from the logic of concentrating a huge number of animals in the plants, because ideal conditions are created for the transmission of diseases. First and foremost, however, is for all of us to realise how serious the situation already is and what the consequences will be in the future if we do not act today to minimise the use of antibiotics.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Let us imagine that seven fully manned large aircraft crash in Europe every month – not anywhere in the world, but every month in the European Union. 25 000 deaths per year. It is not only Commissioner Bulc, who is responsible for transport and is hopefully listening now, that would be busy day and night solving this problem; the whole of the European Union, the European institutions, would probably care nothing but say: we need to change something. But that is the situation with antibiotic resistance: 25 000 deaths per year! Every day, people die somewhere in Europe because antibiotics have lost their effect. In other words, we must act. We must do the same in human medicine. We need to be more careful with antibiotics, we need better hygiene and we need incentives for new antibiotics. The first points are for the Member States, but the latter is for the European Commission. I am very disappointed that the Commission has not yet put forward any proposals to this effect, despite repeated requests from Parliament. But there is also a need for action in veterinary medicine. This is where we are going to get started: Francoise Grossetéte has produced a very good report, and I am glad that tomorrow we will support the result in plenary by a large majority. I would ask the journalists who are listening to report strongly on this and not just on the problems that have not yet been resolved. We have really achieved something here!

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Mr President, there have already been said here, there are many goodnesses of this Regulation, but I too would like to highlight the most important one in my view: having been able to introduce among its priorities one of the greatest challenges that human health currently has, namely combating antimicrobial resistance. There are twenty-five thousand deaths a year for not having a proper antibiotic. And by 2050, if this continues like this, it will be higher than the number of cancer deaths. Actions are therefore needed in the human and animal sphere, but this Regulation has allowed a clearly comprehensive view of actions in the animal field which are, as has been said here, an example and a source of praise.  It has allowed a restricted use list of antibiotics for human use; has restricted the use of prophylaxis to exceptional and justified circumstances, or metaphylaxis, never to the detriment of hygiene or cleanliness; has made the prescription by the veterinarian essential; has, of course, banned use for fattening or online sales, and has made data collection possible. In short, as I said, a comprehensive vision, a very difficult job, but that I think has been worth it.  My congratulations to each of the rapporteurs who have made this possible. I also support the Commission's request that it now legislate and take a sound initiative so that we can combat this problem from the point of view of human health and human use.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, good animal health is absolutely vital for improving overall animal welfare, food production and, ultimately, human health and well—being. Like humans, animals do get sick. That’s the reality. Sometimes it is necessary for antibiotics to be used, in a sensible manner. For instance, the use of antimicrobial products in livestock is important to restore full health as soon as possible and to stop the disease developing further in the animal or throughout the herd or flock. While preventative use of these products may be necessary under certain conditions, they should never be used as a substitute for proper feed, good hygiene practices in an appropriate environment and animal welfare standards. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in both animals and human beings is a growing cause for concern. I find this agreement strikes a good balance between tackling AMR and also allowing safe and secure access to vital medicines. In the UK we do things slightly differently – I suppose maybe that’s part of the problem – than is the case in the rest of Europe. Veterinary medicines have to be prescribed and we also have a strong distribution system allowing medicines to be distributed by vets, suitably qualified persons and pharmacists, depending on the type of medicine. The system allows farmers and pet owners accessibility to a choice of essential medicines for their animals, but not antibiotics. I am relieved that this agreement allows us to continue with a system that has stood over the past decades. I congratulate all involved in this report.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Thank you, Mr President. Dear Commissioner, everyone is concerned with the environment and animal welfare. I am very concerned about the growing antibiotic resistance. But it is also important to note that in many parts of the EU there is a lot of investment in the livestock sector to invest in a better environment and animal welfare. In some European Member States, for example, the use of antibiotics in the livestock sector has fallen by 70%. My point here today, which I absolutely do not want, is that the good ones suffer from a disadvantageous competitive position for those who have not made investments. I therefore want to move towards a harmonised approach in the areas of the environment, animal welfare and also antibiotics. I am also pleased to see that this legislation has finally put a ban on the preventive prescribing of antibiotics in the livestock sector. So we need to move towards a level playing field at European level, but not just that. I also think it is important that we look at a level playing field compared to products we import from countries outside the European Union. After all, how can you explain to a farmer in the European Union that he has to meet all kinds of requirements, but that his product is next to a product that comes from outside the European Union for which those requirements do not apply?

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, the Greens have been seeking to limit the use of antibiotics on farms for 10 years, and Iʼm delighted to say that the outcome of this regulation on medicated feed is a major advance for human and animal welfare. This regulation will introduce some important rules to reduce antibiotic use, including a total ban on the routine use of antibiotics in medicated feed as a preventative measure and better husbandry practices to be adopted instead. Only vets will be able to prescribe antibiotics in medicated feed in future, and only when there are clear signs of disease in the animals. The length of time that animals can be treated with antibiotics will be limited. For decades the routine use of antibiotics in livestock farming has propped up a system of factory farming where animals are packed into squalid conditions, only to be pumped full of antibiotics and other medicated feed to prevent the outbreak of disease. This has often been allowed even when an animal or group of animals has shown no sign of illness. This has encouraged appalling animal welfare standards and led to antimicrobial resistance, which has caused many deaths in our continent. With 91% of European antibiotics administered to farm animals through the feed, these new rules are a significant step in the right direction. Weʼre delighted to welcome this achievement and would like to celebrate this major advance to prevent the growth of antibiotic resistance that is such a threat to public health.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, the current productivist model, which has been imposed on our farmers and our livestock producers, puts us in the face of a permanent health alarm. They are new diseases that arise or old diseases against which there are no effective drugs. The regulation identifies the problem, but deliberately omits the role of multinationals that here always seek to maximise their monopolistic incomes by discriminating against markets or deliberately delaying innovation. We agree with the principle of centralised authorisation because it will limit the possibility of discriminating against markets, but we believe that support for innovation cannot be limited to giving more benefit to multinationals by increasing the term of patents. Veterinary research is crucial for the future of agriculture and this requires greater support or public research centres, so that science is at the service of agriculture and not at the service of some multinational companies.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, as well-intentioned as this legislation may be, it will be a complete own goal if it renders British livestock producers uncompetitive against meat products from third countries where these rules are not adhered to. I have heard an EU official say: ‘Well we are going to ban substandard imports and we’re going to stand up to the WTO if it challenges us by insisting on reciprocal standards’. However, this is easier said than done, as it requires the Commission to undertake a formal human health risk assessment, which must follow a defined procedure. The Commission has not done this, with the potential consequence that large quantities of meat will arrive into the UK from farms that use antibiotics prophylactically, as a medicated feed. It is even possible that the antibiotics in this feed are of a type that the British livestock industry voluntarily does not use because of their extensive use for human patients. I urge the Commission to delay implementing this legislation until either Brexit is safely achieved or they have squared it with the WTO. In any event, the legislation should use sound science when laying down prescriptive rules for medicated feed: for example, the threshold at which carryover in mills becomes a genuine issue. British livestock vets are high-grade professionals who need flexibility in how they prescribe and use medicines. If this legislation becomes too restrictive, welfare problems may ensue, with culling as the only solution. I hope that the future independent UK government will think outside the box as regards antimicrobial resistance, because big advances have been made in commercial genetics. Among our wild bird population we find genes that will tolerate a bacterial attack and shrug it off after a few days of lethargy. These genes could be transferred into our own poultry so that medicines are not required in the first place. I’m sure that Ms Molly Scott Cato won’t like that, but it is a genuine solution. Above all else, we must educate our consumers into taking antimicrobial resistance seriously enough to insist to the supermarkets they do not expect to see substandard products on the shelves.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I don’t share the enthusiasm of some of my fellow MEPs, but I do echo what the previous speaker, Mr Agnew, a fellow UK MEP, stated: the risk to British farming is huge.  What I really, really am concerned about is the degree of increasing red tape that this proposed legislation will produce. The sheer scale of surveillance and veterinary resources required will merely see more cost to the consumer. Using trade deals as a control mechanism is equally unlikely to help, unless the European Union anticipates CCTV cameras in Chinese and Dutch pork farms and EU vets visiting USA—Argentinian cattle ranches, French—Vietnamese duck and UK poultry businesses.  This legislative framework runs the risk of driving antimicrobial sourcing under the radar, into the cyber—market and potentially into the black market, and we’ve got no assurance that some of the EU trade deals will actually adhere to it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I think this evening is an important moment because the package that is being proposed to us is both a step forward and a real step forward. I would therefore like to sincerely thank the negotiating team for this package, with a special mention for my colleague Françoise Grossetête, who has given a lot on this issue for many months. The package that is being proposed to us this evening is a balanced package to curb antimicrobial resistance, which is - as I have already said, I will not go on forever - a scourge and one of the issues of our time. The proposal before us maintains the ability of veterinarians to advise and sell drugs to farmers. This does not seem anecdotal to me: it is important to maintain veterinary medicine in rural areas, otherwise we risk seeing veterinarians leave in urban areas, where the clientele is of a different nature and where the profitability of the practices is much higher. This report contains a fundamental step forward on the reciprocity of standards: it introduces the principle that we have been waiting for so long in the use of antibiotics for imported foodstuffs. This means that the European Union will no longer import meat from a country that has used antibiotics as a growth factor and comes from the list of critically important antimicrobials. In short, a Europe that strengthens consumer protection, a Europe that secures food, I think we are doing our duty here, the one that our fellow citizens expect.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Even today, antibiotic resistance is fatal if you are prematurely born, if you are seriously ill or if you are undergoing severe surgery. We must therefore stop the perfunctory use of antibiotics in animal husbandry, so that antibiotics really work when you are sick. I am pleased that we are now making progress and that we want to ban the use of antibiotics as a preventive measure to healthy groups of animals. However, there are still many examples where we need to go even further in order to really protect both vulnerable groups already affected by antibiotic resistance, but also animals and animal husbandry. I would therefore like to see even stricter rules on how and when antibiotics can be used, because europe should be a strong voice for a responsible antibiotic policy globally. It is a win-win-win to reduce antibiotics in animal husbandry. It is win-win for animal welfare, for those who are sick today and for antibiotic resistance in the world.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I welcome the fact that, in the new regulation, the European Commission guarantees detailed control of the production of medicated feed and prohibits the prophylactic use of antibiotics, sets labelling requirements, investigates and regulates cross-contamination levels with antimicrobial resistance. I fully support the extension of these provisions to domestic animals.  In my opinion, this regulation can only be a transitional solution, and the aim should be to develop modern rules for the breeding of animals fed with feed based on natural, unmodified ingredients. Ensuring animal welfare and full-fledged organic feed will contribute to the good health of animals, i.e. the production of healthy food, which has an invaluable impact on human health. Ladies and gentlemen, let us promote the idea of moving away from antibiotic therapy in the breeding of food-producing animals.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Directive states that the pricing mechanism in the veterinary sector operates according to completely different rules from that of humans. No, the pricing mechanism always works the same way, but you interfere differently in both markets, so the results are different. Pricing rules are always and will be the same in the future. In this case, we are moving towards the similarization of these regulations, to those that affect people, and therefore towards price increases. And it is to be reckoned with that, whatever your intentions, there will also be consequences. The second thing I wanted to point out is the reference to Article 13 of the Directive on the protection of animals used for scientific purposes. The point here is that Article 13 should be used for testing only as a last resort. But animal drug studies, what are they to be studied for? I think it is unintentional that animal medicines should be tested in humans. My guess is that this is not the idea of the creators, but indirectly led to ill-considered references to such a legislative proposal.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues on their work and on the result they have achieved. Antibiotics must produce effects to save the lives of people who have bacterial infections, not to increase the productivity of farms. I support the limited use of medicinal products in livestock so that it can have the intended effect when it is really necessary to use them. More than 70% of antibiotics produced annually go to the animal and poultry industry. That's how these substances end up on our plates and, without realizing it, we get antibiotic resistance and we don't respond to the recommended treatments. This report also specifies the conditions under which medical-veterinary staff are authorised to prescribe and sell antibiotics and, in particular, as a veterinarian, find this essential. As the former head of veterinary services in my country, I find it imperative that this legislation be transposed as soon as possible into all the Member States of the European Union.  The sale on the internet of antibiotics and veterinary medicinal products for which a prescription is required should be firmly prohibited. Article 108 is not ambitious enough. We need to be aware that the improper administration of veterinary antibiotics poses a serious risk to our health, to our children and to future generations.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, we are all concerned about the use of veterinary medicines as it has a direct impact on our diet, the environment and our health. I am therefore pleased that we are supporting a reduction in the use of antibiotics on farms to limit the presence of resistant bacteria in the diet. In this regard, it is essential that veterinary medicines are not used in any way to improve the performance of farms and to compensate for the non-compliance with good breeding practices. Preventive administration of antibiotics without clinical signs of infection should be strictly limited. Owners and owners of livestock should use breeding animals in an appropriate genetic diversity to a degree that does not increase the risk of disease transmission and isolate diseased animals from the rest of the group. Finally, I am fully satisfied that the centralized marketing authorization for veterinary medicines is dissociated from that for drugs for human use.

name: John FLACK
text: – Mr President, it’s good that Parliament is today making the link between animal welfare and the use of veterinary medicines. It’s no wonder so many drugs are needed when 300 million animals a year live their whole lives in cages in the EU, perhaps only feeling the sun on their backs for the first time on the brief journey to the slaughterhouse, many never feeling grass beneath their feet in their short, sad, exploited lives. This sort of industrial farming is only sustained by ever-more use of antibiotics – unnatural for the animal victims, injurious to human health, the by-products polluting the land and the air. Any decent human being must know in their heart that this sort of exploitation is wrong.  We, as politicians, have a duty to lead and to make the hard decisions people are reluctant to make for themselves. It’s about time we decide the endless cheap chase after cheap food and ever-higher yields must end. It’s about time we stopped corporate greed exploiting animals. I support these proposals.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I support the European Parliament's draft report on the regulation on veterinary products, and I thank my colleague François Grossetête for her work on this compromise. It's about animal health, but it's also about human health. We can't separate one from the other. Therefore, if we want to effectively combat antibiotic resistance, then the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry must change. I therefore agree with the proposal on the possibility of restriction, restriction of antibiotic products for veterinary purposes. This restriction must be complemented by other measures, namely improving breeding conditions, promoting research, reducing red tape when introducing new products. Reciprocity is important. I consider it essential that imports of meat from countries that do not ensure the same restriction on the use of antibiotics will not be allowed. Otherwise, this measure would not be effective enough for the European Union and would be discriminatory for our farmers. I hope that this regulation will be adopted and well applied.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, the set of measures we are discussing here today is of great importance. The increasing resistance to antibiotics is a huge threat. The resulting infections kill at least 50,000 people a year in Europe and the United States and 700,000 people worldwide. These figures are expected to increase dramatically over the next 30 years with 10 million deaths expected per year by 2050. A number that will be higher than deaths from cancer and diabetes, unless we act, and I welcome the rapporteurs, the rapporteurs, for the work done. The limitation of the prophylactic use of microbial agents in animals will benefit from the establishment of Community authorisation and surveillance procedures. The allocation to the European Medicines Agency of specific competences for the authorisation of products for veterinary use through a centralised procedure is also very important. Strengthening the regulatory framework for the manufacture, authorisation and distribution of veterinary medicinal products is crucial. This is where we have to keep working.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, antimicrobial resistance and the consequent ineffectiveness of disease-fighting treatments are one of the greatest public health challenges we face today.  The agricultural and animal production sector has an increased responsibility in the battle against this challenge. This will have to be done by preventing and controlling infections and reducing the need for antibiotic use by applying high animal welfare standards.  Antibiotics cannot under any circumstances be used as substitutes for these standards, but the success of this fight also involves research and innovation in order to stimulate the development of new antimicrobials, alternative therapies and diagnostics that contribute to reducing the use of antibiotics. Incentives for this research should be well present in our priorities. Finally, I would like to congratulate our colleague Clara Aguilera on the report produced.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the agreement reached on the regulation on medicated feedingstuffs, for which I would like to thank my colleague Clara Eugenia Aguilera García for her excellent work, will ensure greater competitiveness and innovation in the agri-food sector, strengthening the European Union's fight against antimicrobial resistance. This is a decisive step forward, which will lead our farmers to be even more at the forefront of animal health and welfare. Moreover, sustainable animal production, with healthy animals treated in a proper environment, has always been a priority for European agriculture in the interests of 500 million consumers. Ladies and gentlemen, the high standards of food safety protection, protection and supervision are among the most ambitious globally. We must be proud of the results achieved in recent years, but at the same time we must ensure that compliance with these measures does not turn into a competitive disadvantage to the detriment of European farmers and breeders in relation to their global competitors. Commissioner, we must continue our efforts to demand reciprocity and respect for our production standards by all our trading partners.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, I would start by congratulating our rapporteurs, Mrs Grossetête, Mr Tanasescu and Mrs Aguilera García. My work in the field of public health has had antimicrobial resistance at the centre of interest and I would like to point out that the incorrect and excessive use of antimicrobial veterinary medicinal products has been and is one of the main causes for which we have today superbacteria that no longer respond to antibiotics. I have worked as shadow rapporteur on the report on the new European Action Plan against Antimicrobial Resistance, and I can tell you that the 2050 estimates of the effects of this situation are grim.  I welcome the provisions by which the prophylactic use of antibiotics will be prohibited and I encourage the correct and prudent use of veterinary medicinal products on the recommendation of veterinarians. Awareness of the risk of self-medication or imprudent administration of antibiotics should also be raised. Without combating the cause we cannot have lasting results on effects.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am not concerned with medical or veterinary problems, I am concerned with safety issues and, from the point of view of this issue so much, very broadly, I would like to thank my colleague Grossetête, who has done a great job, and I stress this in particular, because it is neither easy nor well received in terms of its details. On this occasion, on the other hand, I would like to ask for educational elements, better information addressed not only to those who are professionally engaged in what we are talking about today, but also to those individual recipients of various services in this area. My appeal is dictated by observing the behaviour of anti-vaccines, who make a mess in people's heads by calling for the withdrawal of compulsory vaccination in these basic elements. It seems to me that this is very important.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission is very satisfied that the European Parliament has shown broad support for the one-health approach, where animal and human health are addressed together in the important fight against antimicrobial resistance.  The international dimension in the fight against resistance is equally important, as this problem does not stop at the border. For this, I would like to stress the importance of international dialogue to developing common rules through, for example, a dialogue at the G20.  On the topic of human health, our regulation provides for the development of a list of antimicrobials that are reserved for human use. This will increase the chance of preventing resistance.  With regard to human medicine, the Commission will complete the assessment of other actions which would be the most appropriate and effective.  Regarding effecting controls on third countries, the Commission will pay special attention to the way the measures are applied in third countries, including through controls.  Concerning possible red tape, we have taken into account for a long time now the special needs of SMEs. For example, we dedicated support from the European Medicines Agency to reducing the fees to be paid by SMEs.  I would like to thank one more time all three rapporteurs for their sense of priority and their focus, which led to a successful negotiation of this regulatory package.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I want to thank everyone once again and assure you that I want the two regulations to be implemented as soon as possible, which will benefit all parties involved in the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use, as well as the beneficiaries of these processes and procedures.  Today I can say with certainty that we have regulations that provide better access to medicinal products for human and veterinary use, provide viable and modern measures to combat antimicrobial resistance, reduce administrative burden and promote innovation and competitiveness in these sectors, which gives the European Union a solid legislative basis in this area for many years to come.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all our colleagues who have spoken and supported them. Thank, once again, the shadow rapporteurs because this teamwork is so important and allows us to arrive and come up with a text, a regulation which will be, I imagine, particularly effective. This is a step forward, as I said, and to some of our colleagues who unfortunately are no longer here and who were complaining about a growing bureaucracy, I will say that through this regulation we have put together a new system of pharmacovigilance that is more flexible, more efficient and less bureaucratic, with accelerated procedures that must allow a rapid response of laboratories in case of an outbreak. , for example, without compromising our quality and safety standards, which are among the highest in the world. And then I will also say that we have been concerned about the environment. It is not forgotten. We know that we find residues of veterinary products. As such, the text plans to better assess the impact of these substances on the environment. Finally, when I am told about the extra cost, I think that we are forgetting the human value and what we really want to protect, namely to prevent that by 2050 - as the studies predict - there are 10 million deaths in Europe because of antibiotic resistance. So thank you all and I hope that many of us will vote for this regulation.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in order to conclude this debate, I would like to encourage, as some colleague has already done, the media to disclose the good result we have achieved among all of us: between this whole House, the European Commission and the Council. It is a great result and it is good that it is known, because sometimes only bad things and bad results are known, and this is one of the things that must fill us with great satisfaction. I would like to thank everyone, all the shadow rapporteurs of my Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, all members of the committee, in which we have worked hard to reach an agreement, broad, majority, which society demanded of us today to offer guarantees in the fight against antimicrobial resistance; I want to thank all of them because the availability they have had has been very good; also to my two co-consent colleagues for good cooperation, because this final result would not have been understood without good cooperation; and Commissioner Andriukaitis, who I regret that he is not here — Mrs Bulc has replaced him perfectly — because he also gave great impetus for us to achieve this good result; and the Austrian Presidency, which gave a final impetus to achieve this. Finally, I want to dignify the good work of European farmers, the effort they have made in the last decade and in recent years. They are adapting to the demands of society. They are adapting to what a society with full guarantee of food security requires. All we need is that when we introduce products from third countries, we are as demanding as we are here. I hope it's a battle we won soon too, as we won today. I hope that the result will be very positive in the general interest of all Europeans.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Allow me to express my personal satisfaction. It is pleasant to preside over the debates that take place in such a creative, sympathetic, mutually understanding atmosphere, as well as applause, regardless of the political side that speaks out. And the applause is from all over the room. I close the joint debate. Vote on Thursday 25 October 2018

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the report by Christine Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the charging of heavy goods vehicles for the use of certain types of infrastructure (COM(2017)0275 - C8-0171/2017 - 2017/0114(COD)) (A8-0202/2018).

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the presentation of this report today marks the culmination of a long work cycle of almost two years on a text fundamental to the future of European transport policy.  The revision of the European directive which regulates road pricing systems over 136,000 km of the trans-European road network represents a unique opportunity to better take into account the impact of road transport on our society. The reason we are revising this text is because the 'Euro-fee' directive, which has helped to combat discrimination between residents and non-residents, has now reached its limits in terms of contributing fully to the objectives of the Transport White Paper to move towards the full application of the principles 'user-pay' and 'polluter-pay' principles. Without a strong measure and a long-term vision of the evolution of road transport pricing, which accounts for more than 70% of emissions from the transport sector, we will not meet our climate targets and we will not respond to the urgent need to better combat the scourge of air pollution that affects our citizens.  In the face of these emergencies, attitudes are changing and road users are increasingly aware and sensitive to the environmental impact of road transport. And it is from this perspective that we, as policy-makers, will have to show courage and will to accompany and accelerate this awareness and the transition to fairer and more environmental road pricing and I would like to take this opportunity to salute the Commissioner's political courage in putting an ambitious text on the table. The extension of the scope to all heavy vehicles and light vehicles, the phasing out of sticker systems or the obligation to adjust tolls according to CO2 emissions, are all measures that I support and which are reflected in the report to be presented to the vote tomorrow.  And the work in the parliamentary committee has improved the European Commission's proposal. Firstly, with regard to the 'user-pay' principle, the Committee on Transport adopted my proposals to advance the end of the vignettes to 2023 for heavy vehicles and 2026 for light vehicles, in order to accelerate the transition to fairer pricing based on distance travelled. Regarding the "polluter pays" principle, the Committee on Transport voted in favour of the application of specific charges related to pollution standards from 2021 for heavy vehicles and from 2026 for light vehicles. It is a proposal that will better take environmental and societal costs into account in road pricing and ensure that around 50% of the trans-European road network will be covered by the 'polluter pays' principle.  Alongside the application of these two main principles, the acceptability and transparency of toll systems are at the heart of this report.  First, throughout this work, I have placed central emphasis on the territorial and social dimensions of road infrastructure pricing policies. And to combat the territorial divide, I propose to introduce the possibility of lowering the cost of tolls for frequent users, especially on the outskirts of urban areas and in remote areas. The current directive did not give this opportunity to differentiate toll rates between frequent and occasional users. This is a major step forward that I am proposing to ensure that users who have no choice but to use their car daily to get to work can benefit from a preferential rate compared to casual users.  Also on territorial cohesion, I also propose to give Member States more flexibility to take into account the impact of tolls on peripheral regions. Secondly, I am convinced that introducing mandatory arrowing of royalty revenues to combat the degradation of road networks and to promote the transition to sustainable mobility, the acceptability of tolls will be strengthened. The tragic incident of the collapse of the Morandi point in Genoa reminds us of the cruel lack of investment in the maintenance and safety of road infrastructure in Europe. The proposals in my report that establish mandatory arrowing will ensure that toll revenues will be used to ensure the safety of road infrastructure.  In conclusion, I would like to reiterate the importance of approaching my report as a coherent whole. Proposals for the application of the principles "polluter-pay" and "user-pay" cannot be analysed without taking into account all proposals to strengthen the acceptability and transparency of tolls.  Finally, I would like to thank all the people and organizations with whom I have had constructive exchanges to achieve this balanced and ambitious report.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Transport and Tourism and particularly Ms Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy and the shadow rapporteurs for this ambitious report on the Commission’s proposal to revise the current EU rules on road charging. The Commission proposed a major step to put into practice the application of their polluter-pays and user-pays principle, and I am very glad to see that our level of ambition is shared by the European Parliament, which wishes to go even further in some cases. The proposal presented by the Commission last year as part of the first mobility package aims to make sure that national charging schemes converge. The intention is to modernise charging for trucks and buses and, for the first time, to apply some common principles to cars and vans. To be very clear, we would leave it to Member States to decide whether or not to charge for any infrastructure, but if they decide to do so, they would have to conform to common principles. As a contribution to forward-looking climate change policy, we propose to modulate tolls to reflect the level of CO2 emissions. At the same time, we would simplify the application of external cost-charging to address also other forms of pollution. More regular and thorough reporting on the revenues generated by charges should ensure transparency and, importantly, improve access by users. I very much welcome the wide support for the Commission’s proposal behind the changes proposed by Ms Revault d'Allonnes Bonnefoy. I also know that many amendments in her report aim to go beyond the Commission’s proposal. I believe that your position could ease the discussion later on with the Council. At the same time, in some cases we need to be cautious, as amendments might be difficult to implement. Let me highlight just five key points. First, on the transition to distance-based tolls. I am happy to see that Parliament wants to speed up the transition from time-based user charges to modern and proportionate distance-based tolls. This could ensure fair and efficient road pricing, which is a key element of our policy aiming at the decarbonisation of transport. On the second point – on external cost-charging – we consider that the simplification proposed should make external cost-charging more appealing to Member States. This should help them to tackle the problems of air pollution and noise generated by road transport. At the same time, one should be careful when setting minimum charges both for external costs and for congestion. As actual costs differ between Member States, the Commission favours reference value rather than minimum. On markups, the Commission welcomes the simplification related to the application of markups. These measures can help Member States to finance transport infrastructure of critical importance and thus reduce congestion and environmental damage. Having said that, markups can represent a significant increase in the toll – up to 20% – and it is thus essential that they are applied in full transparency. The notification of such schemes to the Commission is there to ensure such necessary transparency. On discounts counts for frequent users, the Commission is also open to consider appropriate discounts with respect to frequent users who might be most affected by tolls, and it is understood that this has to be done with sufficient safeguards to avoid discrimination against occasional and transit traffic, while following the same common principles. Last but not least, on earmarking. Even though the Council might favour a different approach, I am convinced that the earmarking of toll revenues and the more detailed reporting you propose could contribute a great deal to acceptance of tolls by the users as well as, of course, ensure badly-needed financial means for maintenance of transport infrastructure. I am very much looking forward to the debate tonight.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. For 20 years, we have tried to put in place a single European system, a system for charging more than 3.5 tonnes on our roads for modes of transport. However, the previous directives have done so very poorly. The consequence is that today in Europe we have a patchwork of sometimes non-interoperable user charges, tolls or vignettes with or without adjusted external costs. This mess does not do justice to our current environmental ambitions or to those of an integrated transport market. In order to remedy this situation, the following points were particularly important to me: firstly, the inclusion of light commercial vehicles, which are in direct competition with lorries over 3.5 tonnes. However, we are not burdening craft enterprises, but we are only concentrating on the professional drivers who are covered by the regulation on the rules on access to the market for cross-border freight transport – access to the market. Secondly, a uniform application of external costs with incentives to invest in clean vehicles with a technologically neutral approach. Thirdly, greater transparency on the use of the fees charged. This is a particularly important point for me, because we absolutely need more investment in our infrastructure. Even economically well-positioned Member States have considerable catching up to do. I voted against a European set of rules on congestion charges. I believe that this will not solve the problem of congestion on our roads. However, the directive does not only deal with lorries, but also with passenger cars. I am clearly answering the question of whether these should fall within the scope of this directive. Why do I think so? The rules on mobility for our citizens must be simple, efficient and non-discriminatory. It is therefore important that each country respects the same rules. That is why I support the phasing out of vignettes, and I believe that this is not fair and does not do justice to our political aspirations today. This report also offers a number of incentives to invest in clean vehicles, and Member States retain the option of granting a number of exceptions to competence. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur and also the shadow rapporteurs for their work.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, welcome, Commissioner. It is clear that we are increasingly moving towards the principle of 'the user pays' and also that of 'the polluter pays', although I believe that in the context of this proposal it should also be taken into account that, when talking about zero-emission vehicles, if zero, it is zero. And, therefore, adorning them with other things might be complicated, and I see that for the Greens, in some cases, even zero-emission ones are not acceptable.  In any case, in peripheral countries, such as Spain or Portugal, or others, we are increasingly being forced to pay by distance that actually places a burden on many of our trading products, which are sometimes or often of low added value. We therefore, in any event, thank the rapporteur for taking special account of the territorial and social dimension in relation to both peri-urban areas and peripheral areas. And, therefore, we totally reject the Greens' attempt to end these possibilities, with that capability, since there are countries that are not only peripheral, but through which the train does not pass because there is no way to pass the train across the border and, therefore, at least, that approach needs to be possible. Some reservations: identifying motorcycles or trying to integrate them largely into cities, especially after the great crisis experienced, has been a good alternative, on the one hand, to save congestion.  We also find that there is some problem in the equalisation, not clearly different, between heavy vehicles and light commercial vehicles, which can lead to clear harm to SMEs; at the very least, we would like to make it clearer in subsequent negotiations in that case. And finally, also in relation to reservations: a certain unilateral obligation that only those who have an on board unit or a subscription can cope with that step. And, of course, I agree with the application to transport; even from Spain, where we have always had problems with the Treasury, we could be open to fees being applied to mobility and transport.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Europe, of course, needs a modern and secure infrastructure, and this requires considerable investment – this is truism. We understand the need to raise new funds for this purpose and fully agree with the principle that it is the users who contribute most to road wear and tear who should bear the most of their maintenance and construction costs.  Unfortunately, this report goes well beyond this objective and also covers passenger cars of individual road users. This is a huge burden on the citizens of the Member States and a significant financial barrier to access to cheap and, in many regions, the only common means of transport, which is their own car.  We also have serious concerns as to whether the closed catalogue of targets for which road toll funds can be allocated is equally responding to the investment needs of the various Member States. In the opinion of the ECC Group, such ideas go well beyond the commission's proposal, which is why we cannot support this report in tomorrow's vote.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I thank our rapporteur for the quality of her work. In fact, two recent events have shown us how topical this topic is. The report of the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change), which has shown an increasingly worrying climate situation, and we know that transport is unfortunately an element that is not under control, and the tragedy of the Morandi Bridge, which showed that infrastructure perhaps deserved a little more attention from our Member States. The European framework for taxing externalities and road users must restore two goals: to be fair and to be effective. And when you look at the chaotic landscape in Europe on taxes on road users, you can say that the work is considerable. We must in fact return to the externalities of each one: depending on the type of vehicle but for all vehicles, according to the kilometres travelled, taking into account the uses, the hours, the place, the existing concessions, it is also an important subject, since there are already perimeters granted - and also encouraging the improvement of the fleet with positive discrimination for the vehicles that are the least polluting. It is up to everyone to decide whether or not to remove unfair and ineffective mechanisms, including vignettes, and of course we support this proposal. It will be up to the Member States to determine whether this scheme applies or not, but it will at least put an end to a totally unfair and totally ineffective situation. Of course, the tax is not popular, especially when it affects all vehicles. But can the situation be allowed to deteriorate, with rising emissions, major consequences on human health in terms of particulate matter and degraded infrastructure with security problems that put human life at risk? It is desirable for Member States to place this scheme within their national burden framework on road transport and make the necessary adjustments. It is desirable that they agree to allocate their revenues to the object that generates them. All this requires the efforts of the Member States, on the part of the citizens and on the part of our Parliament, which, following the Commission's proposal, will no doubt make its contribution tomorrow, by voting by a vast majority, I hope, in favour of this important text.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Every locomotive in the European Union has to pay a toll on every kilometre of the route. On the road, tolls are voluntary. This should remain the case in Germany, for example, only on motorways, some other roads and for trucks weighing 7.5 tonnes or more. 100% of the rail network is tolled and 1% of the road network. In this way, the environmentally friendly rail system becomes expensive and the climate-damaging road is made cheap by politics. This is crazy, but sad reality, and that must change. We need, at least, fair competition. Every car in the EU is still subsidised by the taxpayer with EUR 1 600 per year because climate, accident and noise costs are not taken into account. The vignette is not only unecological, but also antisocial. For 10 000 kilometres it is just as expensive per year as it is for 200 000 kilometres. Therefore, the vignette must be abolished and replaced by a distance-based toll. We had a large majority in committee for this, and I hope that we will get it here in Parliament. We want a minimum amount for the toll, not a maximum amount. In mountainous regions, they can then estimate the real costs. And frequent drivers must also be treated on an equal footing. There is no flat rate on the railways; why should they be on the streets? Then do it on the railways, so that we at least have fair competition! Transport is the only sector in Europe where emissions have increased since 1990, by 28%! In industry, we have achieved a reduction of 38% with billions of our taxpayers' money, in households by 24%, and only in transport. Transport therefore eats up twice and threetimes what has been achieved in other sectors with billions of our taxpayers' money. That is why we need to change mobility in order to stop climate change and so that our children and their children have a chance to live on this planet. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and my dear colleagues for the good constructive cooperation that has been done on legislation. If, as I hope we do, we want to achieve common climate targets in balance, in line with burden sharing, then a wide range of measures must also be taken in the transport sector to reduce emissions. The legislation before us today is also one part of this work to reduce emissions. And so that we can have fair, usable systems that work for everyone, smart and still easy to use, at least guarantee the possibility of the best acceptability between citizens, i.e. users.  I personally would also have been prepared to earmark funding precisely because our existing transport network, our basic road maintenance network throughout Europe, is in very poor condition. There are, of course, many accidents, with very unpleasant consequences and loss of life. So there's an order for an earta mark. Public transport should be taken into account in such a way that we are able to reduce the performance of individual vehicles on European roads. Thank you for your cooperation.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, again this Parliament and the Commission show that they are out of touch with the public opinion. The British public have many times rejected road tolling and road pricing and since your attempts to implement road charging on British cars have failed, you have now set your sights on HGV drivers. This report will only lead to increased costs for hauliers that, like all forms of hidden taxation, will pass on to the public. With the rising tide of Euroscepticism, how do you think the public will feel when their services and food become more expensive because you have increased transport costs? UK hauliers have already been hit hard in the pocket by paying for unnecessary training from the EU’s Driver Certificate of Professional Competence. This was an insult to the common sense of long—standing hauliers. Not only did this cost far too much for the self-employed, it has actually caused a huge shortage of hauliers in the UK. So what is your answer to this problem? To make drivers pay even more to use the roads that they have already paid for through fuel duty, HGV road user levy and then VAT to top it off. This is just bonkers. Hauliers already have far too much paperwork to do when dropping goods off in the UK and the last thing they need is more paperwork. If you carry on at this rate, each driver will need a personal assistant and a filing cabinet in their truck just to meet your demands.  In summary, this report will increase the cost of goods for our citizens, exacerbate the shortage in this industry and increase the bureaucratic burden on drivers across the UK. That is why I am calling on all of you to vote in favour of my rejection amendment tomorrow.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the What has gone into you? I wonder, and I am sure that many motorists in Europe are wondering, ladies and gentlemen. Because what we have here is a originally good thought – and it is also so nicely written up here: Charging of heavy goods vehicles, an originally good thought – now this is happening. What happens to this? It also completely misses the title. What is happening here is a complete misnous, and it is also a sham, ladies and gentlemen, because a kilometre-based toll for passenger cars is to be introduced here through the back door. What happens to that? I am punishing people who have to drive a lot of cars and the emphasis is on having to. Very few people drive around our streets for fun because they just want to drive around the area. These people have to drive because they have to get to work.  I will tell you one thing: this too must not become a luxury. Driving must not become a luxury. If I look at Austria alone, if you make calculations, for example from Graz to Hartberg, there are additional costs due to this kilometre-dependent toll for passenger cars of 1 570 euros per year, if I assume only 5 cents for the calculation for the road kilometre driven. It will be particularly delicate if we also add to a report to be voted on tomorrow, namely the promotion of clean and energy-efficient road vehicles. It says that the use of e-buses should be encouraged. Now, however, many transport companies have already switched to new diesel buses. In Austria alone, this would result in additional costs of EUR 1.1 billion over 20 years. But what does that mean, ladies and gentlemen? Do you want to bring traffic to a complete standstill, or what is your ulterior motive? I can only tell you, to those who consider this to be at least a nonsensical event: vote in favour of my amendments tomorrow! I believe that it would be necessary in the interests of the working people of this Europe.

name: Andor DELI
text: – I believe that the principles of 'user pays' and 'polluter pays' in relation to tolls are not contested, but there are two other principles that have been ignored by both the European Commission and the reporting woman in the proposals. This is the principle of subsidiarity and social equity. The inclusion of passenger cars in the scope of the Directive is a serious violation of these principles . Make no mistake: tolls must compensate for the environmental impact caused. But how do you achieve this, what measures, track fees or excise duties on fuel, vehicle charges? This should remain the responsibility of the Member States, since the level of the Member States is the most appropriate to strike the right balance between environmental, economic and social aspects.  Banning time-based vignettes for cars and making distance-based fares mandatory does not solve environmental problems. Moreover, high fares increase traffic on secondary roads, which increases the risk of accidents and equally harms the environment. Furthermore, the financial situation of citizens in the Eastern European Member States does not allow the mass purchase of new and expensive greener cars, and regional economic differences must therefore also be taken into account, so that the principle of social equity can be applied.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The EU TollS Directive addresses the question of what taxes traffic must pay on Europe's roads. In short, who pays how much for road use? This is not just a pressing issue of transport policy. No, this is also an important issue in environmental policy. As a Tyrolean, I know full well that noise, air pollution and congestion are an enormous burden on the population. In particular, freight transport is responsible for a large part of CO2 emissions from the transport sector. We are making far too slow progress on the shift to the railways. That is why we need a truth in the cost of commercial freight transport. However, as long as there is no uniform toll system for private cars throughout Europe, I am in favour of maintaining our Austrian motorway vignette. I shall therefore vote in favour of clean truck traffic and the preservation of the Austrian vignette.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, citizen involvement is essential, together with public policies, to achieve the objectives set out in the White Paper on Transport. Intelligent, more sustainable mobility that ensures the free movement of people and goods in the internal market.  Rationality in the establishment of infrastructure fees and transparency in the use of resources obtained through this means are a key part of achieving it. That is why I support the measures proposed here to eliminate discrimination between users, prevent these rates from distorting competition in the internal market and to provide compensation for intensive users.  In addition, we are committed to weighing the level of emissions from vehicles when setting prices and, of course, I think it is essential — and I expressed this in my amendments — that the revenue from this route goes directly back to improving infrastructure. This measure will improve road safety, impact employment and accelerate the development of smart infrastructures and more sustainable mobility.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all the words have been used.  We said :"we have to save the climate," "the house is burning but we're looking elsewhere," "we're dancing on a volcano," "all the indicators are red"! Today, we have a lever of action: a levy on HGVs and all vehicles, calculated on the kilometres travelled and taking into account pollution and noise. That's almost 30 billion euros a year! To do what? To finance the mobility of everyday life, clean transport for citizens, secure infrastructure, to revive rail freight. However, some in this Chamber refuse this project! Who are you kidding? Citizens who can no longer breathe because of air pollution, citizens who see their infrastructure collapse, like the Genoa bridge, citizens who expect their elected representatives to implement the principle of "polluter pays" to save the climate, because it is common sense. The climate does not wait for our responsibility or our security. So I invite you all tomorrow to adopt this excellent text!

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of road tolls is particularly sensitive because of the environmental and safety consequences of infrastructure. We have supported in the text the principles that 'the user pays' and 'the polluter pays', because it is right that the costs incurred by users depend on the actual use of a given road route and that there should be uniform conditions in the different European countries. At the same time, however, it is important that the tolls collected are reinvested in the maintenance of roads, tunnels, bridges and viaducts, especially in the light of the recent sad events in Italy. Let us not forget that the objective of the toll is to recover the costs of the investments made and to bear those for maintenance, modernisation, innovation, sustainability and infrastructure management. We will support the objective of greater environmental protection and the reduction of road congestion during future negotiations with the Council. We will fight to prevent tolls from being a source of enrichment for private individuals, and therefore for dealers, who pursue the logic of profit alone, forgetting the importance of the safety of road users and the environment, leading to the paradox of increasing costs in the absence of concrete benefits for citizens.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: Mr President, we share the fact that some Member States are deteriorating, insecure and under-maintaining the roads of some Member States. However, your answers to this problem are at odds with the interests of our fellow citizens. France, like many Member States, is crossed daily by thousands of foreign lorries not involved in the maintenance of our roads by tax. Your proposal is to ban the Eurovignette model, which has proven its worth in Sweden or Denmark, and to impose a principle of Europeanisation, which France has experienced stinging failure, via ecotax gantries. There are no distinctions for vehicles in our states, which will have to pay even more for the financing of their country's roads, to which they already contribute heavily through taxes. Worse still, you want to tax more individuals who have to use their vehicles daily for their personal and professional lives. In France, fuel taxes have increased by 25% in 10 years and will jump again in 2019. We say "no!" to your desire to hit our carriers and motorists again in the wallet and want national solutions to tax foreign trucks that do not contribute to the maintenance of our roads.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, we have yet another opportunity to discuss this issue which, among the many issues that affect the economic development of our continent, plays such an important and transversal role that we are forced into increasingly strong and increasingly European political positions. Without effective and efficient transport, there is no possibility of real development and sustainable development, and let us not forget that development, and therefore also transport, is sustainable not only if it respects the rules of environmental protection, which we want to see respected, but is sustainable if it also takes account of the economy and keeps it in time. So, from the point of view of the game we are discussing today, the criteria introduced and maintained in the report, that is, 'the user pays' and 'the polluter pays', are criteria that we fully support. I believe – and the experience of my country, Italy, clearly documents this – that the introduction of the remote toll criterion is sufficiently reliable to comply with these pillars. It is also true that there are many other elements which have a positive impact on respect for and protection of the environment, but they must not be added to this criterion of distance, which is more than sufficient. Otherwise, the burden on those who use transport would become such as to turn transport no longer into a resource for development but into a cost that, quite rightly, the citizens would reject.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the Commissioner, thanks also to the rapporteur for her excellent proposal, which I obviously support, because I think that the emphasis really is on pollution, traffic congestion, all the elements that are unfortunately capable, and do, of affecting people's health, or even the death of people. So we finally have a concrete proposal, let us move on to the principle of the 'polluter pays' and the 'who uses pays' and therefore to an aspect that is that of distance and no longer of time. I am also in favour of having a postponement for Member States to 2026 for cars and I stress the importance of not harming commuters, because we already have the heavy effect of urbanization and therefore we must safeguard the most remote areas, as well as ensure that this directive is not affected by the fact that we allow people to go on secondary roads. , so the traffic congestion tax is also fine.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The transport sector is the only sector where emissions have still increased since 1990. If we are to achieve the objectives we have set out in the Paris Agreement, it is time for road transport to start paying for its environmental costs. Distance-based charges for heavy-duty vehicles are a step in the right direction. This makes freight transport by fossil-powered trucks more expensive, but thus strengthens the competitiveness of freight transport by train and by boat, thereby also providing incentives for the environmental efficiency of truck transport. However, it is incomprehensible how conservative groups propose that the revenue from the kilometre tax should go to new parking lots or motorways. It is completely unreasonable and undermines the green transition to a sustainable transport sector. So it is time that we now take responsibility and vote for offensive instruments that provide incentives for green conversion in the transport sector.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. I am a little divided on this directive. I welcome it with regard to lorries and light commercial vehicles. In the case of cross-border transport, Europe is called upon to draw up directives here. Coming from a troubled country such as Austria – I am reminded of the Brenner and Tauern motorways – I can only welcome this. What I do not understand at all, however, is the inclusion of cars in this directive. There is a lot of argument here. But what really happens? We increase the fee on the highway. What do motorists do? They go to the small-scale road network. This puts citizens at risk and puts the environment at risk even more than it already is. In addition, as we all know, the risk of accidents on the small-scale road network is 13.5% higher than on motorways. That is the first thing. The second thing that really needs to be said is: how does Europe actually come to educate itself, since it has to make regulations for all states? I in Austria pay mineral oil tax, which is a mile-based fee and levy. I pay CO2 tax through the car tax, and we still pay a NoVA. Why not leave this word 'subsidiarity', which is on everyone's mind, to really work and take it into account when we make a Directive at European level that cannot apply to Member States? (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, Mrs, because you have opposed the fact that a regulation is being made throughout Europe: but it exists on the railways. Are you then in favour of abolishing the rail toll for passenger rail vehicles, so that those who often use public transport by rail will pay less? Are you there for fair competition, or do you care? This is the environmentally friendly rail, which we can make expensive, but the road, which is harmful to the climate, must be cheap, even in the future.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Cramer, I would like to thank Mr Cramer for his work. I am still with you. Of course, I support anything that increases the competitiveness of the railways. But it is not acceptable to tax cars more and more without anything happening on the railways. Of course, I am in favour of putting goods on the railways, and of course I am in favour of developing local transport. But what does this have to do with the fact that I have to make a Europe-wide regulation for cars? That is incomprehensible. And I say that it is still the competence of the Member States to do something about this. And this competence should be left where it belongs: with the Member States, not with Europe.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I really wanted to thank you. This discussion is getting lively here, and I think this is the moment when questions of their original nature have to be answered. If we look at this directive, we have to answer four questions. Question one: do new legal and financial solutions counteract the degradation of europe's road networks? This degradation is, after all, a fact. Secondly, are the proposals from Parliament and the Council likely to move to greener vehicles more efficiently? Thirdly, will the level improve in terms of the safety of all road traffic, but also, importantly, do drivers have a chance of better working conditions? Fourthly, will it become more common that road users too will be involved in improving the environment? My answer to these four questions is a positive answer in total, which is why I believe that we should be actively working on this directive.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr Air pollution is a huge social and environmental cost. Poisoned air is a shorter life for the people of the European Union. I think that anyone who respects the environment, respects others, will look at this directive. I am very pleased that we are introducing the 'polluter pays' principle. At the same time, I am glad that we have moved away from this principle that you pay for travel time. That would be punishing those who, through no fault of their own, stand in traffic jams. I am pleased and support this proposal that you pay for distance.  On the other hand, I join those doubts raised here by Claudia Schmidt that those charges would apply to users of private cars. This is the responsibility of the Member States, and here we should not pass on this burden to the often not very wealthy private road users. So I hope that the amendments that have been tabled in the course of this directive, concerning private users, will find a majority in this House. But of course I agree with all those voices that say that you have to take care of the environment, fight before it's too late.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. With the traffic it is a bit like with the blood and the veins in our body. Transport is like blood and transport infrastructure, like veins. Of course, the economy needs transport. Mobility is one of the great achievements of our time. But as in our body, high blood pressure can occur, and in the end it can also lead to infarction. I myself live on a motorway that is very close to the infarction, on the Brenner motorway. There are 2.2 million lorries thundering across the road every year, and this is compounded by a very sensitive area. Such an infarction will not benefit anyone. It does not benefit the road or the road users who are stuck in traffic jams, and certainly not the residents, who then have to suffer all the dirt. That is why we need a sustainable transport policy. This report is indeed a one-way move. It recognises that transport must also be managed, that transport causes infrastructure costs and that transport incurs external costs. These external costs are particularly high in sensitive areas such as mountain areas. That is why the approach of this report is correct, that the calculation of these external costs must be higher in mountain areas. That is why I am convinced that we should vote in favour of this report. In any case, I will do so myself with great pleasure.

name: Innocenzo LEONTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Directive 1999/62/EC (the so-called Eurovignette Directive) provides a detailed legal framework for the collection of tolls on heavy goods vehicles using certain roads. While I broadly agree with the objective of making toll systems more transparent, by stepping up monitoring of how revenues are used and also by supporting the intention to promote the gradual harmonisation of vehicle taxes and the establishment of fair mechanisms for charging infrastructure, there are a number of aspects to which I would like to draw your attention. In Italy, the economic dimension of road freight transport is extremely important and, therefore, the introduction of forms of taxation has a negative impact on the competitiveness of Made in Italy. In particular, the introduction of increases at mountain passes applies massively to Italy, leading to competitive distortions in the context of the Single European Market. We must prevent the Eurovignette, designed to generate resources and protect the environment, from becoming a mere tax entry for the countries of Central Europe to the detriment of the exporting countries on the periphery of the European Union. I support the rapporteur's proposal on the use of revenue to meet investment needs and to promote the maintenance and technological development of the road sector. Finally, I would like to express my opposition to the road congestion tax.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will admit that I am not delighted with this project. It has many drawbacks, creates new burdens for drivers, for car owners, more. I must say that the last time it is systematic taxation and gasoline, and fees, and parking et cetera, et cetera. But something needs to be done, we must not be indifferent to those challenges that are related to climate protection, with respect for those who do not have means of transport, and are negative beneficiaries of the development of motoring.  On the other hand, I will draw attention to one element which, from my point of view, is very important, to the clarity of politics, to building it so that it is understandable to those who are its addressees. Today, charging systems are extremely complex, complex, non-precise and, unfortunately, they also build hostility to the legislation that we are talking about today.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course it is a very difficult report when you want to harmonise things, when we have subsidiarity. Of course, the Member States, said the Commissioner, can set taxes, and so we now have the situation on national, international roads. But I think we had to take a step, I think we need to take this principle into account: the polluter pays. We must see how we succeed, of course, not to affect international transport, also to think of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we must take this step. I have reservations about certain amendments but, overall, this report must be voted on tomorrow, because otherwise I do not see how we can gradually move on to respecting this principle – the polluter pays – and having a simplification of the way of charging, because I was in four countries this summer and in each country there was a different tax system. Basically, it is complicated and, of course, I also think it is good that some compromises have been reached to take account of remote areas, more distant countries and to take into account the fact that Member States can reduce taxes when there are good social reasons.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the imposition of tolls has created enormous problems and reactions in Greece for the simple reason that the main roads were built with money from the European Union and the Greek State and suddenly were given to private individuals, without them having put anything in, without having made any investment. And there are too many tolls that people are reacting to. They are now reacting to the new tolls that will enter Egnatia. There are tolls and some citizens, brought to the area of Kavala, will not even be able to leave their city. They're going to have to pay a toll. We have had similar reactions in the region of Attica, because local people have to pay tolls. One realizes that the imposition of tolls at the moment in Greece is an unfair process, it only supports private companies, and the remaining tolls collected go to pay off the lenders. We believe that there should be no tolls on travel in Greece. The infrastructure was created with money from the European Union and the Greek State and individuals simply showed up to collect the profits.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: On. Notis, you're the Olympic catch-the-eye recordman. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this very concrete debate. I would like to thank again all of your Members who have contributed to this discussion. I am really encouraged by seeing that Parliament has confirmed its broad support for the Commission proposals. At the same time, I hear, of course, the concerns regarding the more controversial elements of the proposal, and let me briefly react to some of your concerns.  Some of you suggested that the EU should not regulate road charging for passenger cars. My answer is that we cannot ignore the impact of cars on infrastructure wear and tear and on the environment at local, regional and even at the global level. Cars are responsible for the lion’s share of external costs – two—thirds of CO2 emissions in road transport, which is 60% of all emissions in transport – so we cannot simply ignore that.  Next, we propose to extend the scope of the directive to high vehicles, including LDVs – where there was a comment that this is not the case.
