For zero-emission vehicles we propose incentives, and I’d like to be very clear on that – a special discount on infrastructure charges of 75% – so that is a very strong incentive.  Let me also insist one more time on the fact that the directive, tomorrow, just like today, will not force Member States to charge for infrastructure. Again, we are setting common rules. That is all we are doing. We are setting common rules, not imposing the level of charges. For example, if the UK imposes a charge on UK HGVs today, this is the result of a UK decision. This proposal does not change that fact.  Allow me also to stress that road charges are not a tax, as this is a way to pay for a service – access to the infrastructure – and for externalities. The Commission has actually proposed allowing Member States to have some additional vehicle tax incentives, if I can call them that, on HGVs in parallel with the introduction of tolls. So this can be already done, and this is part of the proposal.  The Commission receives also numerous complaints about discrimination against foreign motorists, especially from border areas, and recurring complaints against national charging schemes. I do believe that common principles, agreed at EU level, are needed and justified, and all the more so as Member States remain fully free to decide whether to charge or not, but if they do, there are certain rules they should respect – common rules. It is also worth mentioning that common principles are an important element of seamless mobility models that we are foreseeing in the forthcoming years.  As a final remark, let me express one more time my real appreciation for the work you have done. It was crucial to conclude the discussions in Parliament before the elections and I am confident that the position adopted in the European Parliament will serve as a solid base for the negotiations with the Council, so I really look forward to a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for this debate and for the extremely strong opinions, thank you commissioner for your commitment and your words. Many of the concerns that have been raised in this debate are in fact already covered by the report, particularly on issues related to social issues and the principle of subsidiarity. However, I will go back to one point in particular, which would suggest that excluding light vehicles from the scope of this text would be tantamount to "defending" road users. It is quite the opposite because, in fact, excluding light vehicles means voting against reducing tolls by 75% for zero-emission vehicles and voting against reducing tolls for cars that emit less CO2. Excluding light vehicles is therefore penalizing users who are increasingly moving towards clean vehicles and we must not have a short-term vision of the future of road infrastructure pricing. Excluding light vehicles also means voting against reducing tolls for frequent users who have to use toll roads to get to work. But that's not all, excluding cars from the scope is also giving states the opportunity to introduce more discriminatory sticker systems between residents and non-residents.  Those who claim to defend road users by wanting to exclude light vehicles are in fact doing the opposite: they are opposed to fairer road pricing for taxpayers, who now pay for road maintenance in many countries, and for users who will not benefit from the toll modernization proposals included in this report. In conclusion, I would therefore like to call on all colleagues not to reduce the level of ambition of the text in order to arrive at a strong position of the European Parliament, particularly with a view to negotiations with the Member States.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 25, 2018.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Andrzej Grzyb, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2009/33/EC on the promotion of clean and energy-efficient vehicles in road transport (COM(2017)0653 - C8-0393/2017 - 2017/0291(COD)) (A8-0321/2018).

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab Today we are dealing with the revision of the Clean Vehicles Directive, the current version of which, for many reasons – I will not mention them – does not work as we would expect. It was therefore necessary to decide whether we are abandoning this regulation at all or reforming a system that is not the most perfect. The Commission decided on the latter solution by proposing a system based on binding purchase, leasing or public tendering services.  In the work in the European Parliament, we first of all had to answer the question of how we understand the definition of a clean vehicle. The majority considered that, in addition to zero-emission vehicles, there should also be vehicles with the best chance of reducing pollutants into the air, both by dust, nitrogen oxides, but also by other pollutants. In seeking an appropriate solution, we decided to base the definition of clean vehicle on an already existing and agreed text, using the fuel list contained in the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive, with certain restrictions on biofuels, in particular the first generation. In this way, we have created synergies between the new law and the existing law. This will promote clean transport, support the development of new technologies such as electric cars or alternative fuels, and thus also improve air quality, allow us to fight smog, a new difficult phenomenon in many cities, and make a brick in the way of achieving the climate objectives agreed in the Paris Agreement.  The objectives that we have adopted must be acho maniable for the public actors who will implement this directive. These regulations must also take into account the principle of subsidiarity. I must therefore stress the need to ensure that these objectives are financed at an appropriate level. Otherwise, local authorities will not be able or unable to buy vehicles whose price currently far exceeds the price of traditional vehicles. It is often twice as high, for example in the case of buses. As a result, they will be slower to replace their rolling stock, which could jeopardise the development of public transport. Many local authorities also have tasks to do, which are related to public transport in non-urban areas, in rural space. There you need a completely different technology when it comes to the drive for these buses. One of the objectives of the Directive is to create contracts for low-emission vehicles on such a scale as to support innovation and the production of vehicles based on new solutions. However, we must also bear in mind European producers so that they do not fall victim to unfair competition. That is why tomorrow we will be voting on an amendment to restore a level playing field for all producers and to encourage those countries that do not allow European producers into their public procurement markets to do so. Otherwise, vehicles produced by companies originating in such countries will not be able to be counted against the objectives of the Directive.  I would also like to appeal – I think I can also say this on behalf of all the shadow rapporteurs, to whom I thank you very much for your cooperation in the work on this regulation – to the Presidency that the European Parliament will be ready to open negotiations from tomorrow. We therefore ask that the Council conclude its work on the general approach quickly so that we can adopt the directive before the end of this parliamentary term.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission welcomes the opportunity today to discuss Mr Grzyb’s report on the revision of the Clean Vehicles Directive, which is an important part of the Clean Mobility Package. The Commission warmly welcomes the progress made in the European Parliament on this file and would like to thank Mr Grzyb and the shadow rapporteurs for their very ambitious work. Let me recall the context of the proposal. The Paris (COP21) Agreement requires substantive emission reductions from all parts of our economy, including transport. The recent special report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) on the impacts of climate change is yet another wake-up call in that respect. We must ensure that we are firmly on the path towards zero emission by mid-century. Among many other things, this means faster deployment of more efficient transport systems, low— and zero—emission vehicles and increased use of alternative energy sources. Public procurement has a special role to play here. This is particularly true in the bus sector, where public procurement represents around 70% of all new vehicle registrations. Public authorities are already today leading the way in the fight against climate change. I therefore welcome this general support in the Parliament’s report for the objectives and the approach that the Commission proposes for the revision of the Clean Vehicles Directive. On some aspects the report goes even further than our initial ambition, by extending its scope to other services and vehicle categories. Compared to the Commission’s proposal, the report takes a different approach to the definition of clean vehicles. It includes all fuels under the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive and introduces sub-targets for low—and zero—emission vehicles. As regards heavy—duty vehicles, as you know, we are not yet able to define emission thresholds. We’re working on it. Including all fuels under the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive could therefore be considered, provided that a sufficient level of ambition for zero-emission vehicles is maintained throughout the sub-targets. For light—duty vehicles, however, we are able to use emission thresholds to define clean vehicles. In my view, this approach remains the best solution for light—duty vehicles, as it is technology-neutral and more future proof. The amended directive should provide a clear long-term market signal allowing public authorities, manufacturers and investors to plan the transition towards zero—emission mobility, based on the technologies and fuels that they deem most suitable. I am pleased to know that work in the Council is also progressing fast and that a general approach is in reach. So let’s therefore all work together to secure a trilogue agreement before the Parliament recess. A timely adoption would be an important step towards the de—carbonisation of mobility. We should not postpone this important piece of legislation. I stand, of course, ready to provide all my support in the upcoming negotiations. I welcome your ambition and I really look forward to your debate.

name: Andor DELI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur for being able to achieve consensus around very difficult issues in this dossier. As a rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) I can say that in TRAN we wanted to have an even more simplified directive, but nevertheless we welcome the fact that a couple of key elements have been taken on board from the TRAN opinion. Firstly, to link this dossier clearly to the Alternative Fuels Infrastructure Directive and to maintain a proper level of technical neutrality. Secondly, I am happy that the ʻwell-to-wheelʼ approach on vehicle emissions was taken on board and that there is a clear deadline for the Commission to propose a methodology for this by the end of 2022. Finally, the most important thing is to make sure that by changing legislation, the obligations are not creating an additional financial burden for the Member States nor leading to a reduction in public transport services or to higher ticket prices that are passed on to passengers. The EU should give assistance in this regard, especially to the cohesion countries.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is certainly justified that public procurement should also aim to promote environmental friendliness and clean vehicles. However, it is important to leave sufficient flexibility and room for manoeuvre at Member State level, because conditions vary greatly across Europe and Member States, municipalities and regions have the best idea of how best to promote clean transport. It is indeed a shortcoming that it has not been possible to define heavy equipment and the use of biofuels for clean transport. We know that biofuels play an important role in clean transport and it is certainly a shortcoming that it has not been possible to take this into account at an adequate level. In addition, the calculation method, which only looks at emissions from the end of the exhaust pipe, does not adequately cover the entire energy consumption and environmental impact. In this respect, therefore, we should be able to promote and improve the calculation method, on the basis of which it is determined what is considered to be a clean vehicle. I am very pleased that the Committee on the Environment has drawn attention to the battery industry and its development needs in Europe. As electronic traffic progresses, it is increasingly important that battery production is also sustainable. This means that we need to have a significant battery industry in Europe, and we must also get raw materials from Europe. At the moment, Europe is far too dependent on import guarantees, imported goods. It is not sustainable at the moment either, and certainly not when the need is going to increase significantly.

name: Seb DANCE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this and to the shadows as well. I think we have reached a good position.  The European Union, of course, is undergoing, like the rest of the world, a transition towards sustainable zero carbon mobility – a transition that is, of course, inevitable if we are to be serious about tackling climate change. The question that we are all grappling with is how soon we do it. Last month, this Parliament voted for ambitious new CO2 standards for cars and vans and, together with the Clean Vehicles Directive revision, we can accelerate this transition towards much cleaner public procurement in Europe, as well, I think, as creating a renewed European market through the creation of, if you like, a premium market through public procurement.  Public procurement is 14% of the EU’s GDP and 75% of new bus registrations, and it is essential that we use taxpayers’ money effectively to procure clean vehicles. It is also important, of course, that public authorities set an example to the rest of the economy when it comes to the transition away from fossil fuels. But I have to be honest, I didn’t support initially the alignment with the Directive on Alternative Fuels Infrastructure (DAFI) because I thought that it would weaken the targets but the inclusion of strong sub—targets are very important on this for zero-emission vehicles and I am pleased that we have managed to reach an agreement. I will, of course, be voting for the strongest and most ambitious targets.  It is crucial now that local authorities and governments put their money where their mouth is and ensure that local authorities are properly funded to remove the burden of compliance on local governments and make sure that air pollution targets can be met without penalising local authorities that are cash-strapped. Crucially, tomorrow’s vote in Parliament will mean that we can get this file done under this Presidency, because progress is so important on this. The ball is now firmly in the Council’s court and I hope that we can get sufficient progress quickly.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Thank you, Mr President. Dear Commissioner, in order to really do something about climate change, we need smart and cost-effective policies. Countries cannot solve this alone. They can't solve climate change on their own. We need to tackle this europeanly and globally.  That is why I welcome this legislation, which ensures that when governments have to buy new cars or buses, we say that they should be clean cars and buses. I think that is important when you consider that, unlike most other sectors, CO2 emissions from the transport sector are still rising. Moreover, I also think that the government should lead by example in the purchase of new cars, and I also think that if you spend taxpayers' money on new city buses or other cars, you are going to spend it well. But the beauty of this legislation is that, finally, it stimulates the demand for clean cars, thereby increasing the development of cleaner cars, making them cheaper and thus becoming more accessible to more people.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the only clean vehicle available on the market today is the bicycle: it is zero CO2 emissions. That is why, Commissioner, I hope that we will step up our efforts to ensure that all cities have more bikes. The goal for tomorrow's car is to have zero emissions. And the way is opened with this text on vehicles acquired by the public order, because the transport sector is still 23% of CO2 emissions in Europe, because most of that 23% is emitted on the road, because the report of the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) recently said that we are approaching the last limit to save the climate and because public control is 14% of European GDP, a major lever for the transition to sustainable mobility. And in the face of that, the Conservatives are telling us: technology is not ready. But why are China and the United States already on the verge of getting there? We have the opportunity to define what a clean vehicle should be and you conservatives, you leave the door still open to vehicles running on biofuel. But is it reasonable to look again at the past, when we are taking you into the 21st century? The house is burning, our lungs are getting dirty and you prefer to look elsewhere. After me the flood. I believe that we must be responsible, open our eyes and this text must be ambitious.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, let me thank the rapporteur for the hard work he has done on the document. From my point of view, this is an absolutely crucial measure in the transition to clean mobility. Without this document, we will not even be able to partially meet the exorbitant targets that we voted for here last time in the context of Mrs Dalli's report. I am therefore extremely sorry for the approach taken by the Austrian Presidency to discuss the directive, which is in no hurry to conclude it. It is not at all clear whether we will be able to conclude the document in this legislative period, yet without massive public sector assistance, the market for clean vehicles cannot be opened up in a timely and sufficiently broad manner.  On the adopted text, I certainly welcome the sensible definition of a clean vehicle. What I do not like, however, is the over-fixation of the 2025 targets only on electric vehicles. The solution adopted by the Committee does not take into account the billions of dollars spent on infrastructure for LPG and CNG cars, which, while slightly higher in CO2 than the 50g received, are significantly lower than conventionally powered vehicles. If Member States have invested billions of public funds in these technologies in the last few years, they cannot be punished for this activity today. I would also like to ask you to reject the initiative to include construction machinery. This is the pressure of a narrow group of lobbyists, the purpose of which is not to make the environment easier, but above all to fill the pockets of their producers.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a fact that public procurement has not stimulated the spread of clean vehicles, and that is precisely why we were, of course, driven the Commission and prompted the European Parliament to work and update this important directive, which represented an opportunity to change things. Unfortunately, however, from our point of view, for the 5 Star Movement, we are wasting it. Tying up until 2030 the definition of a clean vehicle to fuels that are dirty, such as oil and natural gas, means clearing the way for the transformation of the market on the demand side, in particular buses, which are now mainly powered by diesel, in fact also disregarding the recommendations of the EMIS committee, the committee that investigated precisely the dieselgate scandal , which urged public authorities to buy zero-emission vehicles. From our point of view, this updated text complicates even more the procurement procedures for the authorities of the Member States that will have to buy clean vehicles. The definition of a clean vehicle, as it is present in this text today, has in fact not allowed us to insist on an operation, that of retrofitting, which is, from our point of view, fundamental to updating, improving and really having vehicles that are clean on the roads. Unfortunately, we had to remove this reference. From our point of view, we have underestimated the virtuous example of metropolises such as Rome and Barcelona, which from 2025 will only equip themselves with electric buses, and we have underestimated the potential of our companies, which are world leaders in the supply of components for electrification. Despite the inclusion of sub-targets for zero-emission vehicles, the amended directive will not help to bridge the gap between Europe and China, where 380 000 electric buses are already circulating today, compared to a few thousand in Europe, and will therefore play a limited role in combating air pollution in our cities.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Public transport is the solution to many problems in cities, as far as it is environmentally friendly.  That is what we are ensuring with this directive. We are making it easier for local authorities to achieve the objectives of the directive by also recognising hybrids. Here, however, we should make it clear once again tomorrow that we are only talking about plug-in hybrids.  It is also important to me that the municipalities receive support for fleet renewal. This support will come from the European Union, but it will also have to be supplemented by the Member States. This involves financial aid and the development of the charging infrastructure. In the direction of my Conservative colleagues, however, I must also make one thing clear here today: economic protectionism, as provided for in Amendment 82, does not clean up the air in European cities. With this populist Trump policy, you are harming European citizens who have to breathe bad air. With this amendment, you are ensuring that dirty air must later be defined as clean air, as happened last time in Germany. German Chancellor Angela Merkel has made a desperate attempt. This must not become a European policy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to appreciate your generosity, because I was to replace you in the Chair a few minutes ago, and thanks very much for doing the overtime. I think that, having been a shadow in the Committee for Transport and Tourism (TRAN) for the ALDE Group, I can subscribe to what Mr Deli has submitted on behalf of the TRAN Committee. But let me make maybe two or three somewhat different remarks, because I can subscribe to basically nearly all that has been said. I think that we need to perceive this as an issue which still needs a mindset change. We still are working through legislation which is correct. We still need to sort of impose, we still need to motivate, but it’s not yet genuine. And if we look at the policies, one policy, one regulation, one directive, one piece of legislation will not make a difference. I think that we need to basically harmonise the policies on the European level, on the national level and on the municipal level. That is something that requires a mindset and also stimulus and, let’s say, motivation, not just thresholds. Iʼm sure that we can manage.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Mr President, most of the buses and cars in the administration are highly polluting. To compensate for this situation, it is common sense for your new vehicles to be zero emissions. I admit it's not the easiest thing to do, but believe me, it's the most responsible and the fairest. Un experts are very clear. To seize the great economic, social and ecological opportunities of the Paris Climate Agreement, we need much more ambitious measures and involve the whole of society. Aesthetic changes no longer work. Trying to whiten dirty energies with misleading labels does not help to take action at the height of the great climate challenge. It's a matter of political vision. The public administration to be an example to society, to set the bar high and always go one step ahead. That is, lead, such as Barcelona, Madrid or Valencia, in Spain, for example, lead the energy transition, the fight for the climate and for a cleaner air.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, the objectives of this Directive are clear: to reduce pollution, to eliminate greenhouse gases and to promote road transport, both public and private, clean and non-polluting. But above all they are urgent targets.  This means increasing the efficiency of vehicles with the aim of achieving zero emissions as soon as possible, but also the environmental commitment to the recycling of the material used in the production of vehicles and the reuse of them. The excuses of the automotive sector, such as the different maturity of the vehicle market, to circumvent environmental requirements are not acceptable. The standard provides for sufficient adaptation time, and industrial added value is in European battery production, among others. But it is also the public procurement of passenger transport vehicles that must play an essential role in ensuring that the objectives are met, and this is undoubtedly to increase aid and resources for local administrations.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, promoting the use of clean and energy-efficient road transport vehicles is a priority, but the priority requires public authorities to take greater responsibility They must be an example and must be engines for implementing intelligent, clean and inclusive mobility systems. The target of 75% for the minimum percentage of clean vehicles, to be included in procurement tenders by 2030, and incentives for the use of zero-emission shelters are very important. First, to improve the air quality of cities, creating better living conditions and healthier environments. Secondly, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, in line with the targets set out in the Paris Agreement, and finally to boost European industry into the technological transition, creating more and better working conditions. But let us be pragmatic, Commissioner, this priority, to be a priority, must be present in the allocation of the financial resources associated with the different cohesion, convergence and competitiveness programmes, which are key to supporting the transition and building the necessary infrastructure.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have a very green day today, but I will say right away that it is probably also quite expensive for individual users, for manufacturers, for legal entities. Why did I say that? Because I would always like to be aware of all the consequences and costs of the changes that have been made with such votes, so that the effects can also be estimated on those who are poorer, who simply cannot afford certain things today.  This does not mean that I am against the introduction of all these environmental provisions, I am actually fighting for this to happen. However, I must admit that I am surprised to see from time to time speeches on the left side of the political scene, where this attention to ecology and the poorest unfortunately does not go hand in hand. Who drives the worst cars today, the biggest polluters? The poorest. If we increase the cost of producing cars, we increase the cost of using them, but unfortunately we make it more difficult for those who are less well off.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, zero-emission mobility must certainly be something that will concern us and we must have it as a strategy, a green mobility in fact. But this must also be done gradually, carefully, weightedly and balancedly. Of course, the necessary investments must be made and, in order to do so, the public sector could also be exploited. Public authorities, to the extent that they intend to purchase new buses or means of transport, should really contribute to having investments that are compatible with the environment. On the other hand, however, as far as the private sector is concerned, we must pay attention to both individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises. Change and the transition to new technologies cannot be imposed once and for all, because this means great costs and is impossible to cope with. They too must have financial incentives to move on to these changes.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the European Union, in the context of environmental protection due to climate change, has undertaken to reduce, up to zero, carbon dioxide emissions in the transport sector. In order to implement this commitment, clean vehicles and energy efficient vehicles should be produced and used. This effort must also be combined with the creation of infrastructure for the production of alternative fuels, since today 95% of vehicles use fossil fuels. Public procurement also plays an important role. States should give these incentives, especially finances, so that both individuals and companies can obtain clean vehicles. Finally, manufacturers of clean vehicles should be protected from unfair competition created by the production of these vehicles in third countries.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for this stimulating debate. I am happy to know that there is broad support in Parliament for these proposals and objectives. Let me comment on some of your questions and comments. On the comment related to EU manufacturers, most EU manufacturers already have clean vehicles on the market and are investing to further expand their offer well before the date of application of this revised directive. Many EU cities, regions and transport authorities have also already taken strategic decisions to advance the introduction of clean vehicles. The proposal will not penalise EU manufacturers. On the contrary, it will facilitate their investment planning and help them remain competitive in this market. This is particularly needed in light of the quickly accelerating global competition and increasing market share of non-EU manufacturers. In addition, the Commission is open to considering an alternative approach, based on alternative fuels, only if the proposed sub—targets for zero-emission vehicles are maintained at a necessary level of ambition. Finally, let me stress again that I warmly welcome your ambition to conclude the negotiation before the parliamentary recess. There are of course certain aspects that will need to be clarified in cooperation with the Council, but I am confident that the right solution can be found and swift agreement can be reached between the co-legislators. Therefore, I look forward to the adoption of Mr Grzyb’s report in plenary tomorrow.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thank you very much for this debate. I can say that, for example, this indicator that seventy per cent of buses are bought in public procurement shows how much impact public procurement can have on the replacement of rolling stock and on its quality, and on the level of emissions that this rolling stock goes for.  On the other hand, we are also aware that in public transport, for example, the use of buses is not a period of seven or eight years, as in the case of cars, for example passenger cars. This is often a period of fifteen years, and therefore there is a proposal here, which has also been criticised, retrofitting, that is, the reconstruction of the drive units in these buses. We believe that this is extremely important because many local authorities – for example, Tallinn, many other cities – in consultation when we met with representatives of local and regional authorities – have spoken about this. We have done this work. What is more important to buy one new electric bus or to replace, for example, ten buses with old diesel engines? It seems to me that here we get much greater results in a shorter period of time. Each of these elements will have an impact on the final effect of the objective that we want to achieve with this directive.  The second issue, of course, is biofuels. We are convinced that, with the objectives that we have set ourselves in the recirculation economy and with the experience that local authorities show us, the introduction of biofuels, in particular those derived from, for example, recycled organic waste, is also an objective that is already being achieved in many local authorities, within so-called energy clusters or local energy communities. That is what we should take into account. Finally, I would also like to say that many local authorities have also started to make changes to their public transport and service services towards clean vehicles. Often, the proportion of these vehicles in countries that are not the richest is much higher than in countries that have much higher GDP per capita. So local governments have noticed this opportunity to improve air quality, because transport is responsible for forty to sixty percent of emissions. So I think we have allies here – not only those who defend themselves against European regulation, but also those who want to benefit from this regulation. Commissioner, thank you very much for your cooperation and for your declarations as well. Fast work on the final negotiations.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Grzyb, I must say that at the end of your words I already started dreaming about clean vehicles and energy efficiency on railways and in aviation. I think we still have some things to do. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The directive adopted is a very ambitious project, which will entail major changes for many local and regional entities covered by public procurement law. However, I am convinced that the example must go ahead and the promotion of green and energy-efficient vehicles in public institutions is an important step towards CO2 emissions in the European Union. I believe that the rapporteur has succeeded in reaching a proposal that reconciles the public interest in a balanced way with the challenges faced by local governments and vehicle manufacturers. I agree that contracting authorities and entities will need support, including financial support, from the Union, as the ecological transformation will entail costs that may be difficult for smaller entities to bear. I also consider it important to have rules to protect EU producers from unfair competition.

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " Clean air, environmental protection – this is a condition of generational civilization! Today we are looking for a way to minimise the harmful effects of road transport on the environment. We should reduce the number of internal combustion vehicles, especially in our cities. The network of subways, trams and trolleybuses can be an excellent response to the corked streets of modern agglomerations. Using electricity as a driving force for transport is a viable and proven alternative. However, it is essential that this energy is obtained in an environmentally clean, efficient and... Cheap! Poland has a great track record in this field. Using the latest technologies, we can generate electricity in a low-carbon, efficient and low-cost way. Modern coal-fired power plants offer us this opportunity. We should fight not with Polish coal, but with global emissions!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on promoting automatic mutual recognition of diplomas, tabled by Petra Kammerevert, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education (O-000084/2018 – B8—0415/2018) – (2018/2838(RSP)).

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has done. It is remarkable: I do not believe that there is a head of government in the EU who does not want workers in the EU as a whole to become more mobile. Wherever possible, we stress that the European labour market lacks the will to be more mobility- If we want mobile workers, we must finally enable them to be mobile. This can only be done through education and training, and it can only be done by automatically recognising learning periods abroad in the EU. However, the reality is different: the vast majority of pupils who complete a longer-term study abroad lose a school year in their home country. In 1997, almost a quarter of a century ago, the Lisbon Convention was adopted. In principle, this Convention is intended to recognise a university entrance qualification granted in the Contracting State in all Contracting States, as well as degrees and periods of study, without any problems. However, non-compliance with this principle is a reality: recognition procedures take months, administrative procedures between Member States, even in some cases between regions within a Member State, are not coordinated. Despite European guidelines, local tax bases vary considerably. Career planning based on educational attainment obtained abroad is therefore still almost impossible. Those affected feel swayed and exposed to arbitrariness. For 25 years, we have not been able to overcome such hurdles in the European Higher Education Area, and even more so in the educational area to be created, in such a way that it seems attractive enough for trainees to complete learning periods abroad. Our students are best off, but each of us is likely to know a person in his or her own environment who is studying or training, who is grumting with what appears to be nonsensical, lengthy procedures. The free movement of workers remains a right that actually exists only on paper. Or do the counter-test: has you recently met any young European who said: "I spent a training period abroad, my recognition went perfectly smoothly, in two weeks everything was done, great!"? I don't. Exactly what was supposed to be a reality for 25 years sounds like a joke to our ears today. That, ladies and gentlemen, is the real scandal! Now, thankfully, the Commission is trying to launch a proposal to promote automatic recognition. As recently as November, at the Gothenburg Summit, all the Member States declared that the European Education Area was a huge step forward and, above all, that it was extremely important. However, as soon as it comes to the concrete implementation of the idea, unfortunately, the over-the-top concerns win again: an automatic system is not compatible with subsidiarity. Why not? Because if it is entirely up to the Member States to create such an automatic system within seven years, I do not know where there is to be a violation of subsidiarity. It is immediately assumed that the Commission is involved in learning content. However, this is not at any point in the proposal. Those who can read have a clear advantage here. Surely it really cannot be too much to agree within the next seven years on automatic recognition of learning periods, which eliminates the need for separate recognition procedures, especially as all EU Member States have committed themselves to the Lisbon Convention, and have done so for almost 20 years now. I have the impression that the wake-up call that the Commission launched with the Gothenburg Summit was still too quiet to be heard in the Member States and, above all, to be understood in this clarity. The fact that the European Education Area's goal by 2025 not only sounds nice, but is, in my view, an increasingly urgent problem to be solved in terms of skills shortages, language skills shortages, deficits in the field of mathematics and science, deficits in digital skills and the increasing demand for more mobile workers, has, in my view, been completely insufficiently understood by the Member States. There is no other explanation for why some are so opposed to automatisms in mutual recognition. I firmly believe that we need to be much more committed to the ideas for achieving a European Education Area by 2025. Ultimately, it is a question of justice and esteem: not only to students whose mobility through the European Higher Education Area has already been developed. Politically, we must offer this advantage much better to trainees and school leavers. In this respect, I hope that tomorrow, as in the Committee on Culture, the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education and the European Parliament, will finally have a broad majority and that the Heads of State or Government will finally come to reflection.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Commission. – Mr President, I am taking this question on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Navracsics, who unfortunately cannot be here this evening. On behalf of the Commission I would like to thank Ms Kammerevert for tabling this oral question at a time when the Commission and Council are discussing the Commission’s proposal for a Council recommendation on promoting the automatic mutual recognition of higher education and upper secondary education diplomas, and the outcomes of learning periods abroad. The question is a strong sign of support for this important topic in the Parliament, and I would like to thank you for that. Indeed, automatic mutual recognition of diplomas and study periods abroad is key for ensuring the free movement of learners across Europe. It is a key element in creating a European education area, where learning, studying and carrying out research are unimpeded by borders. Learning mobility fosters competences and experiences help people to participate more effectively in society and in the labour market. It fosters labour mobility, contributing to individual and economic resilience. The recent mid-term evaluation of the Erasmus+ programme demonstrates that mobility has a positive impact on learners’ confidence, independence and transition to employment. When compared to their non-mobile peers, Erasmus students are more entrepreneurial, have better language skills and are more likely to get a job. However, in order to make learning mobility a reality, it is crucial that learners have the confidence that their qualifications in another country would be recognised upon their return. I am therefore glad that from next month, Member States will make a political commitment to put in place by 2025 the steps that are needed for automatic recognition of higher education and upper secondary education qualifications, and the outcomes of learning periods abroad. This political commitment will be accompanied by actions to help Member States to build trust in each other’s education systems, because without trust, automatic recognition will not work. The Commission will be supporting Member States in this process through a series of concrete actions, such as exchanges of good practice, building synergies between EU transparency tools, and exploring the potential of digital technologies – in particular blockchain – to facilitate automatic recognition. The Commission, through the Erasmus+ programme, also provides funding to the national academic recognition information centres to facilitate cooperation and recognition. This year alone, EUR 1 million was allocated to these projects, including digital exchange of student data, creating a digital database of school-leaving qualifications, and the recognition of qualifications held by refugees. Of course, we are not starting from scratch. Several Member States already have systems which allow for automatic recognition of diplomas, and we can learn from them. For example, there is the Benelux decision on the automatic recognition of higher education qualifications; the Nordic and Baltic agreements to recognise higher education and school leaving qualifications; bilateral agreements, such as the one between France and Italy on the recognition of school leaving qualifications; and the Nordic, Franco-German, Austrian and Italian arrangements to recognise mobility periods during secondary education. The Commission is convinced that its vision for a European education area and the many initiatives that stem from it will enable Member States to make progress quickly while inspiring the non-EU Member States in wider European higher education. This impetus is important, because after 30 years of cooperation through both the Lisbon Recognition Convention and the Erasmus programme, learners still face avoidable problems with the recognition of their diplomas and study periods abroad. This is not acceptable. In conclusion, let me underline that improving learning mobility and the exchange of ideas have a positive impact on education systems throughout Europe, and they contribute to the creation of a dynamic, innovative education community. There is no evidence that automatic recognition will cause a brain drain or weaken Member States’ education systems. On the contrary, it will ensure that learners can study abroad with the confidence that their learning outcomes and their qualifications will be recognised. This will encourage – and should encourage – more learners to participate and return after their time abroad, and more academic and education institutes can support mobility and automatic recognition. I wish to thank again Ms Kammerevert for raising this question, and I look forward to hearing the views of the Members.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, I think we can agree with the need for automatic recognition of higher education results in other Member States. The objectives are in line with what is happening in the Bologna Process, which is linked to the emerging European education area and should be further strengthened. We also support the idea that qualifications at upper secondary education level should be automatically recognised for further study in another Member State. The European Union needs to have a better framework for the recognition of educational outcomes and recognition of qualifications than that offered today by the Lisbon Convention. The Commission should therefore shed light on its precise intentions. Its proposal for a Council recommendation is addressed to the Member States, but the European Parliament plays an important role here and cannot be left out.  As regards the Council recommendation itself, I consider it important to better define the term learning agreement, because in some parts of the text it refers to tertiary and in some cases only to secondary education. Our oral question therefore rightly points to a number of other aspects, such as the fact that the Commission should be clear about bilateral agreements on the recognition of qualifications between Member States. In short, we are moving towards the use of the energy that the European Union is putting into erasmus+ and others in a meaningful way.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the effective automatic mutual recognition of secondary diplomas is a prerequisite without which we will not be able to achieve a genuine people's Europe and, more particularly, a genuine European education area by 2025. This is a political priority for the CULT Committee and for parliament as a whole, which is the spokesman for citizens' demands, and on which I hope that the Education, Youth, Culture and Sport Council on 6 November will make concrete commitments. The effective use of the principle of the free movement of persons, whether students or workers, and freedom of establishment also depends on the removal of all those obstacles which, in fact, do not allow to date or do not facilitate the possibility of working, especially for young people, in one Member State thanks to the recognition of the degree acquired in another State. All the investigations confirm this worrying reality. To date, around 65 % of Europeans with a qualification find it difficult to have them recognised outside their own country, and 59 % of those studying for a period in an institution in an EU country other than their own have difficulty validating credits once they return to their country. To date, progress has been made, but only through bilateral agreements between certain States, steps which are, moreover, important references to the automatic recognition of diplomas throughout the EU. As the European Union, we must therefore take a new course so that the Member States, overcoming resistance and reluctance, mutually recognise the value of qualifications awarded by other EU Member States, if necessary by defining additions to curricula in order to acquire substantially homogeneous levels of preparation for, for example, declarations of comparability of upper secondary school diplomas. All this in order to finally create a real European education area that allows strong mobility for students, teachers and workers, taking due account of the objective needs of people with disabilities or disadvantaged people, including refugees and migrants.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services and the free movement of students and workers in the Union are fundamental principles of the Treaties, which are at the root of European construction. However, these freedoms in practice are not yet guaranteed and the process of mutual recognition of diplomas in secondary and higher education is still not well developed. In the Member States there are professions whose exercise is reserved for persons with certain professional qualifications and whose level and content are established within each national education system. In recent years we have adopted directives for the mutual recognition of diplomas, certificates and other degrees of academic and vocational training. Substantial progress has been made in higher education, in particular through agreements between Member States, which can inspire automatic recognition within the European Education Area. Among the measures we suggest I would like to highlight the regular issuance of declarations of comparability of higher secondary education diplomas; systematic use of the ratings table and the European credit transfer system; the use of a European student card with the aim of facilitating mutual recognition of diplomas and learning periods abroad, while reducing administrative burdens and costs. Through this Resolution which accompanies the oral question from our Committee on Culture and Education to the Commission, we call for the accelerated cooperation in the field of education for the automatic mutual recognition of diplomas. Improved cooperation in European education is a positive game, more freedoms for citizens and greater benefits for all.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission's proposal for automatic joint recognition of higher and secondary education degrees is yet another attempt to remove the right that Member States have so far to shape their education systems, the content of qualifications and teaching methods. The implementation of the proposal is also based on a tool-based view of knowledge and education, the qualification market and the pieces of knowledge certified and recognised throughout Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's recommendations to the Council seek, through homogenisation, to bring education systems in the Member States into line with the political priorities of the neoliberal European Union. We have seen in practice the results now of the Bologna Process and the Commission's guidelines and education, Commissioner. The political priorities of the neoliberal European Union in education are the degradation and underfunding of public education, the conversion of studies into educational products, the introduction of tuition fees in universities, the subordination of curricula to the requirements of the market, degrees without real rights, the deterioration of the role of students and teachers in the decision-making process, the ejection of the 'brain drain' phenomenon which mainly benefits the powerful countries to the detriment of the countries of the South. I don't know if that's what we're talking about. Three hundred thousand scientists have left Greece in the years of crisis and have gone to stronger countries. The creation of a European area for education therefore completes these reforms. In Greece, the education movement claims educational institutions that will promote universal knowledge, increase government spending on education, upgrade the role of teachers and teachers, public and free education for all and, finally, overturn austerity policies to combat unemployment.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, EUR 11,000 is the price that some 500 Italian lawyers have been willing to pay in order to obtain a precious sesame: the registration of the Madrid bar, thus bypassing the skimming of Italian authorisation. Ridiculous, scandalous, this miscellaneous fact is nevertheless only one of the avatars of the many absurdities that abound on the fertile ground of the recognition of diplomas and professional titles in Europe. French medical students who have gone to more lenient Romanian skies will not tell you anything else. Escaping the numerus clausus, however, they secured a position on their return to France, for better, but especially for worse. Especially for the worse: in 2016, a hospital in the Paris region excluded six interns trained in Romania for professional inadequacies. At a time when employers are decrying skills shortages, the Union has therefore found nothing better than to make a forced march towards automatic recognition of qualifications. Light years away from a Europe of excellence, the result will be that of the least academic and above all the levelling down.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is very late, it is 22, so in a nutshell: it is necessary to recall the source of this debate. The source of this debate was questions from the Committee on Culture about automaticity – I stress automaticity – of the recognition of diplomas, because diplomas are very often recognised, and the problem is precisely this automaticity that we lack. The question was addressed to the Commission, but the task is de facto for states to make the effort, the effort in their own countries, the automatic recognition of diplomas that arise in other countries.  Finally, I would like to draw attention to only two elements. Firstly, the importance of the Erasmus+ programme, which builds and experiences, and some common denominators for the education acquired in each country by young people from different European Union countries. And the second thing to recall is some of the legal uncertainty that is currently building as a result of a potential Brexit. I pay attention to this because young people are very keen to study in the UK. We know that this principle, which is in force at the moment, will be maintained for a transitional period, but then there may be trouble. I would like to draw your attention to this today.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, this is not the first time we have discussed in plenary the need for mutual recognition of diplomas and qualifications within the European Union. I would like to recall that this is one of the main objectives of the Bologna process, which started in 1998. Seventeen years later, in the 2015 Yerevan Communiary, ministers once again committed to working towards automatic recognition of qualifications. Now we are at the end of 2018, and there are no visible results yet. Over the past few years, we are increasingly talking about the digital single market and the importance of completing it. However, how often do we hear talk about a common European area of education?  The truth is, this is simply not a political priority. Unfortunately, students and students suffer from a lack of political will. They continue to pay for expensive e-alignment procedures, and this does not always guarantee recognition of the successful results achieved. This continued inaction directly affects the professional realization of young people. Instead of helping them, we're interfering with their future.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, with the Bologna process and reforms in higher education we have achieved greater recognition of qualifications between Member States. What made our system fragile, which was the comparability of degrees with third countries, seems to have been resolved. However, we have created a new problem which is reflected in the fact that some Member States have not completed the transition and have failed to match training between the pre-Bologna past and the new post-Bologna present. We cannot have Member States with public procurement that requires post-Bologna level training and that leave out citizens who have completed the same level curriculum equated in the pre-Bologna education framework and in some cases even with more years of study and more ECT. We are talking about automatic recognition of diplomas between Member States, but we seem to have forgotten to reconcile recognition with our recent past. At the level of transnational cooperation, using information and communication technologies, the recognition of the source qualifications for access to regulated professions takes place through the online platform Internal Market Information System. You don't have to invent the wheel to do the same across the educational system. I do not want it to be said that preparing future generations involves harmonising education at European level. The diversity of curricula allows us to prepare citizens with greater adaptation to the challenges of each Member State and gives us greater adaptability to face the future. What is needed, that is, is that Member States agree on educational compliance targets with mutual recognition of the award of a degree, without this implying the ratification of the content.  In order to fulfil a Europe with greater internal mobility, do not think that the greatest impediment is mutual recognition. It is the domain of national languages that remains its biggest obstacle.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to join my speaker, who have very significantly accentuated their support for the automatic recognition of university diplomas. It's very important, the reasons have fallen here. If we are fighting youth unemployment, then we must allow them to have their education, their qualifications applicable in any EU country, and this is linked to the Erasmus project itself. I have recently met Czech students who tell me that unfortunately the attractiveness of education in Erasmus is decreasing, because some universities have trouble counting subsequently studying and practicing within the Erasmus project in the education itself at the home kindergarten. These are problems that should be addressed and which we should not leave in the air in any way.  On the other hand, as I support mutual recognition, it must be said that there are certain fields where mutual recognition is not entirely possible. My colleague here named the issue of legal education that Italian lawyers had registered in the Madrid Law Chamber. In short, this is precisely the type of education, study of law and legal sciences, where each country, thanks to its own legal system, has its own education. This needs to be approached selectively and the fields where universal quality is possible and where this is influenced by national specificities, e.g. the legal system of a given country, are possible. Mutual recognition should not damage the principle of excellence and lead to some comparison of the quality of universities in Europe. We must maintain excellent education.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is a given that, in order to make the students themselves and teachers and scientists more mobile, diplomas must be recognised. This is something very important and I think no one disputes it. The point is, however, not to use the mechanism for the recognition of diplomas as a system of degradation of studies themselves. For example, we have the Bachelor in England which is a three-year study and these could be recognised in other Member States, such as Greece, but where university studies are four years old. So the question arises: why would anyone study at a Greek university that is four years old, since one can go to an English university and study three years and then come to Greece and have the same rights as the one who studied four years? You understand, then, that diplomas must be recognised, but in such a way that studies are not degraded and the very nature of the education system is not altered. It is a difficult exercise, but we must move on.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the enormous economic crisis affecting the countries of the European Union, and especially the countries of the South, is forcing highly educated young people and young scientists from these countries to leave and go to other countries in order to find better working conditions there. The tragic victim of this unacceptable situation is the youth of Greece, who are obliged to leave the country. Already four hundred thousand young scientists and highly educated young people have left Greece to find a way out to another country. It is therefore not the identification of the data that will solve the problem in order to prevent the brains from escaping, because we will simply enable them to move. What is needed is to create the right conditions for young scientists to remain, work and thrive in their own country. Each country has its needs, it shapes according to them its education system and that is where all the effort must be identified and focused.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you again for this discussion. Open debate and dialogue, of course, is the best way to build trust and the Commission will continue to support measures that will help to build that trust, which have been suggested by you here this evening.  Mutual trust in the quality of the education system of each single Member State is very important. This, along with the continuous focus on high quality education, is the basis of automatic mutual recognition of diplomas and learning periods abroad, so I want to assure Members that the Commission will continue to work with Member States in this direction. We have already achieved a lot, but much more still needs to be done, as has been explained here by many Members. We need our young people to be able to live in a European education area, which does not hamper their free movement as learners, and we have received a strong push to do more from our Heads of State and Government in the Council conclusions last December. We are responding in a very concrete way to give effect to these concerns and this push. I’m sure I can count on the support of all members of this House to keep this momentum up.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 25 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – I welcome the European Parliament's resolution on promoting mutual automatic recognition of diplomas. The right to education is a fundamental human right that must be guaranteed to all. Transparent recognition of foreign qualifications is both the objective of the Bologna Process and the fundamental value on which an open, inclusive European higher education area is based. I think it is important that higher education degrees are finally mutually recognised in the European Union and that the administrative barriers to recognition are finally removed. The resolution calls on the Member States to make a commitment and to establish mechanisms for the automatic mutual recognition of higher education and upper secondary education and periods of study abroad, in line with the objectives of the European Education Area. Furthermore, it calls on the Commission to support the achievement of this objective by encouraging mutual learning and the sharing of best practices, for example through the regular publication of 'declarations of comparability' attesting to upper secondary education and the consistent use of the european credit transfer system grading table. It calls on the Member States to introduce by 2025 mechanisms to facilitate automatic mutual recognition of the results of diplomas and periods of study abroad, in line with the objectives of the European Education Area and building on existing frameworks.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The implementation of automatic recognition of diplomas promotes learning mobility and encourages education abroad. Learning mobility can contribute to positive changes in educational practice, faster access to education, university development and the research sector. In addition, facilitating the recognition of diplomas and periods of study can contribute to labour market activation, labour mobility and economic development.  Unfortunately, obstacles are emerging in this regard. Students are often not guaranteed that their diplomas obtained in one Member State will be recognised in another. I support the proposed EC recommendations, the consequences of which will enable the creation of an integrated European education area and the functioning of an open European labour market, but should be implemented in all Member States. It should be noted, however, that it is the individual countries that are responsible for their education and training systems. The automatic recognition of diplomas should be without prejudice to the right of education and training institutions to decide on the admission of a candidate.  An important aspect of the project is the voluntary involvement in the proposed actions of individual countries, while respecting their competences. The planned actions should complement national actions. The current legislation in Poland already implements the idea of automatic recognition of university diplomas and secondary school leaving certificates issued in an EU, EEA and OECD country. I encourage all Member States to make a commitment in this regard.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The life of ordinary EU citizens, in particular young people, has been complicated by the lack of automatic mutual recognition of diplomas within the European Higher Education Area (EHEA). I strongly believe that the introduction of an automatic mechanism for diplomas within the EHEA will have a very positive impact on the life of EU citizens, the EU economy, education and every spectrum of social life. Therefore, I support the efforts of the Commission to encourage Member States to implement already agreed recognition mechanisms with the EHEA.  This should happen as soon as possible because nowadays the lack of mutual recognition of qualifications and study periods abroad is hampering mobility between EU Member States for the purposes of learning. I do believe that the EU should continue its efforts to encourage and support automatic mutual recognition of diplomas within the EHEA because this will facilitate mobility on the internal market and will improve the quality of the EU education system. Therefore, I warmly welcome and support the idea of automatic recognition of diplomas.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the grave lack of implementation of the EU Reach Regulation and use of non-tested chemicals in the EU (2018/2887(RSP)).

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, on the issue at hand concerning the lack of implementation of the REACH Regulation and, as a consequence, the extensive use of non-tested chemicals in the EU, the Presidency and the Council as a whole acknowledged the sentiments expressed by certain Members of this House, as well as the commitment of the other institutions to addressing this issue. The Presidency takes note of the report from the German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment, which has alerted us to the risks deriving from placing on the market potentially harmful chemicals without correctly assessing whether they are mutagenic, teratogenic or toxic. The Presidency thanks Members for drawing our attention to these risks and the magnitude of the problem. We also take note of the fact that the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) agrees with the report’s overall assessment, confirming that the quality of data on chemicals in registration dossiers still needs to improve. This view is also shared by the Presidency. In the 10 years since REACH entered into force, safety in the EU has undoubtedly increased, but there is still much to do. Both industry and the authorities must increase their efforts to improve the quality of safety information on chemicals. It should be stressed though that the Council’s role in this process has recently been very limited as no new legislation in the area of REACH has been proposed since the mid—term review in 2013. ECHA’s Enforcement Forum is currently designing tailored enforcement actions, together with Member States, to increase compliance of the dossiers concerned. In instances such as these, it is to the Commission, in its role as guardian of the Treaties and as enforcer of Union level legislation, that we should turn for guidance and action that is appropriate and justified.  On that note, if you allow me, I would like to draw your attention to the second REACH review, which was discussed in the Council bodies earlier this year. This report showed that, in the 10 years since its entry into force, REACH has become fully operational and is delivering results towards achieving its stated objectives. We should not lose sight of the progress made.  The report, however, also identifies priorities and actions needed to further improve the application of the REACH Regulation. Among these, it was noted that Member States identified the quality of registration dossiers as the main issue that needs to be addressed in a timely manner. Member States expressed concerns about two things; firstly, that some registration dossiers do not comply with the information requirement that the REACH Regulation lays down, and, secondly, how updates to registration dossiers can be ensured. As to time, in June of this year, the Commission expressed its intention to work with the European Chemicals Agency and the Member States to identify the reasons for the poor quality of dossiers’ updates. The Commission also signalled that it would make the appropriate proposals for improvements to this system by the first quarter of 2019. The Presidency is launching discussions on this issue in the Council working groups concerned. Moreover, the Presidency is convening an international conference on the future chemicals policy in October in Vienna and another one on green chemistry in November. The Presidency will provide a progress report to the Competitiveness Council, as well as to the Environmental Council. The Presidency would like to join the calls on the European Chemicals Agency, as well as on Member States, to show that they are serious about protecting human health and the environment. We call on both industry and the authorities to increase their efforts on improving the quality of registration dossiers and, of course, the Council also looks forward to any proposal that the Commission may present in the future. I would like to conclude for now by expressing my gratitude for this opportunity to join in your discussion here today. I look forward to hearing your views and to conveying them back to my colleagues in the Council.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am representing Commissioner Vella, who unfortunately cannot be here this evening. Reach is the most comprehensive chemical legislation in the world. It was designed to address the knowledge gap on the chemicals manufactured and used in Europe and to speed up risk reduction strategies for those substances that are harmful for health and harmful for the environment. The basic condition of Reach is no data, no market. This means that companies must register the chemicals they make or import. Without registration, the substance is not allowed on the market.  In these registration dossiers, the companies must detail the impact of the chemicals on human health and the environment, and how to manage those risks. Prior to registration, the European Chemicals Agency assesses all dossiers for completeness. The Chemicals Agency and the Member States’ competent authorities also carry out targeted evaluations to check that the dossiers comply with the legal requirements. The Commission is aware of recent reports indicating that an estimated one—third of the registration dossiers are non—compliant.  The need to improve compliance of registration dossiers was one of the main findings of the second review carried out earlier this year, and specific actions are already being taken to address this issue. For example, we have asked and tasked the European Chemicals Agency to increase the efficiency of the evaluation procedures by 2019. We would like to stress that already now when a dossier is found to be non—compliant, it must be remediated by the respective company and brought into compliance. The Reach Regulation requires the Chemicals Agency to check the compliance of at least 5% of all registration dossiers. The Agency does this by targeted compliance checks of the registration dossiers that matter most through its so-called integrated regulatory strategy. We are also looking at incentives to companies to regularly review the registration dossiers and update them when necessary. We should not lose sight of the fact that the Reach review confirmed that, overall, Reach is functioning and meeting its objectives, notwithstanding what I have just said. By the last registration deadline in May this year, more than 21 000 substances in 90 000 registration dossiers were registered at the European Chemicals Agency. This is a large amount of information unique in the world and it represents much more and better information on substances that are on the EU market, in 10 years.  The Reach review also confirmed that Reach improved risk management of chemicals by companies as well as communication and safety along the supply chains. Reach has also led to the listing of 191 substances of very high concern on the candidate list. This is in addition to the 68 entries on the restrictions list which represents hundreds of hazardous substances that are now banned.  Altogether, this means that hazardous chemicals are being replaced by safer alternatives. The evaluation procedure will help identify more substances of concern, I have no doubt. Enforcement is, of course, of huge importance and this is the responsibility of Member States. Coordination of their activities through the enforcement forum is proving reasonably satisfactory at EU and national level.  Based on the findings of the Reach review, I strongly believe that Reach has already contributed to the protection of EU citizens’ health and the environment, but there is much more work needed to be done to improve implementation. I am calling on the constructive cooperation of all parties involved to improve the effectiveness of our legislation.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. –Mr President, Commissioner, it is thanks to REACH that Europe has one of the most extensive chemical databases in the world, but the progress of the last ten years has not been fast or transparent enough and the challenges we had in 2009 in assessing the two years of the agency's opening are the same as we have today. It should be seen, moreover, that of the 40,000 registration submissions only four will have been rejected, which is much less than the rejections before reach was implemented. Of course, we have to take into account that ECHA only has to carry out follow-up checks on about 5% of the dossiers, yes, only in 5%. The Commission will think that the REACH procedure is a success because it imposes barriers to entry through market access requirements and hence there are only four rejections, but no. From the assessment conducted by the German Federal Institute of Risk Assessment and the German Environment Agency, it was concluded that the number of compliant substances never exceeded 50% in the criteria of biotic and abiotic gradation of bioaccumulation and ecotoxicity. Furthermore, the evaluation of this institute considered that the standard requirements are not well applied in the dossiers because they use experimental data or parallel data, or do not present full justification for the absence of data. Chemicals need to be taken more seriously and ECHA is more accountable for its assessment. One third of high-volume chemicals, manufactured or imported into the Union since 2010, do not comply with rules to protect health and the environment. We are talking about mutagenic substances with environmental toxicity that affect biodiversity and human toxicity that can induce health problems such as metabolic, oncological and endocrine diseases.  The Commission certainly knows that there are other dangerous chemicals that we regularly use with a much tighter legal mesh, medicines, but here the collaboration between Member States is much greater. Regulation does not have to be the same for chemicals and pharmaceuticals, but to defend public health. We need European agencies that can act as competent authorities and that are impervious to the interests of market self-regulation.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
